quote: The state court relies upon the case of Osborne v. Mobile, 16 Wall. 479, ... This court held that the ordinance was not unconstitutional. This was in December term, 1872. In view of the course of decisions which have been made since that time, it is very certain that such an ordinance would now be regarded as repugnant to the power Conferred upon Congress to regulate commerce among the several States.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that the holding of Osborne v. Mobile would now be regarded as unconstitutional, thereby overruling its precedential value.

cited_decision: Pensacola Telegraph Co. v. Western Union Telegraph Co. (1878)
quote: In the case of The Pensacola Telegraph Company v. The Western Union Telegraph Company, 96 U. S. 1, we held that it was not only the right, but the duty of Congress to take care that intercourse among the States and the transmission of intelligence between them be not obstructed or unnecessarily incumbered by state legislation...
rationale: The Acting Decision references Pensacola Telegraph Co. v. Western Union Telegraph Co. to support its reasoning, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: In Western Union Telegraph Company v. Texas, 105 U. S. 460, we decided that a State cannot lay a tax on the interstate business of a telegraph company, as it is interstate commerce, and that if the company accepts the provisions of the act of 1866, it becomes an agent of the United States, so far as the business of the government is concerned...
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Telegraph Co. v. Texas as precedent supporting its holding, without criticizing or limiting its authority.

cited_decision: Robbins v. Shelby County Taxing District (1887)
quote: It comes plainly within the principle of the decisions lately made by this court in Robbins v. The Taxing District of Shelby County, 120 U. S. 489...
rationale: The Acting Decision references Robbins v. Shelby County Taxing District as supporting precedent, without questioning or altering its authority.

rationale: The Acting Decision cites Philadelphia & Southern Steamship Co. v. Pennsylvania as supporting precedent, without criticizing, limiting, or otherwise altering its authority.

quote: This certificate distinctly presents for decision the question (argued, but not decided, when this case was before this court at a former term, reported in 144 U. S. 653 ) of the construction of the will of Jacob Dawson...
rationale: The Acting Decision references the earlier appearance of the case (Roberts v. Lewis, 144 U.S. 653) to note that the question was previously argued but not decided; there is no substantive discussion or critique, so the treatment is 'Mentioned'.

quote: The opinion of the Supreme Court of the State appears to have been formed upon full consideration of the difficulties of. the case; and is entitled to great weight, especially upon the construction of the statute of the State. Suydam v. Williamson, 24 How. 427.
rationale: Suydam v. Williamson is cited as authority for giving weight to state court interpretations of state statutes, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes nor distinguishes it, so it is merely 'Mentioned'.

quote: He begins by giving her 'all my estate, real and personal,' which of itself would carry a fee, unless restricted by other words. Lambert v. Paine, 3 Cranch, 97.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Lambert v. Paine as a general principle supporting its reasoning, without criticizing or limiting it, so the treatment is 'Mentioned'.

cited_decision: Brant v. Virginia Coal & Iron Co. (1876)
quote: In Brant v. Virginia Coal Co., the bequest which was held to give a life estate, and no power to convey a fee, was only of the testator’s estate, real and personal, to his wife, 'to have and to hold during her life, and to do with as she sees proper, before her death.' 93 U. S. 327.
rationale: The Acting Decision explains that Brant v. Virginia Coal Co. involved different will language and thus is not controlling; it is distinguished on its facts and wording.

quote: If the clause containing them is repugnant and void, the view of the Supreme Court of Nebraska that the widow took an estate in fee is fortified. See Howard v. Carusi, 109 U. S. 725; Potter v. Couch, 141 U. S. 296, 315, 316.
rationale: Howard v. Carusi is cited as additional support for a possible interpretation, but there is no discussion or critique, so it is 'Mentioned'.

quote: If the clause containing them is repugnant and void, the view of the Supreme Court of Nebraska that the widow took an estate in fee is fortified. See Howard v. Carusi, 109 U. S. 725; Potter v. Couch, 141 U. S. 296, 315, 316.
rationale: Potter v. Couch is cited alongside Howard v. Carusi as supporting authority, but not discussed or criticized, so it is 'Mentioned'.

quote: This court, on reconsideration of the whole matter... is of opinion that the sound construction of this will, as to the extent of the power conferred on the widow, is in accordance with the conclusion of the state court, and not with the former decision of this court, which must, therefore, be considered as overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that the former decision in Giles v. Little is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value.

quote: Due process of law, this court has held, does not require the State to adopt any particular form of procedure, so long as it appears that the accused has had sufficient notice of the accusation and an adequate opportunity to defend himself in the prosecution. Rogers v. Peck, 199 U. S. 425, 435 , and previous cases in this court there cited.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Rogers v. Peck as support for a general principle regarding due process, without criticizing, limiting, or otherwise altering its authority. The citation is used to reinforce the court's reasoning, constituting a 'Mentioned' treatment.

quote: Holding this view> notwithstanding our reluctance to overrule former decisions of this court, we now are constrained to hold that the technical enforcement of formal *647 rights in criminal procedure sustained in the Crain Case is no longer required in the prosecution of offenses under present systems of law, and so far as that case is not in accord with the views herein expressed it is necessarily overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Crain v. United States is 'necessarily overruled' to the extent it conflicts with the current opinion, which is a clear and express overruling.

quote: The position there taken that the legislature of Texas, while the State was owner of the bonds, could limit their negotiability by an act of legislation, of which all subsequent purchasers were charged with notice, although the bonds on their face were payable to bearer, must be regarded as overruled. And the further position that negotiable government securities, redeemable at the pleasure of the government after a specified day, but in which no date is fixed for final payment, cease to be negotiable as overdue after the day named when they first become redeemable, must be regarded as limited to cases where the title of the purchaser is acquired with notice of the defect of title, or under circumstances which discredit the instrument, such as would affect the title to negotiable paper payable on demand, when purchased after an unreasonable length of time from the date of issue.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that a key holding of Texas v. White 'must be regarded as overruled,' directly nullifying its precedential value on that point.

cited_decision: Vermilye & Co. v. Adams Express Co.
quote: Mr. Justice Miller then added: 'We have not quoted the language from the opinion in that case with any view of affirming it. It may admit of grave doubt whether such bonds, redeemable but not payable at a certain day, except at the option of the government, do become overdue in the sense of being dishonored if not paid or redeemed on that day.'
rationale: The Acting Decision expresses 'grave doubt' about the reasoning in Vermilye, questioning its continuing validity on the relevant legal issue.

quote: The rules established in Murray v. Lardner, 2 Wall. 110, 118 — 'that the purchaser of coupon bonds, before due, without notice and in good faith, is unaffected by want of title in the seller, and that the burden of proof in respect-to notice and want of good faith is on the claimant of the bonds as against the purchaser' — were repeated and reaffirmed, but it was added: 'These rules have never been applied to matured obligations.'
rationale: The Acting Decision references and restates the rule from Murray v. Lardner without criticizing, limiting, or otherwise altering its authority.

quote: The case came before the court again in another aspect, and is reported as Texas v. Hardenberg, 10 Wall. 68, in which the grounds of the former decision were reconsidered and declared to be satisfactory.
rationale: The Acting Decision simply recounts the procedural history and outcome of Texas v. Hardenberg without criticizing or distinguishing it.

quote: The same questions, as to part of the same issue of bonds, came again before the court in Huntington v. Texas, 16 Wall. 402, in which the two prior decisions were relied on, on behalf of the State of Texas, as conclusive.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Huntington v. Texas as part of the historical development of the law, without criticizing or limiting its authority.

cited_decision: National Bank of Washington v. Texas
quote: The question 'whether the bonds were overdue in the sense which puts a purchaser of dishonored negotiable paper on the inquiry as to defences which may be set up against it,' was expressly waived, in the opinion of the court, because, it being 'quite clear that they were transferable by delivery after due, the same as before,' it followed that, 'to invalidate the title so acquired by a purchaser, it is necessary to make out some defect in that title,' which the court decided had not been done.
rationale: The Acting Decision notes that the key legal question was expressly waived in National Bank of Washington v. Texas and distinguishes the facts and reasoning from the present case.

quote: "To hold otherwise," said this court in Cromwell v. County of Sac, 96 U. S. 51, 58, "would throw discredit upon a large class of securities issued by municipal and private corporations, having years to run, with interest payable annually or semi-annually."
rationale: The Acting Decision quotes Cromwell v. County of Sac to support a general principle, without criticizing or limiting its authority.

quote: And the doctrine was reaffirmed in Railway Co. v. Sprague, 103 U. S. 756.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Sprague as reaffirming a doctrine, without criticizing, limiting, or otherwise altering its authority.

cited_decision: Lake Shore & Michigan Southern Railway Co. v. Smith (1899)
quote: True it is that it may not be possible to reconcile these views with all that is said in the opinion delivered for the majority of the court in the case of Lake Shore & Michigan Southern Ry. Co. v. Smith, supra. The views therein expressed which are inconsistent with the right of the States to fix reasonable commutation fares when the carrier has itself established fares for such service, must be regarded as overruled by the decision in this case.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that the inconsistent views in the Smith case 'must be regarded as overruled,' making this an explicit overruling of at least part of the Cited Decision.

cited_decision: Penna. R.R. Co. v. Public Ser. Com. (1915)
quote: The injunction was refused, and on appeal the Court of Appeals of Maryland affirmed the decree... We find no error in the decree of the Court of Appeals of Maryland, and the same is Affirmed.
rationale: The Acting Decision is a direct review of this Cited Decision and affirms its outcome, as stated explicitly in the opinion.

cited_decision: Interstate Com. Commiss. v. B. & O. RAILROAD (1892)
quote: In Interstate Commerce Commission v. Baltimore & Ohio R. R. Co., 145 U. S. 263 , this court held that a 'party rate ticket' for the transportation of ten or more persons at a less rate than that charged a single individual did not make a discrimination against an individual charged more for the same service, or amount to an unjust or unreasonable discrimination within the meaning of the Act to Regulate Commerce. In the course of the opinion the right to issue tickets at reduced rates good for limited periods upon the principle of commutation was fully recognized.
rationale: The Acting Decision references this case to support a general principle and does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

cited_decision: Norfolk and Western Railway Company v. Conley, Attorney General of the State of West Virginia (1913)
quote: In Norfolk & Western Ry. Co. v. West Virginia, 236 U. S. 605, 608 , after making reference to Northern Pacific Ry. Co. v. North Dakota, 236 U. S. 585 , this court said: 'It was recognized [in the North Dakota Case] that the State has a broad field for the exercise .of its discretion in prescribing reasonable rates for common carriers within its jurisdiction...'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case for a general legal principle regarding state authority to set rates, without criticizing or limiting its holding.

cited_decision: Northern Pacific Railway Co. v. North Dakota Ex Rel. McCue (1915)
quote: In Norfolk & Western Ry. Co. v. West Virginia, 236 U. S. 605, 608 , after making reference to Northern Pacific Ry. Co. v. North Dakota, 236 U. S. 585 , this court said: 'It was recognized [in the North Dakota Case] that the State has a broad field for the exercise .of its discretion in prescribing reasonable rates for common carriers within its jurisdiction...'
rationale: The Acting Decision references this case as part of a chain of authority for a general proposition, without criticism or limitation.

quote: In Louisville & Nashville R. R. Co. v. Kentucky ( 183 U. S. 503 ), after citing the Smith case and like cases, the court says (at p. 511): Nor, yet, are we ready to carry the doctrine of the cited cases beyond the limits therein established.’
rationale: The Acting Decision references this case as part of a discussion of the limits of prior doctrine, but does not criticize or limit its holding.

quote: In the Minnesota Rate Case (Simpson v. Shepard, 230 U. S. 352 ) the legality of an order of the Commission of that State was recognized which fixed a maximum freight rate and passenger rate, the latter at two cents a mile as the maximum fare for passengers twelve years of age or over, and one cent a mile for those under twelve years of age.
rationale: The Acting Decision references this case as an example of the legality of certain rate regulations, without criticism or limitation.

cited_decision: Interstate Consolidated Street Railway Co. v. Massachusetts (1907)

rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case as an example supporting the validity of special rates, without criticizing or limiting its holding.

quote: In Merrill v. Monticello, 138 U. S. 673, 687, 691 , it was held that the implied power of a municipal corporation to borrow money to enable it to execute the powers expressly conferred upon it by law, if existing at all, did not authorize it to create and issue negotiable securities to be sold in the market and to be taken by the purchaser freed from the equities that might be set up by the maker; and that to borrow money, and to give a bond or obligation therefor which might circulate in the market as a negotiable security, freed from any equities that might be set up by the maker of it, were essentially different transactions in their nature and legal effect.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses and applies the reasoning of Merrill v. Monticello, citing it with approval and using its principles, but does not criticize, limit, or overrule it. The case is analyzed and relied upon, so the treatment is 'Mentioned'.

quote: We, therefore, must regard the cases of Rogers v. Burlington and Mitchell v. Burlington, as overruled in the particular-referred to, by later cases in this court.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Rogers v. Burlington is overruled in the relevant aspect by later cases, making the treatment 'Overruled'.

quote: In Claiborne County v. Brooks, 111 U. S. 400 , it was held that the power to issue commercial paper was foreign to the objects of the creation of the political divisions of counties and townships, and was not to be conceded to such organizations unless by virtue of express legislation or by very strong implication from such legislation; and that the power conferred by statutes of Tennessee upon a county, to erect a court-house, jail and other necessary county buildings, did not authorize the issue of commercial paper as evidence of or security for a debt contracted for the construction of such a building.- The opinion in the case was delivered by Mr. Justice Bradley; and the case of Police Jury v. Britton, 15 Wall. 566 , was cited and approved, although the unsuccessful *185 party cited as authority the case of Rogers v. Burlington, 3 Wall. 654 .
rationale: The Acting Decision describes and applies the holding of Claiborne County v. Brooks, citing it with approval and using its reasoning, but does not criticize, limit, or overrule it. The treatment is 'Mentioned'.

quote: We, therefore, must regard the cases of Rogers v. Burlington and Mitchell v. Burlington, as overruled in the particular-referred to, by later cases in this court.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Mitchell v. Burlington is overruled in the relevant aspect by later cases, making the treatment 'Overruled'.

quote: In the opinion of the court, delivered by Mr. Justice Bradley, it is stated, that the police jury of the parish of Tensas, Louisiana, which issued the negotiable bonds in question in that case, had no express authority to issue them; that the power could not be implied from the ordinary powers of local administration and police which were conferred upon the boards and trustees of political districts; ... and that, although the authority for such-bodies to issue negotiable paper might be implied in some cases from other and express powers granted, those implications should not be extended beyond the fair inferences to be gathered from the circumstances of each case.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses and applies the reasoning of Police Jury v. Britton, citing it with approval and using its principles, but does not criticize, limit, or overrule it. The treatment is 'Mentioned'.

quote: It follows that the cases of Doyle v. Continental Insurance Co., 94 U. S. 535, and Security Mutual Life Insurance Co. v. Prewitt, 202 U. S. 246, must be considered as overruled and that the views of the minority judges in those cases have become the law of this court.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Doyle v. Continental Insurance is overruled, leaving no doubt as to its treatment.

cited_decision: Security Mutual Life Insurance v. Prewitt (1906)
quote: It follows that the cases of Doyle v. Continental Insurance Co., 94 U. S. 535, and Security Mutual Life Insurance Co. v. Prewitt, 202 U. S. 246, must be considered as overruled and that the views of the minority judges in those cases have become the law of this court.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Security Mutual Life Insurance v. Prewitt is overruled.

quote: The case was heard on bill and answer, and is to be considered on the averments of the bill which are not denied by the answer. Iowa v. Illinois, 147 U. S. 1, 7.
rationale: Iowa v. Illinois is cited only for a procedural point regarding how the case is to be considered, without further discussion or analysis.

quote: They began with Insurance Co. v. Morse, 20 Wall. 445, which was followed by Doyle v. Continental Insurance Co., 94 U. S. 535...
rationale: Home Ins. Co. v. Morse is listed as the starting point of a line of cases but is not discussed or analyzed further.

quote: They began with Insurance Co. v. Morse, 20 Wall. 445, which was followed by Doyle v. Continental Insurance Co., 94 U. S. 535; Barron v. Burnside, 121 U. S. 186...

quote: They began with Insurance Co. v. Morse, 20 Wall. 445, which was followed by Doyle v. Continental Insurance Co., 94 U. S. 535; Barron v. Burnside, 121 U. S. 186; Southern Pacific Co. v. Denton, 146 U. S. 202...

quote: They began with Insurance Co. v. Morse, 20 Wall. 445, which was followed by Doyle v. Continental Insurance Co., 94 U. S. 535; Barron v. Burnside, 121 U. S. 186; Southern Pacific Co. v. Denton, 146 U. S. 202; Martin v. Baltimore & Ohio R. R. Co., 151 U. S. 673, 684...
rationale: Martin's Administrator v. Baltimore & Ohio Railroad is listed among other cases, but not discussed further.

quote: They began with Insurance Co. v. Morse, 20 Wall. 445, which was followed by Doyle v. Continental Insurance Co., 94 U. S. 535; ... Barrow S. S. Co. v. Kane, 170 U. S. 100, 111...
rationale: Barrow Steamship Co. v. Kane is included in a string citation, with no further analysis.

cited_decision: Herndon v. Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railway Co. (1910)
quote: They began with Insurance Co. v. Morse, 20 Wall. 445, which was followed by Doyle v. Continental Insurance Co., 94 U. S. 535; ... Herndon v. Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Ry. Co., 218 U. S. 135...
rationale: Herndon v. Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railway Co. is mentioned as part of a list, without further discussion.

cited_decision: Harrison v. St. Louis & San Francisco Railroad (1914)
quote: They began with Insurance Co. v. Morse, 20 Wall. 445, which was followed by Doyle v. Continental Insurance Co., 94 U. S. 535; ... Harrison v. St. Louis & San Francisco R. R. Co., 232 U. S. 318...
rationale: Harrison v. St. Louis & San Francisco Railroad is included in a string citation, with no substantive discussion.

cited_decision: Donald v. Philadelphia & Reading Coal & Iron Co. (1916)
quote: They began with Insurance Co. v. Morse, 20 Wall. 445, which was followed by Doyle v. Continental Insurance Co., 94 U. S. 535; ... Wisconsin v. Philadelphia & Reading Coal & Iron Co., 241 U. S. 329.
rationale: Donald v. Philadelphia & Reading Coal & Iron Co. is referenced as part of a list of cases, with no further analysis or discussion.

cited_decision: Friedlander v. Texas & Pacific Railway Co. (1889)
quote: We think that the Fried-lander case should be overruled so far as it supports such an exception and that the judgment of the court of appeals should be reversed.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Friedlander should be overruled to the extent it supports the exception limiting employer liability for an agent's fraud, thus nullifying its precedential value on that point.

cited_decision: Roy & Roy v. Northern Pacific Railway Co. (1906)
quote: To this extent the case has been often cited and followed. Louisville & Nashville R. R. Co. v. Nat. Park Bk., 188 Ala. 109, 119 ; Roy & Roy v. Northern Pacific Ry Co., 42 Wash. 572, 576 ; contra, Bank of Batavia v. New York, etc. R. R. Co., 106 N. Y. 195.
rationale: The Acting Decision merely lists Roy & Roy as a case that followed Friedlander on a specific point, without discussing or analyzing its reasoning or outcome.

cited_decision: Planters' Rice-Mill Co. v. Merchants' National Bank (1887)
quote: The state courts, including those of Georgia where the cause of action arose, have very generally reached the opposite conclusion, holding that the liability of the principal for the false statement or other misconduct of the agent acting within the scope of his authority is unaffected by his secret purpose or motives. Planters’ Rice-Mill Co. v. Merchants’ Nat’l Bank, 78 Ga. 574 ...
rationale: The Acting Decision references this case as an example of the prevailing rule in state courts, but does not analyze or alter its holding.

quote: The state courts, including those of Georgia where the cause of action arose, have very generally reached the opposite conclusion, holding that the liability of the principal for the false statement or other misconduct of the agent acting within the scope of his authority is unaffected by his secret purpose or motives. ... Havens v. Bank of Tarboro, 132 N. C. 214 ...
rationale: The Acting Decision cites this case as an example of the general rule in state courts, without further discussion or criticism.

quote: This proposition, indeed, is said to be justified by the authority of certain language in the opinion of this court in the case of Poindexter v. Greenhow, 114 U.S. 270 . In that case the effect of a tender in payment of taxes upon the subsequent act of the collector in seizing the personal property of the tax-payer was considered and decided, but there is nothing in the opinion which countenances the idea that such a tender was a payment of the taxes, so as to extinguish all subsequent claim of the State therefor. Its effect was precisely defined in the following statement (page 299): His tender, as we have already seen, was equivalent to payment, so far as concerns the legality of all subsequent steps by the collector to enforce payment by distraint of his property. There is nothing in the opinion to indicate that the party making the tender was relieved from the operation of the rule of law, making it necessary to keep the tender good, or that a subsequent action at law for the recovery of the taxes would be unlawful, reserving, of course, in such a case, the admitted right of the defendant to plead the fact of his tender and bring it into court, in pursuance of the usual practice in such cases, as a defence.
rationale: The Acting Decision explains that Poindexter v. Greenhow addressed a different factual scenario—seizure of property after a tender—whereas the present case concerns the right to bring suit after a tender. The court clarifies the scope of Poindexter and limits its application, thus distinguishing it.

quote: In pursuance of the principles adjudged in the case of Osborn v. Bank of the United States, supra, it has been repeatedly and uniformly held by this court that an injunction will lie to restrain the collection of taxes sought to be collected by seizures of property imposed in the name of the State, but contrary to the Constitution of the United States, the defendants being officers of the State threatening the distraint complained of. The grounds of this jurisdiction were stated in Allen v. Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Co., 114 U.S. 311. The vital principle in all such cases is that the defendants, though professing to act as officers of the State, are threatening a violation of the personal or property rights of the complainant, for which they are personally and individually liable... The present case stands upon a footing altogether different.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Allen as an example of a case where officers were personally liable for violating property rights, but then states that the present case is 'altogether different,' thereby distinguishing Allen from the facts and legal issues at hand.

quote: And the point as involved in that case was stated by Mr. Justice Swayne, delivering the opinion of the court in Davis v. Gray, 16 Wall. 203, 220, as follows: In deciding who are parties to the suit the *488 court will not look beyond the record. Making a state officer a party does not make the State a party, although her law may have prompted his action and the State may stand behind him as the real party in interest... But what was said by Chief Justice Marshall in Osborn v. Bank of the United States, supra, must be taken in connection with its immediate context...
rationale: The Acting Decision references Davis v. Gray as part of a line of cases about party status, but then clarifies that the present case is different in substance and outcome, thus distinguishing Davis v. Gray.

cited_decision: Commonwealth of Ky. v. DENNISON, GOVERNOR, &C. (1861)
quote: This view was reiterated by this court in Kentucky v. Dennison, 24 How. 66, 98, where it was said to be settled, that where the State is a party, plaintiff or defendant, the Governor represents the State, and the suit may be, in form, a suit by him as Governor in behalf of the State, where the State is plaintiff, and he must be summoned or notified as the officer representing the State, where the State is defendant.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Dennison only to restate a general principle about party representation, without engaging in analysis or criticism, thus it is merely mentioned.

quote: The converse of that case is to be found in Hagood v. Southern, 117 U.S. 52. There, the State of South Carolina, which was the party in interest, was not nominally a defendant... The decrees of the Circuit Court granting the relief were reversed, and the cause remanded, with *491 instructions to dismiss the bills, on the ground that the suits, though nominally against the officers of the State, were really against the State itself.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Hagood v. Southern as an example supporting its jurisdictional analysis, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority; it is simply mentioned as precedent.

quote: This principle is illustrated and enforced by the case of United States v. Lee, 106 U. S. 196. In that case the plaintiffs had been wrongfully dispossessed of their real estate by defendants, claiming to act under the authority of the United States... This feature will be found, on an examination, to characterize every case where persons have been made defendants for acts done or threatened by them as officers of the government... The present case stands upon a footing altogether different.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses United States v. Lee as an illustration of a different principle—personal liability for wrongful acts—then expressly states that the present case is 'altogether different,' thereby distinguishing it.

cited_decision: Osborn v. Bank of United States (1824)
quote: It must be regarded as a settled doctrine of this court, established by its recent decisions, that the question whether a suit is within the prohibition of the 11th Amendment is not always determined by reference to the nominal parties on the record. Poindexter v. Greenhow, 114 U.S. 270, 287. This, it is true, is not in harmony with what was said by Chief Justice Marshall in Osborn v. Bank of the United States, 9 Wheat. 738, 857.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly notes that its current doctrine is 'not in harmony' with the rule stated in Osborn, thereby criticizing the reasoning or approach of Osborn.

quote: But this court, when the question came before it in Bauer v. O’Donnell, 229 U. S. 1, rejecting plausible argument and. adhering to the language of the statute from which all patent right is derived, refused to give such a construction to the act of Congress, and decided that the owner of a patent is not authorized by either the letter or the purpose of the law to fix, by notice, the price at which a patented article must be sold after the first sale of it, declaring that the right-to- vend is exhausted by a single, unconditional sale, the article sold being thereby carried outside the monopoly of. the patent law and rendered free of every restriction which the vendor may attempt to put upon it.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Bauer v. O'Donnell as precedent supporting its reasoning but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority; it is cited as an example of the exhaustion doctrine.

cited_decision: Henry v. A. B. Dick Co. (1912)
quote: It is obvious that the conclusions arrived at in this opinion are such that the decision in Henry v. Dick Co., 224 U. S. 1, must be regarded as overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Henry v. Dick Co. is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value.

cited_decision: Continental Paper Bag Co. v. Eastern Paper Bag Co. (1908)
quote: In short, for whatever motive, he may keep his device wholly out of use. Continental Paper Bag Co. v. Eastern Paper Bag Co., 210 U. S. 405, 422. So much being undisputed, I cannot understand why he may not keep it out of use unless the licensee, or, for the matter of that, the buyer, will use some unpatented thing in connection with it.
rationale: The Cited Decision is referenced in the dissent to support a general proposition about patent rights, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, distinguish, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: Revised Statutes, § 4900, requiring that patented articles shall be marked with the word Patented” affects only the damages recoverable for infringement, Dunlap v. Schofield, 152 U. S. 244 , and Rev. Stats., § 4901, protects by its penalties the inventor, but neither one contemplates the use of such a License Notice” as we have here and whatevér validity it has must be derived from the general and not from the patent law.
rationale: Dunlap v. Schofield is cited for a narrow, factual point about statutory damages and marking requirements, without further discussion or criticism.

cited_decision: Keeler v. Standard Folding Bed Co. (1895)
quote: The extent to which the use of the patented machine may validly be restricted to specific supplies or otherwise by special contract between the owner of a patent and the purchaser or licensee is a question outside the patent law and with it we are not here concerned. Keeler v. Standard Folding Bed Co., 157 U. S. 659.
rationale: Keeler is cited as authority for the proposition that certain restrictions are outside the scope of patent law, but the Acting Decision does not criticize or limit its holding.

cited_decision: Keystone Bridge Co. v. Phoenix Iron Co. (1877)
quote: It is to the claims of every patent, therefore, that we must turn when we are seeking to determine what the invention is, the exclusive use of which is given to the inventor by the grant provided for by the statute, — “He can claim nothing beyond them.” Keystone Bridge Co. v. Phœnix Iron Co., 95 U. S. 274 ; Railroad Co. v. Mellon, 104 U. S. 112, 118 ; Yale Lock Mfg. Co. v. Greenleaf, 117 U. S. 554, 559 ; McClain v. Ortmayer, 141 U. S. 419, 424.

In disapproving that doctrine we do not hold *80 unconstitutional § 34 of the Federal Judiciary Act of 1789 or any other Act of Congress. ... As. we hold this was error, the judgment is reversed and the case remanded to it for further proceedings in conformity with our opini o n.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly disapproves and overrules the doctrine of Swift v. Tyson, declaring it unconstitutional and ending its precedential value. The language is clear and direct in overruling the cited decision.

rationale: The Acting Decision references Stevenson as an example of the adaptability of common law, but does not analyze, criticize, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

quote: Patton v. United States, 281 U.S. 276, 306 .

quote: Collector v. Day, supra, and New York ex rel. Rogers v. Graves, supra, are overruled so far as they recognize an implied constitutional immunity from income taxation of the salaries of officers or employees of the national or a state government or their instrumentalities.

S. 405 , 412—415. ... These were the-determining considerations that led the great Chief Justice to strike down the Maryland statute as an unambiguous measure of discrimination against the use by the United States of the Bank of the United States as one of its instruments of government.

Mountain Producers Corp., 303 U. S. 376 .
rationale: The Acting Decision references Metcalf & Eddy v. Mitchell as part of the development of the doctrine, but does not criticize, limit, or overrule it.

cited_decision: Dobbins v. Commissioners of Erie County
quote: Neither Dobbins v. Commissioners, 16 Pet. 435 , and its offspring, nor Collector v. Day, supra, and its, can stand appeal to the Constitution and its historic purposes. Since both are the starting points of an interdependent doctrine, both should be, as I assume them to be, overruled this day.
rationale: Both the lead and concurring opinions state that Dobbins v. Commissioners of Erie County is overruled as a starting point of the now-rejected doctrine of implied immunity.

quote: From the decision just announced, it is clear that the Court has overruled Dobbins v. Commissioners of Erie County (1842) 16 Pet. 435 ; Collector v. Day (1871) 11 Wall. 113 ; New York ex rel. Rogers v. Graves, supra, and Brush v. Commissioner (1937) 300 U. S. 352 .
rationale: The dissenting opinion, summarizing the majority's holding, states that Brush v. Commissioner is overruled by the Acting Decision.

cited_decision: Pollock v. Farmers' Loan & Trust Co. (1895)
quote: See also the separate opinion of Mr. Justice Field in Pollock v. Farmers’ Loan & Trust Co., 157 U. S. 429, 586 , 604 et seq.
rationale: Pollock is referenced for the separate opinion of Justice Field and as historical context, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise materially engage with its holding.

quote: The cases, pro and con, are collected in the recent dissenting opinion by Chief Judge Bond of the Court of Appeals of Maryland in Gordy v. Dennis, 5 A. 2d 69, 82.
rationale: Gordy v. Dennis is cited as a collection of cases and for comparative purposes, but the Acting Decision neither adopts nor rejects its reasoning, nor does it distinguish or criticize it.

quote: But to the extent *283 that what the Court now says is inconsistent with what was said in Miles v. Graham, 268 U. S. 501, the latter cannot survive.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Miles v. Graham 'cannot survive' to the extent it is inconsistent with the current holding, which is the language of overruling.

quote: He quoted (p,-505) with approval from Indian Oil Co. v. Oklahoma, 240 U. S. 522, the statement of the opinion (p. 530) that 'A tax upon the leases is a tax upon’the power to make them, and could be used to destroy - the power, to make them.' 15 *295 Miles v. Graham (1925), 268 U. S. 501, held invalid § 213 (a), Revenue Act of 1918, (condemned in Evans v. Gore) when applied to compensation of Judge Graham, *296 appointed after its enactment. Mr. Justice Holmes joined in the decision. Mr. Justice Brandéis merely noted dissent. In the course of the opinion, we said: ... The power to tax carries with it the power to embarrass and destroy’; may be applied to every object within its range fin such measure as Congress may determine’; enables that body to select one calling and omit another, to tax one class of property and to forebear to tax another’; and may be applied in different ways to different objects so long as there is ‘geographical uniformity’ in the duties, imposts and excises imposed. [Citing.] Is it not therefore morally certain that the discern *294 ing statesmen who framed the Constitution and were so sedulously bent on* securing the independence of the judiciary intended to protect the compensation of the judges from assault and diminution in the name or form of a tax? Could not the purpose of the prohibition be wholly thwarted if this avenue of attack were left open? Certainly there is nothing in the words of the prohibition indicating that it is directed against one legislative power and not another; and in our opinion due regard for its spirit and principle requires that it be taken as directed against them all.” . Mr. Justice Holmes wrote a dissenting opinion, in which Mr. Justice Brandéis joined. With that expression his opposition to the decision ended. Two years later, in Gillespie v. Oklahoma, 257 U. S. 501, writing for the Court, invalidating a state tax upon- net income of a lessee from sales of his share of oil and gas received under leases of restricted Indian land, he said (p. 505): “In cases where the principal is absolutely immune from interference an inquiry is allowed into the sources from which net income is derived and if a part of it comes from-,such a source the tax is pro tanto void; Pollock v. Farmers’ Loan & Trust Co., 157 U. S. 429; 158 U. S. 601; a.rule lately illustrated by Evans v. Gore . . .” And in that case he relied on the truth, as put by Chief Justice Marshall in M’Culloch v. Maryland, 4 Wheat. 316, 431, that “the power to tax involves the power to destroy.”
rationale: M'culloch v. Maryland is cited for the famous dictum about the power to tax, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or distinguish it; it is used as background authority.

quote: By means of § 22 of the Revenue Act of 1932, Congress sought to avoid, at least in part, the consequences of Evans v. Gore, 253 U. S. 245. That case, decided on June 1, 1920, ruled for the first time that a provision requiring the compensation received by the judges of the United States to be included in the “gross income” from which the net income is to be computed, although merely part of a taxing measure of general, non-discriminatory application to all earners of incomes, is contrary to Article III, § 1, of the Constitution ... However, the meaning which Evans v. Gore imputed to the history which explains Article III, § 1, was contrary to the way in which it was read by other English-speaking courts. ... The decision met wide and steadily growing disfavor from legal scholarship and professional opinion. ... Evans v. Gore itself was rejected by most of the courts before whom the matter came after that decision. ... Evidently the, Court intends to destroy the decision in Evans v. Gore. Without suggesting that there is any distinction between that case and Miles v. Graham, it declares that the latter 'cannot survive.' But the decision of today fails to deal with, much less to detract from the reasoning of those cases. ... Admittedly the Court now repudiates its earlier decisions upon the point here in issue.
rationale: The Acting Decision makes clear that Evans v. Gore is no longer good law, describing the Court's intent to 'destroy the decision' and 'repudiates its earlier decisions,' which is the language of overruling.

cited_decision: Helvering v. St. Louis Union Trust Co.
quote: We therefore reject as untenable the diversities taken in the St. Louis Trust cases in applying the Klein doctrine — untenable because they drastically eat into the principle which those cases professed to accept and to which we adhere.
rationale: The lead opinion expressly rejects and overturns the distinctions and reasoning of the St. Louis Trust cases, making clear that they are no longer good law.

quote: The teaching of the Klein case is exactly the opposite. ... Freed from the distinctions, introduced by the St. Louis Trust cases, the Klein case furnishes such a harmonizing principle.
rationale: The Acting Decision repeatedly references Klein v. United States as the controlling and correct principle, but does not alter, criticize, or limit it; it is cited as authoritative.

cited_decision: Cyrus H. McCormick v. David Burnet
quote: The Commissioner made the same contention in this court, but it was overruled upon the authority of May v. Heiner. Then came the two St. Louis Union Trust Company cases, decided upon the authority of May v. Heiner and McCormick v. Burnet.
rationale: While the dissent treats McCormick as controlling, the lead opinion groups it with the St. Louis Trust cases and implies its reasoning is inconsistent with the Klein doctrine, thus questioning its continuing validity.

quote: By the Joint Resolution of March 3, 1931, c. 454, 46 Stat. 1516, Congress displaced the construction which this Court put upon § 302 (c) in those cases wherein it was held that the reservation by a decedent of a life estate in property conveyed inter vivos, did not constitute a sufficient postponement of the remainder to bring it into the grantor’s gross estate. May v. Heiner, 281 U. S. 238 ...
rationale: The lead opinion notes that May v. Heiner was legislatively overruled in relevant part and treats its reasoning as superseded, thus questioning its precedential value.

cited_decision: Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Schwarz
quote: Some indication of the influence of Klein v. United States upon the lower courts may be found in Sargent v. White, 50 F. 2d 410 and Union Trust Co. v. United States, 54 F. 2d 152, cert. denied, 286 U. S. 547. Cf. Commissioner v. Schwarz, 74 F. 2d 712.
rationale: Schwarz is only cited as an example of lower court application and is not discussed or analyzed further.

cited_decision: Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Hallock
quote: In each case the Commissioner of Internal Revenue included the trust property in the decedent’s gross estate. In Nos. 110, 111 and 112 his determination was reversed by the Board of Tax Appeals, 34 B. T. A. 575, and the Board was affirmed by the Circuit Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, 102 F. 2d 1.
rationale: This is a lower court decision in the same litigation, mentioned only as procedural history and not analyzed or criticized.

cited_decision: Becker v. St. Louis Union Trust Co.
quote: We therefore reject as untenable the diversities taken in the St. Louis Trust cases in applying the Klein doctrine — untenable because they drastically eat into the principle which those cases professed to accept and to which we adhere.

cited_decision: Procter & Gamble Co. v. United States (1912)
quote: In translating these- important objectives for effectuating the Congressional scheme to enlarge the independent powers of the Interstate Commerce Commission into a seemingly technical distinction between “negative” and “affirmative” orders, the opinion in Procter & Gambie v. United States gave authority to a doctrine which harmonizes neither with the considerations which induced it nor with the course of decisions which have purported to follow it. ... We conclude, therefore, that any distinction, as such, between “negative” and “affirmative” orders, as a touchstone of jurisdiction to review the Commission’s orders, serves no useful purpose, and insofar as earlier decisions have been controlled by this distinction, they can no longer be guiding.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly limits the precedential value of Procter & Gamble by rejecting the distinction between 'negative' and 'affirmative' orders as a basis for jurisdiction, stating that earlier decisions controlled by this distinction 'can no longer be guiding.'

cited_decision: Mayor of New York v. Miln
quote: In City of New York v. Miln, 11 Pet. 102, at 143 , it was said that it is 'as competent and as necessary for a State to provide precautionary measures against the moral pestilence of paupers, vagabonds, and possibly convicts, as it is to guard against the physical pestilence, which may arise from unsound and infectious articles imported, . . .' ... But assuming that the term is applicable to him and to persons similarly situated, we do not consider ourselves bound by the language referred to. City of New York v. Miln was decided in 1837. Whatever may have been the notion then prevailing, we do not think that it will now be seriously contended that because a person is without employment and without funds he constitutes a 'moral pestilence.' Poverty and immorality are not synonymous.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly declines to be bound by the language of Miln and limits its applicability to the present context, stating that the historical notion underlying Miln is no longer controlling. Thus, the treatment is 'Limited.'

quote: In Gillespie v. Oklahoma, 257 U. S. 501 , the question concerned income derived from leases of restricted Indian lands. The leases were deemed to be instrumentalities of the United States in carrying out its duties to the Indians, and the Court, speaking through Mr. Justice Holmes, concluded that the tax imposed by Oklahoma was 'a direct hamper upon the effort of the United States to make the best terms that it can for its wards.' ... These decisions are not controlling here. The nature and purpose of copyrights place them in a distinct category and we are unable to find any basis for the supposition that a nondiscriminatory tax on royalties hampers in the slightest degree the execution of the policy of the copyright statute.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Gillespie is not controlling because the facts and legal context are different, thus distinguishing it.

quote: 4 Scranton v. Wheeler, 179 U. S. 141, 162 ... 9 Scranton v. Wheeler, 179 U. S. 141, 143, 144 ... The dominant power of the federal Government, as has *597 been repeatedly held, extends to the entire bed of a stream, which includes the lands below ordinary high-water mark. The exercise of the power within these limits is not an invasion of any private property right in such lands for which the United States must make compensation.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Scranton v. Wheeler as authority for the general proposition regarding the federal government's power over navigable waters, but does not criticize, distinguish, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

cited_decision: United States v. Chandler-Dunbar Water Power Co. (1913)
quote: 7 United States v. Chandler-Dunbar Co., 229 U. S. 53, 62 ... 12 See the cases cited in Note 9, and United States v. Chandler-Dunbar Co., 229 U. S. 53, 70 ...
rationale: The Acting Decision references Chandler-Dunbar as supporting authority for the scope of federal power over navigable waters, without criticizing or limiting its holding.

quote: But we think this Court has never followed it as a binding decision that compensation is due for injury or destruction of a riparian owner’s property located in the bed of a navigable stream. And we think that, so far as it sanctions such a principle, it is in irreconcilable conflict with our later decisions* 11 and cannot be considered as expressing the law.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly declines to follow Lynah as binding precedent on the issue at hand, stating that it is in conflict with later decisions and cannot be considered as expressing the law, thereby limiting its scope and precedential value.

quote: What was said in the Cress case must be confined to the facts there disclosed. In that case, the Government’s improvement in a navigable stream resulted in the flooding of the plaintiff’s land in and adjacent to a non-navigable stream. The owners of the land along and under the bed of the stream were held entitled to compensation for the damage to their lands. The question here presented was not discussed in the opinion.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Cress by limiting its application to its specific facts and noting that the question at issue in the present case was not discussed in Cress.

quote: Commerce, the regulation of which between the states is committed by the Constitution to Congress, includes navigation. 'The power to regulate commerce compre *596 hends the control for that purpose, and to the extent necessary, of all the navigable waters of the United States which are accessible from a State other than those in which they lie. For this purpose they are the public property of the nation, and subject to all the requisite legislation by Congress.' 3
rationale: Gilman v. Philadelphia is cited as foundational authority for the federal power over navigable waters, but the Acting Decision does not alter or question its holding.

quote: 6 Gibson v. United States, 166 U. S. 269, 271, 272.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Gibson as supporting authority for the subordination of riparian rights to federal power, without further discussion or alteration.

rationale: The Acting Decision lists Appalachian Electric Power Co. among several cases supporting the scope of federal power, but does not discuss or alter its holding.

cited_decision: Lewis Blue Point Oyster Cultivation Co. v. Briggs (1913)
quote: 12 See the cases cited in Note 9, and United States v. Chandler-Dunbar Co., 229 U. S. 53, 70 ; Lewis Blue Point Oyster Co. v. Briggs, 229 U. S. 82, 86-88.
rationale: Lewis Blue Point Oyster Co. v. Briggs is cited as additional authority for the general proposition, without further discussion or modification.

quote: The true rationale of these decisions is that the Removal Acts qualify pro tanto the Act of 1793. Subsequent decisions have clarified the loose ground advanced in French v. Hay, 22 Wall. 250, 253. See Kline v. Burke Construction Co., 260 U. S. 226; Taylor and Willis, The Power of Federal Courts to Enjoin Proceedings in State Courts, 42 Yale L. J. 1169, 1174-75; compare Bryant v. Atlantic Coast Line R. Co., 92 F. 2d 569, 571.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Dietzsch v. Huidekoper as a removal case, noting that its rationale is based on the Removal Acts, which are a statutory exception to the general rule. Thus, the case is distinguished from the present context, which does not involve removal.

quote: See Kline v. Burke Construction Co., 260 U. S. 226, 235: 'The rank and authority of the [federal and state] courts are equal but both courts cannot possess or control the same thing at the same time, and any attempt to do so would result in unseemly conflict. The rule, therefore, that the court first acquiring jurisdiction shall proceed without interference from a court of the other jurisdiction is a rule of right and of law based upon necessity, and where the necessity, actual or potential, does not exist, the rule does not apply. Since that necessity does exist in actions in rem and does not exist in actions in -personam, involving a question of personal liability only, the rule applies in the former but does not apply in the latter.'
rationale: Kline v. Burke Construction Co. is quoted for its general principle about jurisdiction and is used to clarify the distinction between in rem and in personam actions. The Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its authority, but simply references and explains it.

cited_decision: Gunter v. Atlantic Coast Line Railroad
quote: It has been suggested that the provision reflected the then strong feeling against the unwarranted intrusion of federal courts upon state sovereignty. Chisholm v. Georgia, 2 Dall. 419, was decided on February 18, 1793, less than two weeks before the provision was enacted into law. The significance of this proximity is doubtful. Compare Warren, Federal and State Court Interference, 43 Harv. L. Rev. 345, 347-48, with Gunter v. Atlantic Coast Line, 200 U. S. 273, 291-92. ... Another group of cases is said to constitute an exception to § 265, namely, where federal courts have enjoined litigants from enforcing judgments fraudulently obtained in the state courts. ... The foundation of these cases is thus very doubtful. However, we need not undertake to reexamine them here since, in any event, they do not govern the cases at bar.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Gunter v. Atlantic Coast Line Railroad as part of a group of cases whose foundation is described as 'very doubtful' and explicitly states that they do not govern the present case, thus distinguishing them.

quote: Subsequent decisions have clarified the loose ground advanced in French v. Hay, 22 Wall. 250, 253. See Kline v. Burke Construction Co., 260 U. S. 226; Taylor and Willis, The Power of Federal Courts to Enjoin Proceedings in State Courts, 42 Yale L. J. 1169, 1174-75; compare Bryant v. Atlantic Coast Line R. Co., 92 F. 2d 569, 571.
rationale: The Acting Decision refers to 'the loose ground advanced in French v. Hay' and notes that later decisions have clarified its rationale, indicating that it is not controlling and is distinguished from the present context.

quote: We come, then, to the so-called 'relitigation' cases, the first of which is Dial v. Reynolds, 96 U. S. 340. ... The lower court sustained Reynolds’ demurrer, and this Court affirmed. It held that the 'gravamen' of the bills was an injunction to prevent Reynolds from proceeding in the state court. 'Such an injunction, except under the Bankrupt Act, no court of the United States can grant. With this exception, it is expressly forbidden by law.' 96 U. S. at 341.
rationale: The Acting Decision summarizes the holding of Dial v. Reynolds as part of its historical review, but does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its authority. It is simply mentioned and explained.

cited_decision: Supreme Tribe of Ben-Hur v. Cauble
quote: Supreme Tribe of Ben-Hur v. Cauble, 255 U. S. 356, held that a federal district court, having rendered a decree in a class suit brought in behalf of all the members of a certain class of beneficiaries in a fraternal association, may enjoin members of the class, found to be bound by the decree, from prosecuting suits in the state courts which would relitigate questions settled by such decree. The opinion of Mr. Justice Day contains no reference to either the Act of March 2, 1793, or to Dial v. Reynolds. ... Having determined this question in the affirmative, the Court disposed of the remaining — § 265 — question in one sentence, citing only one case in support of its conclusion, Looney v. Eastern Texas R. Co., supra, which, as we have seen, was not a relitigation case.
rationale: The Acting Decision points out that Supreme Tribe of Ben-Hur v. Cauble did not adequately address the statutory prohibition and relied on a case that was not on point, thus criticizing its reasoning and precedential value.

quote: Root v. Woolworth, 150 U. S. 401, is erroneously regarded as illustrating a 'relitigation' exception to § 265. The case holds merely that courts of equity have jurisdiction to 'effectuate their own decrees by injunctions or writs of assistance in order to avoid the relitigation of questions once settled between the same parties.' 150 U. S. at 411-12. The Court did not uphold a federal injunction against a state suit to relitigate a claim already settled by a previous federal decree — no such state suit had been brought. Consequently, there was no occasion to consider the applicability of § 265.
rationale: The Acting Decision clarifies that Root v. Woolworth did not actually involve an injunction against state court proceedings and thus does not support a 'relitigation' exception, distinguishing it from the present context.

quote: The 'first come, first served' rationale of cases like Prout v. Starr, 188 U. S. 537, was discarded in Kline v. Burke Construction Co., 260 U. S. 226, 235. Cf. Haines v. Carpenter, 91 U. S. 254, 257.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the rationale of Prout v. Starr has been discarded by later authority, distinguishing it from the current case.

quote: Currin v. Wallace, supra, 11 , and see to the like effect United States v. Rock Royal Co-op., supra, 568, note 37.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Currin v. Wallace as an example supporting its reasoning but does not criticize, distinguish, limit, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

quote: Congress, following its own conception of public policy concerning the restrictions which may appropriately be imposed on interstate commerce, is free to exclude from the commerce articles whose use in the states for which they are destined it may conceive to be injurious to the public health, morals or welfare, even though the state has not sought to regulate their use. Reid v. Colorado, supra; Lottery Case, supra; Hipolite Egg Co. v. United States, supra; Hoke v. United States, supra.
rationale: Reid v. Colorado is cited as precedent for the proposition that Congress may exclude certain articles from interstate commerce, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: Brooks v. United States, supra; Kentucky Whip & Collar Co. v. Illinois Central R. Co., supra; Electric Bond & Share Co. v. Securities & Exchange Comm’n, 303 U. S. 419 ; Mulford v. Smith, 307 U. S. 38 .
rationale: Mulford v. Smith is cited as supporting precedent for the abandonment of a distinction in Commerce Clause jurisprudence, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

cited_decision: Clark Distilling Co. v. Western Maryland Railway Co. (1917)
quote: It extends not only to those regulations which aid, foster and protect the commerce, but embraces those which prohibit it. Reid v. Colorado, 187 U. S. 137 ; Lottery Case, 188 U. S. 321 ; United States v. Delaware & Hudson Co., 213 U. S. 366 ; Hoke v. United States, 227 U. S. 308 ; Clark Distilling Co. v. Western Maryland Ry. Co., 242 U. S. 311 ; United States v. Hill, 248 U. S. 420 ; McCormick & Co. v. Brown, 286 U. S. 131 .

Appalachian Electric Power Co., 311 U. S. 377 .

quote: See McCul *119 loch v. Maryland, 4 Wheat. 316, 421 . Cf. United States v. Ferger, 250 U. S. 199 .

quote: Such legislation has often been sustained with respect to powers, other than the commerce power granted to the national government, when the means chosen, although not themselves within the granted power, were nevertheless deemed appropriate aids to the accomplishment of some purpose within an admitted power of the national government. See Jacob Ruppert, Inc. v. Caffey, 251 U. S. 264 ; Everard’s Breweries v. Day, 265 U. S. 545, 560 ; Westfall v. United States, 274 U. S. 256, 259 .

S. 342 ; Railroad Commission of Wisconsin v. Chicago, B. & Q. R. Co., 257 U. S. 563 ; United States v. Louisiana, 290 U. S. 70, 74 ; Florida v. United States, 292 U. S. 1 .

quote: Nor is it any longer open to question that it is within the legislative power to fix maximum hours. Holden v. Hardy, 169 U. S. 366 ; Muller v. Oregon, 208 U. S. 412 ; Bunting v. Oregon, 243 U. S. 426 ; Baltimore & Ohio R. Co. v. Interstate Commerce Comm’n, supra. Similarly the statute is not objectionable because applied alike to both men and women. Cf. Bunting v. Oregon, 243 U. S. 426 .
rationale: Bunting v. Oregon is cited as precedent for the legislative power to fix maximum hours and for gender-neutral application, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: The conclusion is inescapable that Hammer v. Dagenhart , was a departure from the principles which have prevailed in the interpretation of the Commerce Clause both *117 before and since the decision and that such vitality, as a precedent, as it then had has long since been exhausted. quote: But the contention that the due process clause forecloses taxation of an interest in intangibles by the state of its owner when they are held in trust in another state was rejected in Bullen v. Wisconsin, 240 U. S. 625.

quote: Curry v. McCanless, 307 U. S. 357 ; cf. Graves v. Elliott, 307 U. S. 383 .
