cited_decision: Bayside Fish Flour Co. v. Gentry (1936)
quote: If the provisions in the state laws against employer discrimination are valid, it follows that the contract prohibition also is valid. Bayside Fish Flour Co. v. Gentry, 297 U. S. 422, 427.
rationale: Bayside Fish Flour Co. v. Gentry is cited as precedent for the proposition that contract prohibitions are valid if the underlying law is valid, but the Acting Decision does not analyze or alter its holding.

quote: And see Sage v. Hampe, 235 U. S. 99, 104-105.
rationale: Sage v. Hampe is cited as additional authority for the contract clause argument, but the Acting Decision does not analyze or alter its holding.

quote: In 1907 this Court in Adair v. United States, 208 U. S. 161, considered the federal law which prohibited discrimination against union workers. ... This Court there held, over the dissents of Justices McKenna and Holmes, that the railroad, because of the due process clause of the Fifth Amendment, had a constitutional right to discriminate against union members and could therefore do so through use of yellow dog contracts. The chief reliance for this holding was Lochner v. New York, 198 U. S. 45, which had invalidated a New York law prescribing maximum hours for work in bakeries. ... This Court beginning at least as early as 1934, when the Nebbia case was decided, has steadily rejected the due process philosophy enunciated in the Adair-Coppage line of cases. In doing so it has consciously returned closer and closer to the earlier constitutional principle that states have power to legislate against what are found to be injurious practices in their internal commercial and business affairs, so long as their laws do not run afoul of some specific federal constitutional prohibition, or of some valid federal law.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly rejects the due process philosophy of Adair and its line of cases, indicating disagreement with its reasoning.

quote: The chief reliance for this holding was Lochner v. New York, 198 U. S. 45, which had invalidated a New York law prescribing maximum hours for work in bakeries. ... This Court beginning at least as early as 1934, when the Nebbia case was decided, has steadily rejected the due process philosophy enunciated in the Adair-Coppage line of cases.
rationale: The Acting Decision criticizes the reasoning of Lochner and notes that its due process philosophy has been rejected.

quote: This Court had found support for its Lochner holding in what had been said in Allgeyer v. Louisiana, 165 U. S. 578, a case on which appellants here strongly rely.
rationale: Allgeyer is mentioned as a case relied upon by appellants and as background to the Lochner line, but the Acting Decision does not analyze or alter its holding.

quote: In 1914 this Court reaffirmed the principles of the Adair case in Coppage v. Kansas, 236 U. S. 1, again over strong dissents, and held that a Kansas statute outlawing yellow dog contracts denied employers and employees a liberty to fix terms of employment. For this reason the law was held invalid under the due process clause. ... This Court beginning at least as early as 1934, when the Nebbia case was decided, has steadily rejected the due process philosophy enunciated in the Adair-Coppage line of cases.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly rejects the due process philosophy of Coppage and its line of cases, indicating disagreement with its reasoning.

quote: See cases cited in Olsen v. Nebraska, 313 U. S. 236, 244-246, and Osborn v. Ozlin, 310 U. S. 53, 66-67.
rationale: Osborn v. Ozlin is cited as an example in a string citation, but the Acting Decision does not analyze or alter its holding.

quote: And the same constitutional philosophy was faithfully adhered to in Adams v. Tanner, 244 U. S. 590, a case strongly pressed upon us by appellants. In Adams v. Tanner, this Court with four justices dissenting struck down a state law absolutely prohibiting maintenance of private employment agencies. The majority found that such businesses were highly beneficial to the public and upon this conclusion held that the state was without power to proscribe them. Our holding and opinion in Olsen v. Nebraska, supra, clearly, undermined Adams v. Tanner.
rationale: The Acting Decision criticizes Adams v. Tanner and states that it has been undermined by later precedent.

cited_decision: Chas. Wolff Packing Co. v. Court of Industrial Relations (1923)
quote: Appellants also rely heavily on certain language used in this Court’s opinion in Wolff Packing Co. v. Court of Industrial Relations, 262 U. S. 522. In that case the Court invalidated a state law which in part provided a method for a state agency to fix wages and hours. ... In invalidating this part of the state act, this Court construed the due process clause as forbidding legislation to fix hours and wages, or to fix prices of products. The Court also relied on a distinction between businesses according to whether they were or were not 'clothed with a public interest.' This latter distinction was rejected in Nebbia v. New York, 291 U. S. 502.
rationale: The Acting Decision criticizes the reasoning of Wolff Packing Co. and notes that its distinctions have been rejected.

cited_decision: Chas. Wolff Packing Co. v. Court of Industrial Relations of Kansas (1925)
quote: See Wolff Co. v. Industrial Court, 267 U. S. 552, 565.
rationale: This case is cited as a follow-up to the earlier Wolff Packing Co. decision, but the Acting Decision does not analyze or alter its holding.

quote: This latter distinction was rejected in Nebbia v. New York, 291 U. S. 502. That the due process clause does not ban legislative power to fix prices, wages and hours as was assumed in the Wolff case, was settled as to price fixing in the Nebbia and Olsen cases.
rationale: Nebbia is cited as precedent for the proposition that the due process clause does not bar legislative regulation of prices, wages, and hours, but the Acting Decision does not analyze or alter its holding.

quote: That wages and hours can be fixed by law is no longer doubted since West Coast Hotel Co. v. Parrish, 300 U. S. 379; United States v. Darby, 312 U. S. 100, 125; Phelps Dodge Corp. v. Labor Board, 313 U. S. 177, 187.
rationale: United States v. Darby is cited as precedent for the proposition that wages and hours can be fixed by law, but the Acting Decision does not analyze or alter its holding.

cited_decision: Phelps Dodge Corp. v. National Labor Relations Board (1941)
quote: That wages and hours can be fixed by law is no longer doubted since West Coast Hotel Co. v. Parrish, 300 U. S. 379; United States v. Darby, 312 U. S. 100, 125; Phelps Dodge Corp. v. Labor Board, 313 U. S. 177, 187.
rationale: Phelps Dodge Corp. is cited as precedent for the proposition that wages and hours can be fixed by law, but the Acting Decision does not analyze or alter its holding.

cited_decision: West Virginia State Board of Education v. Barnette (1943)
quote: This contention rests on the premise that the Fourteenth Amendment makes the prohibitions and guarantees of the First Amendment applicable to state action. See West Virginia v. Barnette, 319 U. S. 624, 639.
rationale: Barnette is cited for the proposition that the First Amendment applies to the states via the Fourteenth Amendment, but the Acting Decision does not analyze or alter its holding.

quote: We hold that all evidence obtained by searches and seizures in violation of the Constitution is, by that same authority, inadmissible in a state court... In overruling the Wolf case the Court, in my opinion, has forgotten the sense of judicial restraint which, with due regard for stare decisis, is one element that should enter into deciding whether a past decision of this Court should be overruled.
rationale: The lead opinion and the dissent both explicitly state that Wolf v. Colorado is being overruled by the Court's decision in Mapp v. Ohio.

quote: Likewise, time has set its face against what Wolf called the 'weighty testimony' of People v. Defore, 242 N. Y. 13, 150 N. E. 585 (1926). There Justice (then Judge) Cardozo, rejecting adoption of the Weeks exclusionary rule in New York, had said that '[t]he Federal rule as it stands is either too strict or too lax.' 242 N. Y., at 22, 150 N. E., at 588. However, the force of that reasoning has been largely vitiated by later decisions of this Court.
rationale: The Court discusses People v. Defore as a precedent that has lost its persuasive force due to subsequent developments, expressing doubt about its continuing validity.

quote: They express 'supplementing phases of the same constitutional purpose — to maintain inviolate large areas of personal privacy.' Feldman v. United States, 322 U. S. 487, 489-490 (1944). The philosophy of each Amendment and of each freedom is complementary to, although not dependent upon, that of the other in its sphere of influence — the very least that together they assure in either sphere is that no man is to be convicted on unconstitutional evidence. Cf. Rochin v. California, 342 U. S. 165, 173 (1952).
rationale: Rochin v. California is cited as a comparative reference to support the Court's reasoning, but is not discussed or altered in its precedential value.

quote: These include the recent discarding of the 'silver platter' doctrine which allowed federal judicial use of evidence seized in violation of the Constitution by state agents, Elkins v. United States, supra; ... Only last year this Court expressly considered that contention and found that 'pragmatic evidence of a sort' to the contrary was not wanting. Elkins v. United States, supra, at 218.
rationale: Elkins v. United States is referenced multiple times to support the Court's reasoning and to illustrate the development of exclusionary rule doctrine, but its holding is neither changed nor criticized.

quote: Less than 30 years after Boyd, this Court, in Weeks v. United States, 232 U. S. 383 (1914), stated that 'the Fourth Amendment ... put the courts of the United States and Federal officials, in the exercise of their power and authority, under limitations and restraints ... and the duty of giving to it force and effect is obligatory upon all entrusted under our Federal system with the enforcement of the laws.' At pp. 391-392.
rationale: Weeks v. United States is repeatedly cited as foundational precedent for the exclusionary rule, and its authority is affirmed and extended to the states, but not altered or criticized.

quote: Some five years after Wolf, in answer to a plea made here Term after Term that we overturn its doctrine on applicability of the Weeks exclusionary rule, this Court indicated that such should not be done until the States had 'adequate opportunity to adopt or reject the [Weeks] rule.' Irvine v. California, supra, at 134.
rationale: Irvine v. California is cited as part of the historical development of the exclusionary rule, but is not criticized, overruled, or otherwise materially affected.

quote: Significantly, among those now following the rule is California, which, according to its highest court, was 'compelled to reach tha(t conclusion because other remedies have completely failed to secure compliance with the constitutional provisions . . . .' People v. Cahan, 44 Cal. 2d 434, 445, 282 P. 2d 905, 911 (1955).
rationale: People v. Cahan is cited as an example of a state court adopting the exclusionary rule, but the Acting Decision does not alter or criticize its holding.

quote: Seventy-five years ago, in Boyd v. United States, 116 U. S. 616, 630 (1886), considering the Fourth and Fifth Amendments as running 'almost into each other' ... this Court held that the doctrines of those Amendments 'apply to all invasions on the part of the government and its employés of the sanctity of a man’s home and the privacies of life.'
rationale: Boyd v. United States is cited as historical precedent for the principles underlying the exclusionary rule, but its authority is not questioned or altered.

quote: Since Mr. Justice Harlan, Mr. Justice Frankfurter, and Mr. Justice Clark agree with us concerning Wilcox, that case is overruled.
rationale: The lead opinion explicitly states that Commissioner v. Wilcox is overruled, leaving no doubt as to the treatment.

quote: Six years later, this Court held, in Rutkin v. United States, 343 U. S. 130, that extorted money does constitute taxable income to the extortionist in the year that the money is received under § 22 (a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1939. In Rutkin, the Court did not overrule Wilcox, but stated: 'We do not reach in this case the factual situation involved in Commissioner v. Wilcox, 327 U. S. 404. We limit that case to its facts.'
rationale: Rutkin is discussed for its reasoning and its relationship to Wilcox, but the Acting Decision neither overrules, criticizes, nor distinguishes it; it is used as supporting precedent and context.

cited_decision: McKnight v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue (1942)
quote: See, e. g., Spear Box Co. v. Commissioner, 182 F. 2d 844 (C. A. 2d Cir.); Helvering v. Jane Holding Corp., 109 F. 2d 933 (C. A. 8th Cir.); Pacific Magnesium, Inc., v. Westover, 86 F. Supp. 644 (D. C. S. D. Cal.). See, e. g., Schweppe v. Commissioner, 168 F. 2d 284 (C. A. 9th Cir.); North American Coal Corp. v. Commissioner, 97 F. 2d 325 (C. A. 6th Cir.); Securities Co. v. United States, 85 F. Supp. 532 (D. C. S. D. N.Y.).
rationale: McKnight is only listed among other cases in a string citation and is not discussed or analyzed; it is merely mentioned.

quote: Corliss v. Bowers, 281 U. S. 376, 378. Thus, the fact that Rutkin secured the money with the consent of his victim, Rutkin v. United States, supra, at p. 138, is irrelevant. Likewise unimportant is the fact that the sufferer of an extortion is less likely to seek restitution than one whose funds are embezzled. What is important is that the right to recoupment exists in both situations.
rationale: Corliss v. Bowers is cited for a general principle about control over property and is not the subject of any criticism, limitation, or distinction.

quote: Rutkin v. United States, supra, at p. 138; United States v. Sullivan, 274 U. S. 259, 263. Thereafter, the Court held that gains from illicit traffic in liquor are includible within 'gross income.' Ibid.
rationale: Sullivan is referenced as precedent for the inclusion of illegal gains in gross income, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, distinguish, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: But the fact that Congress has remained silent or has re-enacted a statute which we have construed, or that congressional attempts to amend a rule announced by this Court have failed, does not necessarily debar us from re-examining and correcting the Court’s own errors. Girouard v. United States, 328 U. S. 61, 69-70; Helvering v. Hallock, 309 U. S. 106, 119-122.
rationale: Helvering v. Hallock is cited for a general principle about the Court's authority to revisit its own precedents, not for its specific holding or reasoning.

cited_decision: North American Oil Consolidated v. Burnet (1932)
quote: When a taxpayer acquires earnings, lawfully or unlawfully, without the consensual recognition, express or implied, of an obligation to repay and without restriction as to their disposition, 'he has received income which he is required to return, even though it may still be claimed that he is not entitled to retain the money, and even though he may still be adjudged liable to restore its equivalent.' North American Oil v. Burnet, supra, at p. 424.
rationale: North American Oil is cited for a general principle about the claim of right doctrine, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or distinguish it.

quote: When a law-abiding taxpayer mistakenly receives income in one year, which receipt is assailed and found to be invalid in a subsequent year, the taxpayer must nonetheless report the amount as 'gross income' in the year received. United States v. Lewis, supra; Healy v. Commissioner, supra.
rationale: Lewis is cited as support for the claim of right doctrine and annual accounting, but is not criticized, limited, or otherwise treated beyond being referenced.

quote: If it is due process for Nevada to adjudicate the marriage status of a domiciliary without personal service over the absent spouse (as it clearly is, see Williams v. North Carolina, I, 317 U. S. 287 ), I see no reason why Nevada cannot, at least for the purposes of her own law, also adjudicate the incidents of that status. ... Where status is concerned, this Court held that the interest in certainty as to whether one is married or single outweighs the interest of home States in the marital status of their domiciliaries, so that North Carolina was forced to swallow Nevada’s views as to what is sufficient cause for divorce even though the North Carolina wife had not appeared in the Nevada proceeding. Williams, I, supra. But I see no reason why we should extend that ... to hold that Nevada’s views as to support as well as divorce must be forced onto other States...
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Williams v. North Carolina by noting that while it controls the recognition of marital status, it does not require the same result for support obligations, which are treated as a separate issue.

quote: It has long been the constitutional rule that a court cannot adjudicate a personal claim or obligation unless it has jurisdiction over the person of the defendant. 6 Here, the Nevada divorce court *419 was as powerless to cut off the wife’s support right as it would have been to order the husband to pay alimony if the wife had brought the divorce action and he had not been subject to the divorce court’s jurisdiction. ... Pennoyer v. Neff, 95 U. S. 714, 726-727.
rationale: Pennoyer v. Neff is cited as authority for the general principle of personal jurisdiction, but the Acting Decision does not alter, criticize, or otherwise materially engage with its holding beyond applying its settled rule.

quote: Petitioner claims that this case is governed by Thompson v. Thompson, 226 U. S. 551. For the reasons given in a concurring opinion in Armstrong v. Armstrong, 350 U. S. 568, 575, at 580-581, the Thompson case, insofar as it held that an ex parte divorce destroyed alimony rights, can no longer be considered controlling.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Thompson v. Thompson is no longer controlling to the extent it held that an ex parte divorce destroyed alimony rights, thereby limiting its precedential value.

quote: In Estin v. Estin, 334 U. S. 541, this Court decided that a Nevada divorce court, which had no personal jurisdiction over the wife, had no power to terminate a husband’s obligation to provide her support as required in a preexisting New York separation decree. The factor which distinguishes the present case from Estin is that here the wife’s right to support had not been reduced to judgment prior to the husband’s ex parte divorce. In our opinion this difference is not material on the question before us.
rationale: Estin v. Estin is discussed and its rule is applied to the present facts, with the Acting Decision stating that the factual distinction is not material. The case is neither overruled, criticized, nor limited, but rather mentioned and followed.

quote: The keystone of supporting authorities mustered by the Court’s opinion last June to justify its holding that Art. Ill, § 2, and the Fifth and Sixth Amendments did not apply abroad was In re Ross, 140 U. S. 453 . The Ross case is one of those cases that cannot be understood except in its peculiar setting; even then, it seems highly unlikely that a similar result would be reached today... At best, the Ross case should be left as a relic from a different era.
rationale: The lead opinion expressly states that Ross should be left as a relic and not expanded, thus limiting its precedential value to its facts and refusing to extend its reasoning to the present context.

cited_decision: United States Ex Rel. Toth v. Quarles (1955)
quote: Construing this Courts decision in United States ex rel. Toth v. Quarles, 350 U. S. 11 , as holding that “a civilian is entitled to a civilian trial” the District Court held that Mrs. Covert could not be tried by court-martial and ordered her released from custody... There are no supportable grounds upon which to distinguish the Toth case from the present cases.
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on Toth as a supporting authority and analogizes the present case to it, but does not overrule, criticize, or otherwise alter its holding; it is cited as persuasive precedent.

quote: See Dorr v. United States, 195 U. S. 138, 144-148 .
rationale: Dorr is cited as part of a string citation to support the proposition that constitutional limitations can apply to government action outside the continental United States, but is not discussed or altered.

quote: In No. 713, Kinsella v. Krueger, the judgment of the District Court is reversed and the case is remanded with instructions to order Mrs. Smith released from custody. Reversed and remanded.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly reverses the judgment in Kinsella v. Krueger, as explicitly stated in the lead opinion.

quote: The Court’s opinion last Term alsp relied on the “Insular Cases” to support its conclusion that Article III and the Fifth and Sixth Amendments were not applicable to the trial of Mrs. Smith and Mrs. Covert. 22 We believe that reliance was misplaced. The “Insular Cases,” which arose at the turn of the century, involved territories which had only recently been conquered or acquired by the United States... The Insular Cases” can be distinguished from the present cases in that they involved the power of Congress to provide rules and regulations to govern temporarily territories with wholly dissimilar traditions and institutions whereas here the basis for governmental power is American citizenship. None of these cases had anything to do with military trials and they cannot properly be used as vehicles to support an extension of military jurisdiction to civilians.
rationale: Downes v. Bidwell is treated as part of the Insular Cases and is expressly distinguished on the basis of different facts and legal context.

quote: Marbury v. Madison, 1 Cranch 137, 176-180 ; Hawaii v. Mankichi, 190 U. S. 197, 236-239 (Harlan, J., dissenting).
rationale: Hawaii v. Mankichi is cited in a string citation and not discussed or analyzed further.

quote: Nothing said here contravenes the rule laid down in McCulloch v. Maryland, 4 Wheat. 316, at 421 , that: “Let the end be legitimate, let it be within the scope of the constitution, and all means which are appropriate, which are plainly adapted to that end, which are not prohibited, but consist with the letter and spirit of the constitution, are constitutional.”
rationale: McCulloch is quoted for a general principle regarding the Necessary and Proper Clause, but its holding is neither altered nor criticized.

quote: In re Di Bartolo, 50 F. Supp. 929 .
rationale: In Re Di Bartolo is cited in a string citation among lower court cases upholding military trial of civilians, but is not discussed or analyzed.

quote: Madsen v. Kinsella, 343 U. S. 341 , is not controlling here. It concerned trials in enemy territory which had been conquered and held by force of arms and which was being governed at the time by our military forces. In such areas the Army commander can establish military or civilian commissions as an arm of the occupation to try everyone in the occupied area, whether they are connected with the Army or not.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly distinguishes Madsen v. Kinsella on the grounds that it involved military government in occupied enemy territory, not the trial of civilian dependents accompanying the armed forces in friendly countries.

quote: On several occasions this Court has been faced with an attempted expansion of the jurisdiction of military courts. Ex parte Milligan, 4 Wall. 2 , one of the great landmarks in this Court’s history, held that military authorities were without power to try civilians not in the military or naval service by declaring martial law in an area where the civil *31 administration was not deposed and the courts were not closed.
rationale: Ex Parte Milligan is cited as a landmark case supporting the principle that civilians cannot be tried by military courts when civilian courts are open, but its holding is not altered or criticized.

quote: To take but one example: Balzac v. Porto Rico, 258 U. S. 298 , is not good authority for the proposition that jury trials need never be provided for American citizens tried by *75 the United States abroad; but the case is good authority for the proposition that there is no rigid rule that jury trial must always be provided in the trial of an American overseas, if the circumstances are such that trial by jury would be impractical and anomalous.
rationale: Balzac is distinguished as not controlling the present case; its holding is limited to its facts and not extended to the situation at hand.

quote: Subsequently, the Court granted a petition for rehearing, 352 U. S. 901 . Now, after further argument and consideration, we conclude that the previous decisions cannot be permitted to stand.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that the previous decisions (including 351 U.S. 487) cannot stand, thereby overruling its prior judgment in the same case.

quote: We overrule Brown v. United States, supra, and reverse and remand this case for proceedings under Rule 42 (b).
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that it overrules Brown v. United States, making this a clear case of the 'Overruled' treatment.

quote: In more than one instance in the Southern District of New York, from which this case comes, witnesses cited for testimonial contempt before the grand jury were given hearings under Rule 42 (b). E. g., United States v. Castaldi, 338 F. 2d 883 ; United States v. Tramunti, 343 F. 2d 548 ; United States v. Shillitani, 345 F. 2d 290; United States v. Pappadio, 346 F. 2d 5 .
rationale: The Acting Decision merely lists United States v. Pappadio as an example of a case where a certain procedure was followed, without discussing or analyzing its reasoning or outcome.

quote: In more than one instance in the Southern District of New York, from which this case comes, witnesses cited for testimonial contempt before the grand jury were given hearings under Rule 42 (b). E. g., United States v. Castaldi, 338 F. 2d 883 ; United States v. Tramunti, 343 F. 2d 548 ; United States v. Shillitani, 345 F. 2d 290; United States v. Pappadio, 346 F. 2d 5 .
rationale: United States v. Tramunti is mentioned as an example of a case where a certain procedure was used, but the Acting Decision does not analyze or critique its holding.

quote: Summary contempt is for 'misbehavior' (Ex parte Terry, 128 U. S. 289, 314 ) in the 'actual presence of the court.'
rationale: Ex Parte Terry is cited as historical authority for the definition of summary contempt, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes nor distinguishes it.

quote: Brown v. United States was reaffirmed and followed in Levine v. United States, 362 U. S. 610.
rationale: Levine v. United States is mentioned in passing as having followed Brown, but the Acting Decision does not discuss its reasoning or outcome.

quote: In more than one instance in the Southern District of New York, from which this case comes, witnesses cited for testimonial contempt before the grand jury were given hearings under Rule 42 (b). E. g., United States v. Castaldi, 338 F. 2d 883 ; United States v. Tramunti, 343 F. 2d 548 ; United States v. Shillitani, 345 F. 2d 290; United States v. Pappadio, 346 F. 2d 5 .
rationale: United States v. Castaldi is listed as an example of a case using a certain procedure, with no further discussion or analysis.

quote: In more than one instance in the Southern District of New York, from which this case comes, witnesses cited for testimonial contempt before the grand jury were given hearings under Rule 42 (b). E. g., United States v. Castaldi, 338 F. 2d 883 ; United States v. Tramunti, 343 F. 2d 548 ; United States v. Shillitani, 345 F. 2d 290; United States v. Pappadio, 346 F. 2d 5 .
rationale: United States v. Shillitani is mentioned as an example of a case where a certain procedure was followed, without further discussion or analysis.

quote: The critical question in this case is whether, under the circumstances, .the refusal by the police to honor petitioner’s request to consult with his lawyer during the course of an interrogation constitutes a denial of “the Assistance of Counsel” in violation of the Sixth Amendment to the Constitution as “made obligatory upon the States by the Fourteenth Amendment,” Gideon v. Wainwright, 372 U. S. 335, 342 , and thereby renders inadmissible in a state criminal trial any incriminating statement elicited by the police during the interrogation.
rationale: Gideon v. Wainwright is cited as authority for the proposition that the Sixth Amendment right to counsel applies to the states, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes, limits, nor overrules it; it is used as foundational precedent.

quote: The judgment of the Illinois Supreme Court is reversed and the case remanded for proceedings not inconsistent with this opinion. Reversed and remanded.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly reverses the judgment of the Illinois Supreme Court in The PEOPLE v. Escobedo.

quote: In Massiah v. United States, 377 U. S. 201 , this Court observed that “a Constitution which guarantees a defendant the aid of counsel at . . . trial could surely vouchsafe no less to an indicted defendant under interrogation by the police in a completely extrajudicial proceeding. Anything less . . . might deny a defendant effective representation by counsel at the only stage when *485 legal aid and advice would help him.’ ” Id., at 204 , quoting Douglas, J., concurring in Spano v. New York, 360 U. S. 315, 326 .
rationale: Massiah is cited as supportive precedent for the right to counsel during interrogation, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: The Court’s opinion in Cicenia v. Lagay, 357 U. S. 504 , decided the same day, merely said that the “contention that petitioner had a constitutional right to confer with counsel is disposed of by Crooker v. California . . . That case adds nothing, therefore, to Crooker . In any event, to the extent that Cicenia or Crooker may be inconsistent with the principles announced today, they are not to be regarded as controlling.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Cicenia is not controlling to the extent it is inconsistent with the new rule announced, thereby limiting its precedential value.

quote: It was a stage surely as critical as was the arraignment in Hamilton v. Alabama, 368 U. S. 52 , and the preliminary hearing in White v. Maryland, 373 U. S. 59 .
rationale: White v. Maryland is cited as an example of a critical stage requiring counsel, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: When petitioner requested, and was denied, an opportunity to consult with his lawyer, the investigation had ceased to be a general investigation of “an unsolved crime.” Spano v. New York, 360 U. S. 315, 327 (Stewart, J., concurring).
rationale: Spano v. New York is referenced for its discussion of when an investigation becomes accusatory, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: Crooker v. California, 357 U. S. 433 , does not compel a contrary result. ... In any event, to the extent that Cicenia or Crooker may be inconsistent with the principles announced today, they are not to be regarded as controlling.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Crooker is not controlling to the extent it conflicts with the new rule, thereby limiting its precedential value.

quote: It was a stage surely as critical as was the arraignment in Hamilton v. Alabama, 368 U. S. 52 , and the preliminary hearing in White v. Maryland, 373 U. S. 59 . What happened at this interrogation could certainly “affect the whole trial,” Hamilton v. Alabama, supra, at 54, since rights “may be as irretrievably lost, if not then and there asserted, as they are when an accused represented by counsel waives a right for strategic purposes.” Ibid.
rationale: Hamilton v. Alabama is cited as precedent for the importance of counsel at critical stages, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

cited_decision: Adkins v. Children's Hospital of Columbia (1923)
quote: This intrusion by the judiciary into the realm of legislative value judgments was strongly objected to at the time, particularly by Mr. Justice Holmes and Mr. Justice Brandéis. Dissenting from the Court’s invalidating a state statute which regulated the resale price of theatre and other tickets, Mr. Justice Holmes said, ... The doctrine that prevailed in Lochner, Coppage, Adkins, Burns, and like cases — that due process authorizes courts to hold laws unconstitutional when they believe the legislature has acted unwisely- — -has long since been discarded. We have returned to the original constitutional proposition that courts do not substitute their social and economic beliefs for the judgment of legislative bodies, who are elected to pass laws. As this Court stated in a unanimous opinion in 1941, “We are not concerned . . . with the wisdom, need, or appropriateness of the legislation.” ... In the face of our abandonment of the use of the “vague contours” 9 of the Due Process Clause to nullify laws which a majority of the Court believed to be economically unwise, reliance on Adams v. Tanner is as mistaken as would be adherence to Adkins v. Children’s Hospital , overruled by West Coast Hotel Co. v. Parrish, 300 U. S. 379 (1937).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Adkins as part of a group of cases whose doctrine has been discarded and notes that Adkins was overruled by West Coast Hotel Co. v. Parrish, but does not itself overrule, criticize, or otherwise treat Adkins beyond mentioning its historical context.

quote: There was a time when the Due Process Clause was used by this Court to strike down laws which were thought unreasonable, that is, unwise or incompatible with some particular economic or social philosophy. In this manner the Due Process Clause was used, for example, to nullify laws prescribing maximum hours for work in bakeries, Lochner v. New York, 198 U. S. 45 (1905), ... The doctrine that prevailed in Lochner, Coppage, Adkins, Burns, and like cases — that due process authorizes courts to hold laws unconstitutional when they believe the legislature has acted unwisely- — -has long since been discarded.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly rejects the doctrine of Lochner and similar cases, stating that their approach has been discarded, which constitutes criticism of their reasoning and result.

quote: This intrusion by the judiciary into the realm of legislative value judgments was strongly objected to at the time, particularly by Mr. Justice Holmes and Mr. Justice Brandéis. Dissenting from the Court’s invalidating a state statute which regulated the resale price of theatre and other tickets, Mr. Justice Holmes said, ... Mr. Justice Holmes even went so far as to say that “subject to compensation when compensation is due, the legislature may forbid or restrict any business when it has a sufficient force of public opinion behind it.” Tyson & Brother v. Banton, 273 U. S. 418, 445, 446 (1927) (dissenting opinion).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Tyson & Brother v. Banton only to quote Holmes's dissenting opinion, not to discuss or alter the precedential value of the case itself.

cited_decision: Olsen v. Nebraska Ex Rel. Western Reference & Bond Assn., Inc. (1941)
quote: As this Court stated in a unanimous opinion in 1941, “We are not concerned . . . with the wisdom, need, or appropriateness of the legislation.” 6 ... 6 Olsen v. Nebraska ex rel. Western Reference & Bond Assn., 313 U. S. 236, 246 (1941) (upholding a Nebraska statute limiting the amount of the fee which could be charged by private employment agencies).
rationale: Olsen is cited as authority for the proposition that courts should not judge the wisdom of legislation, but the Acting Decision does not otherwise discuss or alter its holding.

quote: Legislative bodies have broad scope to experiment with economic problems, and this Court does not sit to “subject the State to an intolerable supervision hostile to the basic principles of our Government and wholly beyond the protection which the general clause of the Fourteenth Amendment was intended to secure.” 7 ... 7 Sproles v. Binford, 286 U. S. 374, 388 (1932).
rationale: Sproles is cited for a general principle about legislative discretion, without further discussion or modification.

cited_decision: Lincoln Federal Labor Union v. Northwestern Iron & Metal Co. (1949)
quote: It is now settled that States “have power to legislate against what are found to be injurious practices in their internal commercial and business affairs, so long as their laws do *731 not run afoul of some specific federal constitutional prohibition, or of some valid federal law.” 8 Lincoln Federal Labor Union v. Northwestern Iron & Metal Co., 335 U. S. 525, 536 (1949).
rationale: Lincoln Federal Labor Union is cited as authority for the settled law on state legislative power, but the Acting Decision does not otherwise discuss or alter its holding.

cited_decision: Williamson v. Lee Optical of Oklahoma, Inc. (1955)
quote: We refuse to sit as a “superlegislature to weigh the wisdom of legislation,” 11 and we emphatically refuse to go back to the time when courts used the Due Process Clause “to strike down state laws, regulatory of business and industrial conditions, because they may be unwise, im *732 provident, or out of harmony with a particular school of thought.” 12 ... Mr. Justice Harlan concurs in the judgment on the ground that this state measure bears a rational relation to a constitutionally permissible objective. See Williamson v. Lee Optical Co., 348 U. S. 483, 491 . ... 15 See Williamson v. Lee Optical Co., 348 U. S. 483, 488-489 (1955);
rationale: Williamson v. Lee Optical is cited multiple times as authority for the rational basis test and legislative discretion, but the Acting Decision does not otherwise discuss or alter its holding.

cited_decision: Home Budget Service, Inc. v. Boston Bar Association (1957)
quote: The Massachusetts statute was upheld in Home Budget Service, Inc., v. Boston Bar Assn., 335 Mass. 228 , 139 N. E. 2d 387 (1957).
rationale: Home Budget Service is cited as an example of a state court upholding a similar statute, with no further discussion or alteration.

quote: In doing so, the Pennsylvania court relied heavily on Adams v. Tanner, 244 U. S. 590 (1917), which held that the Due Process Clause forbids a State to prohibit a business which is “useful” and not “inherently immoral or dangerous to public welfare.” Both the District Court in the present case and the Pennsylvania court in Stone adopted the philosophy of Adams v. Tanner , and cases like it, that it is the province of courts to draw on their own views as to the morality, *729 legitimacy, and usefulness of a particular business in order to decide whether a statute bears too heavily upon that business and by so doing violates due process. ... The doctrine that prevailed in Lochner, Coppage, Adkins, Burns, and like cases — that due process authorizes courts to hold laws unconstitutional when they believe the legislature has acted unwisely- — -has long since been discarded. ... In the face of our abandonment of the use of the “vague contours” 9 of the Due Process Clause to nullify laws which a majority of the Court believed to be economically unwise, reliance on Adams v. Tanner is as mistaken as would be adherence to Adkins v. Children’s Hospital , overruled by West Coast Hotel Co. v. Parrish, 300 U. S. 379 (1937). Not only has the philosophy of Adams been abandoned, but also this Court almost 15 years ago expressly pointed to another opinion of this Court as having “clearly undermined” Adams . 10
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly rejects the reasoning and philosophy of Adams v. Tanner, stating that its doctrine has been abandoned and undermined, which constitutes criticism.

quote: American Communications Assn. v. Douds, 339 U. S. 382 , which upheld the predecessor statute to § 504 is ob *465 viously overruled.
rationale: The dissenting opinion explicitly states that Douds is 'obviously overruled' by the majority's reasoning, and the majority opinion repeatedly distinguishes and rejects the rationale of Douds, making clear that the precedent is no longer good law.

cited_decision: Communist Party of United States v. Subversive Activities Control Bd. (1961)
quote: Communist Party v. Subversive Activities Control Board, 367 U. S. 1 , lends support to our conclusion. ... A majority of the Court rejected the argument that the Act was a bill of attainder, reasoning that § 3 does not specify the persons or groups upon which the deprivations set forth in the Act are to be imposed, but instead sets forth a general definition. ... In this case no disagreement over whether the statute in question designates a particular organization can arise, for § 504 in terms inflicts its disqualification upon members of the Communist Party.
rationale: The majority opinion distinguishes the Subversive Activities Control Board case by noting that the statute there set forth a general definition rather than targeting a specific group, unlike § 504, which directly targets Communist Party members.

cited_decision: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System v. Agnew (1947)
quote: The Solicitor General points out that in Board of Governors v. Agnew, 329 U. S. 441 , this Court applied § 32 of the Banking Act of 1933... We find this argument without merit. First, we note that § 504, unlike § 32 of the Banking Act, inflicts its deprivation upon the members of a political group thought to present a threat to the national security. ... Thus insofar as § 32 incorporates a condemnation, it condemns all men. ... That Congress was legislating with *455 respect to general characteristics rather than with respect to a specific group of men is well demonstratecfby the fact that § 32 provides that the prescribed disqualification should not obtain whenever the Board of Governors determined that 'it would not unduly influence the investment policies of such member bank or the advice it gives its customers regarding investments.'
rationale: The majority opinion distinguishes Agnew by emphasizing that the statute there applied a general rule to all persons with certain business interests, whereas § 504 targets a specific political group, making the two statutes meaningfully different.

quote: The approach which Chief Justice Marshall had suggested was followed in the twin post-Civil War cases of Cummings v. Missouri, 4 Wall. 277 , and Ex parte Garland, 4 Wall. 333 . ... This Court struck down both provisions as bills of attainder on the ground that they were legislative acts inflicting punishment on a specific group: clergymen and lawyers who had taken part in the rebellion and therefore could not truthfully take the oath.
rationale: Cummings v. Missouri is cited as historical precedent supporting the broad reading of the Bill of Attainder Clause, but the Acting Decision does not alter, criticize, or limit its holding; it is used as background authority.

quote: The next extended discussion of the Bill of Attainder Clause 21 came in 1946, in United States v. Lovett, 328 U. S. 303 , where the Court invalidated § 304 of the Urgent Deficiency Appropriation Act, 1943, 57 Stat. 431 , 450, which prohibited payment of further salary to three named federal employees, 22 as a bill of attainder.
rationale: Lovett is cited as a supporting precedent for the majority's interpretation of the Bill of Attainder Clause, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes nor limits its holding; it is used to reinforce the majority's reasoning.

quote: The leading case is Hawker v. New York, 170 U. S. 189 , which upheld a provision prohibiting convicted felons from practicing medicine against a claim that, as applied to one convicted before its enactment, it was an ex post facto law.
rationale: Hawker is discussed as an example of a statute that was upheld against a constitutional challenge, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

quote: Whether a punitive purpose would be inferred has depended in past cases on a number of circumstances, including the nature of the disability, whether it was traditionally regarded as punishment, whether it is rationally connected to a permissible legislative objective, as well as the specificity of the legisla *463 ture’s designation of the persons to be affected. See generally Kennedy v. Mendoza-Martines, 372 U. S. 144, 168-169.
rationale: Kennedy v. Mendoza-Martinez is cited for its analytical framework regarding punitive purpose, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: Perez v. Brownell is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Perez v. Brownell is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value.

cited_decision: United States v. Wong Kim Ark (1898)
quote: And this was the unequivocal statement of the Court in the case of United States v. Wong Kim Ark, 169 U. S. 649. ... The Court then held that Congress could not do anything to abridge or affect his citizenship conferred by the Fourteenth Amendment.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Wong Kim Ark as supporting authority for the proposition that Congress cannot abridge citizenship, but does not alter, criticize, or otherwise materially affect its precedential value.

quote: his general understanding of the statute was approved by this Court in Kurtz v. Moffitt, 115 U. S. 487, 501.
rationale: Kurtz v. Moffitt is mentioned in the context of historical practice and understanding, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes nor distinguishes it, nor does it affect its authority.

quote: Trop v. Dulles, 356 U. S. 86 ; Nishikawa v. Dulles, 356 U. S. 129 . Kennedy v. Mendoza-Martinez, 372 U. S. 144 ; Schneider v. Rusk, 377 U. S. 163 .
rationale: Trop v. Dulles is cited as part of a string of cases that have cast doubt on Perez, but the Acting Decision does not overrule, criticize, or otherwise alter Trop's precedential value.

quote: Moreover, the dictum must be read in light of the subsequent opinion for the Court, written by Mr. Justice McKenna, in Mackenzie v. Hare, 239 U. S. 299. Despite counsel’s invocation of Wong Kim Ark, id., at 302 and 303, the Court held in Mackenzie that marriage between an American citizen and an alien, unaccompanied by any intention of the citizen to renounce her citizenship, nonetheless permitted Congress to ■withdraw her nationality. It is immaterial for these purposes that Mrs. Mackenzie’s citizenship might, under the statute there, have been restored upon termination of the marital relationship; she did not consent to the loss, even temporarily, of her citizenship, and, under the proposition apparently urged by the Court today, it can therefore scarcely matter that her expatriation was subject to some condition subsequent.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses MacKenzie v. Hare as a case where citizenship was lost under different circumstances (marriage to an alien), and contrasts it with the present case, thereby distinguishing it on its facts and legal context.

quote: For on that premise my Brother Stewart sets out methods in accord with the Fourth Amendment to guide States in the enactment and enforcement of laws passed to regulate wiretapping by government. In this respect today’s opinion differs sharply from Berger v. New York, 388 U. S. 41 , decided last Term, which held void on its face a New York statute authorizing wiretapping on warrants issued by magistrates on showings of probable cause. The Berger case also set up what appeared to be insuperable obstacles to the valid passage of such wiretapping laws by States. The Court’s opinion in this case, however, removes the doubts about state power in this field and abates to a large extent the confusion and near-paralyzing effect of the Berger holding.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly notes that its holding 'differs sharply' from Berger and clarifies or narrows the confusion caused by Berger, indicating that Berger is not overruled but is distinguished on its facts and effect.

quote: But '[t]he premise that property interests control the right of the Government to search and seize has been discredited.' Warden v. Hayden, 387 U. S. 294, 304.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Hayden for a general legal principle about property interests and the Fourth Amendment, without criticizing, limiting, or otherwise altering its authority.

quote: Indeed, we have expressly held that the Fourth Amendment governs not only the seizure of tangible items, but extends as well to the recording of oral statements, overheard without any 'technical trespass under . . . local property law.' Silverman v. United States, 365 U. S. 505, 511.
rationale: Silverman is cited as supporting precedent for the proposition that the Fourth Amendment applies to certain forms of eavesdropping, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or overrule it.

quote: It is true that this Court has occasionally described its conclusions in terms of 'constitutionally protected areas,' see, e. g., Silverman v. United States, 365 U. S. 505, 510, 512 ; Lopez v. United States, 373 U. S. 427, 438-439 ; Berger v. New York, 388 U. S. 41, 57, 59 , but we have never suggested that this concept can serve as a talismanic solution to every Fourth Amendment problem.
rationale: Lopez is referenced as an example of prior case law using certain terminology, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes nor limits its holding.

quote: In omitting any requirement of advance notice, the federal court that authorized electronic surveillance in Osborn simply recognized, as has this Court, that officers need not announce their purpose before conducting an otherwise authorized search if such an announcement would provoke the escape of the suspect or the destruction of critical evidence. See Ker v. California, 374 U. S. 23, 37-41.
rationale: Ker is cited for a procedural point about notice in searches, with no criticism or limitation of its authority.

quote: But what he seeks-to preserve as private, even in an area accessible to the public, may be constitutionally pro *352 tected. See Rios v. United States, 364 U. S. 253 ; Ex parte Jackson, 96 U. S. 727, 733.
rationale: Rios is cited as supporting precedent for the proposition that privacy can be protected in public areas, without any criticism or limitation.

quote: It is true that the absence of such penetration was at one time thought to foreclose further Fourth Amendment inquiry, Olmstead v. United States, 277 U. S. 438, 457, 464, 466 ; Goldman v. United States, 316 U. S. 129, 134-136 , for that Amendment was thought to limit only searches and seizures of tangible *353 property. 13 ... We conclude that the underpinnings of Olmstead and Goldman have been so eroded by our subsequent decisions that the 'trespass' doctrine there enunciated can no longer be regarded as controlling.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that the foundational doctrine of Goldman is no longer controlling, which amounts to an overruling of its core holding.

quote: It is true that the absence of such penetration was at one time thought to foreclose further Fourth Amendment inquiry, Olmstead v. United States, 277 U. S. 438, 457, 464, 466 ; ... We conclude that the underpinnings of Olmstead and Goldman have been so eroded by our subsequent decisions that the 'trespass' doctrine there enunciated can no longer be regarded as controlling.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the doctrine of Olmstead is no longer controlling, thereby overruling its central holding regarding the Fourth Amendment and wiretapping.

quote: Having concluded that Frank v. Maryland, to the extent that it sanctioned such warrantless inspections, must be overruled, we reverse.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Frank v. Maryland is overruled regarding its approval of warrantless inspections, directly nullifying its precedential value on this point.

cited_decision: Ohio Ex Rel. Eaton v. Price (1960)
quote: In Eaton v. Price, 364 U. S. 263, a similar conviction was affirmed by an equally divided Court.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Eaton v. Price as a similar case and notes its procedural posture but does not engage in substantive analysis or criticism, nor does it overrule or distinguish it.

quote: As such, the Fourth Amendment is enforceable against the States through the Fourteenth Amendment. Ker v. California, 374 U. S. 23, 30.
rationale: Ker v. California is cited for the general proposition that the Fourth Amendment applies to the states, without further discussion or alteration of its holding.

quote: Relying on Frank v. Maryland, Eaton v. Price, and decisions in other States, 3 the District *528 Court of Appeal held that § 503 does not violate Fourth Amendment rights...
rationale: Givner v. State is referenced as an example of a state court decision following Frank v. Maryland, but the Acting Decision does not analyze or alter its reasoning.

quote: See, e. g., Stoner v. California, 376 U. S. 483; United States v. Jeffers, 342 U. S. 48; McDonald v. United States, 335 U. S. 451; Agnello v. United States, 269 U. S. 20.
rationale: Stoner v. California is cited as an example supporting the general rule that warrantless searches are unreasonable, but the Acting Decision does not critique or distinguish it.

quote: See, e. g., Stoner v. California, 376 U. S. 483; United States v. Jeffers, 342 U. S. 48; McDonald v. United States, 335 U. S. 451; Agnello v. United States, 269 U. S. 20.
rationale: McDonald v. United States is cited as precedent for the general rule requiring warrants for searches, with no further discussion or modification.

cited_decision: Paquette v. City of Fall River (1959)

City of Fall River, 338 Mass. 368, 155 N. E. 2d 775; Richards v. City of Columbia, 227 S. C. 538, 88 S. E. 2d 683; Boden v. City of Milwaukee, 8 Wis. 2d 318, 99 N. W. 2d 156.
rationale: Paquette v. City of Fall River is listed among cases upholding municipal police power to enforce minimum standards, but the Acting Decision does not analyze or alter its holding.

rationale: Commonwealth v. Hadley is cited as an example of a state court decision upholding warrantless inspections, but the Acting Decision does not discuss or critique it directly.

quote: See Abbate Bros. v. City of Chicago, 11 Ill. 2d 337, 142 N. E. 2d 691; City of Louisville v. Thompson, 339 S. W. 2d 869 (Ky.); Adamec v. Post, 273 N. Y. 250, 7 N. E. 2d 120; Paquette v. City of Fall River, 338 Mass. 368, 155 N. E. 2d 775;
rationale: Adamec v. Post is referenced as precedent for municipal enforcement of minimum standards, but the Acting Decision does not analyze or alter its reasoning.

quote: See Schmerber v. California, 384 U. S. 757, 770-771.
rationale: Schmerber v. California is cited for the proposition that the public interest must be considered in reasonableness analysis, but the Acting Decision does not critique, distinguish, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: In Malloy v. Hogan, supra, the Court rejected Palko’s discussion of the self-incrimination clause. Respectfully, we reject the prior dicta regarding jury trial in criminal cases.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly rejects the dicta in Palko regarding the right to jury trial, expressing doubt about its continuing validity and thus questioning its precedential value.

quote: In Malloy v. Hogan, 378 U. S. 1 (1964).
rationale: Malloy v. Hogan is cited as an example of a case applying Bill of Rights protections to the states, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes nor distinguishes it, instead referencing it as part of the incorporation doctrine.

quote: Pointer v. Texas, 380 U. S. 400 (1965).
rationale: Pointer v. Texas is cited as an example of a right incorporated against the states, with no criticism or limitation; it is simply referenced to support the incorporation of rights.

quote: The question has been asked whether a right is among those 'fundamental principles of liberty and justice which lie at the base of all our civil and political institutions,' Powell v. Alabama, 287 U. S. 45, 67 (1932);
rationale: Powell v. Alabama is cited as a source for the test of fundamental rights, and is used to support the reasoning of the Acting Decision, without criticism or limitation.

quote: District of Columbia v. Clawans, 300 U. S. 617 (1937).
rationale: Clawans is cited as precedent for distinguishing between petty and serious offenses for jury trial purposes, and is used as guidance for the current decision, without criticism or limitation.

quote: Gideon v. Wainwright, 372 U. S. 335 (1963).
rationale: Gideon v. Wainwright is cited as an example of a right incorporated against the states, and is referenced positively to support the incorporation doctrine.

quote: Maxwell held that no provision of the Bill of Rights applied to the States— a position long since repudiated — and that the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment did not prevent a State from trying a defendant for a noncapital offense with fewer than 12 men on the jury. It did not deal with a case in which no jury at all had been provided.
rationale: The Acting Decision limits Maxwell v. Dow by noting that its holding is confined to cases with fewer than 12 jurors and that its broader position on the Bill of Rights has been repudiated, thus narrowing its applicability.

quote: See also Irvin v. Dowd, 366 U. S. 717, 721-722 (1961);
rationale: Irvin v. Dowd is cited as supporting authority for the importance of jury trial, without criticism or limitation.

quote: This Court as in those cases reversed the conviction of a defendant in Haynes v. Washington, 373 U. S. 503 (1963), whose persistent request during his interrogation was to phone his wife or attorney. 25 In other settings, these individuals might have exercised their constitutional rights. In the incommunicado police-dominated atmosphere, they succumbed.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Haynes v. Washington as an example of a prior case where a confession was found inadmissible due to coercive circumstances, but does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its precedential value. It is used to illustrate the Court's reasoning.

quote: This question, in fact, could have been taken as settled in federal courts almost 70 years ago, when, in Bram v. United States, 168 U. S. 532, 542 (1897), this Court held: 'In criminal trials, in the courts of the United States, wherever a question arises whether a confession is incompetent because not voluntary, the issue is controlled by that portion of the Fifth Amendment . . . commanding that no person 'shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself.''
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Bram v. United States as historical support for its holding, reaffirming its principle regarding the Fifth Amendment and voluntariness of confessions, without criticizing or limiting it.

quote: We dealt with certain phases of this problem recently in Escobedo v. Illinois, 378 U. S. 478 (1964)... We have undertaken a thorough re-examination of the Escobedo decision and the principles it announced, and we reaffirm it.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly reaffirms Escobedo v. Illinois, treating it as controlling precedent and building upon its principles. There is no criticism or limitation; rather, it is positively cited and extended.

quote: Our decision in Malloy v. Hogan, 378 U. S. 1 (1964), necessitates an examination of the scope of the privilege in state cases as well. In Malloy, we squarely held the privilege applicable to the States, and held that the substantive standards underlying the privilege applied with full force to state court proceedings.
rationale: Malloy v. Hogan is cited as binding precedent for the application of the Fifth Amendment privilege to the states. The Acting Decision accepts and applies its holding without criticism or limitation.

quote: In accordance with our holdings today and in Escobedo v. Illinois, 378 U. S. 478, 492, Crooker v. California, 357 U. S. 433 (1958) and Cicenia v. Lagay, 357 U. S. 504 (1958) are not to be followed.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Crooker v. California is not to be followed, thereby overruling it.

quote: Ashcraft v. Tennessee, 322 U. S. 143 (1944); Malinski v. New York, 324 U. S. 401 (1945); Leyra v. Denno, 347 U. S. 556 (1954).
rationale: Ashcraft v. Tennessee is cited as an example of a prior confession case, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: The defendant in Lynumn v. Illinois, 372 U. S. 528 (1963), was a woman who confessed to the arresting officer after being importuned to 'cooperate' in order to prevent her children from being taken by relief authorities.
rationale: Lynumn v. Illinois is referenced as an illustrative case supporting the Acting Decision's reasoning, without criticism or limitation.

cited_decision: Ziang Sung Wan v. United States
quote: In 1924, Mr. Justice Brandéis wrote for a unanimous Court in reversing a conviction resting on a compelled confession, Wan v. United States, 266 U. S. 1.
rationale: Ziang Sung Wan v. United States is cited as historical precedent for the requirement of voluntariness in confessions, supporting the Acting Decision's holding.

quote: For example, in Leyra v. Denno, 347 U. S. 556 (1954), the interrogator-psychiatrist told the accused, 'We do sometimes things that are not right, but in a fit of temper or anger we sometimes do things we aren’t really responsible for,' id., at 562, and again, 'We know that morally you were just in anger. Morally, you are not to be condemned,' id., at 582. ... A variant on the technique of creating hostility is one of engendering fear. This is perhaps best described by the prosecuting attorney in Malinski v. New York, 324 U. S. 401, 407 (1945): 'Why this talk about being undressed? Of course, they had a right to undress him to look for bullet scars, and keep the clothes off him. That was quite proper police procedure. That is some more psychology — let him sit around with a blanket on him, humiliate him there for a while; let him sit in the corner, let him think he is going to get a shellacking.'
rationale: Malinski v. New York is referenced as an example of police interrogation techniques, but the Acting Decision does not criticize or limit its authority.

cited_decision: Hopt v. People of Territory of Utah
quote: The admissibility of a statement in the face of a claim that it was obtained in violation of the defendant’s constitutional rights is an issue the resolution of which has long since been undertaken by this Court. See Hopt v. Utah, 110 U. S. 574 (1884).
rationale: Hopt v. Utah is cited as an early precedent for judicial review of the admissibility of confessions, without criticism or limitation.

quote: In accordance with our holdings today and in Escobedo v. Illinois, 378 U. S. 478, 492, Crooker v. California, 357 U. S. 433 (1958) and Cicenia v. Lagay, 357 U. S. 504 (1958) are not to be followed.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Cicenia v. Lagay is not to be followed, thereby overruling it.

quote: In view of the Nardone and Benanti decisions, 8 the doctrine of Schwartz v. Texas cannot survive the demise of Wolf v. Colorado, supra.
rationale: The lead opinion explicitly states that the doctrine of Schwartz v. Texas 'cannot survive,' indicating that the Court is expressly overruling Schwartz as a precedent.

quote: That doctrinal underpinning of the Schwartz decision was, of course, completely removed by Mapp v. Ohio, 367 U. S. 643 , which overruled Wolf and squarely held that evidence obtained by state officers in an unreasonable search is inadmissible in a state criminal trial.
rationale: The opinion directly states that Wolf v. Colorado was overruled by Mapp v. Ohio, and this overruling is central to the Court's reasoning in the present case.

quote: In Nardone v. United States, 302 U. S. 379 , the Court was first called upon to decide whether § 605 had indeed served to render evidence of intercepted communications inadmissible in a federal trial.
rationale: The opinion discusses Nardone as foundational precedent for interpreting § 605, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority; it is cited as supporting the current decision.

quote: Indeed, evidence obtained by a state officer by means which would constitute an unlawful search and seizure under the Fourth Amendment to the Federal Constitution is nonetheless admissible in a state court, Wolf v. Colorado, 338 U. S. 25 , while such evidence, if obtained by a federal officer, would be clearly inadmissible in a federal court. Weeks v. United States, 232 U. S. 383.
rationale: Weeks is referenced as background for the exclusionary rule in federal courts, but the Acting Decision does not alter or question its authority.

quote: But the decision we reach today is not based upon language and doctrinal symmetry alone. It is buttressed as well by the 'imperative of judicial integrity.' Elkins v. United States, 364 U. S. 206, 222.
rationale: Elkins is cited for the principle of judicial integrity and as part of the doctrinal development, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

cited_decision: Adler v. Board of Ed. of City of New York (1952)
quote: Moreover, to the extent that Adler sustained the provision of the Feinberg Law constituting membership in an organization advocating forceful overthrow of government a ground for disqualification, pertinent constitutional doctrines have since rejected the premises upon which that conclusion rested. Adler is therefore not dispositive of the constitutional issues we must decide in this case.
rationale: The lead opinion explicitly states that Adler is no longer dispositive and that its premises have been rejected by subsequent constitutional doctrine. The Court then proceeds to hold the relevant statutes unconstitutional, thereby overruling Adler to the extent it upheld those statutes.

quote: We cannot gainsay the potential effect of this obscure wording on 'those with a conscientious and scrupulous regard for such undertakings.' Baggett v. Bullitt, 377 U. S. 360, 374.
rationale: Baggett is cited as an example of the chilling effect of vague statutes, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its precedential value; it simply applies its reasoning.

quote: In Elfbrandt v. Russell, 384 U. S. 11, we said, 'Those who join an organization but do not share its unlawful purposes and who do not participate in its unlawful activities surely pose no threat, either as citizens or as public employees.' Id., at 17.
rationale: Elfbrandt is quoted as controlling precedent for the proposition that mere membership without specific intent is not a constitutionally adequate basis for exclusion from employment. The Acting Decision applies Elfbrandt without questioning or limiting it.

cited_decision: National Ass'n for the Advancement of Colored People v. Button (1963)
quote: We emphasize once again that '[precision of regulation must be the touchstone in an area so closely touching our most precious freedoms,' N. A. A. C. P. v. Button, 371 U. S. 415, 438; '[f]or standards of permissible statutory vagueness are strict in the area of free expression.... Because First Amendment freedoms need breathing space to survive, government may regulate in the area only with narrow specificity.' Id., at 432-433.
rationale: Button is cited as authority for the standard of precision required in statutes affecting First Amendment freedoms. The Acting Decision relies on Button's reasoning without criticizing or limiting it.

quote: For '¿tjhe threat of sanctions may deter . . . almost as potently as the actual application of sanctions.' N. A. A. C. P. v. Button, supra, at 433. The danger of that chilling effect upon the exercise of vital First Amendment rights must be guarded against by sensitive tools which clearly inform teachers what is being proscribed. See Stromberg v. California, 283 U. S. 359, 369; Cramp v. Board of Public Instruction, 368 U. S. 278; Baggett v. Bullitt, supra. The regulatory maze created by New York is wholly lacking in 'terms susceptible of objective measurement.' Cramp v. Board of Public Instruction, supra, at 286. It has the quality of 'extraordinary ambiguity' found to be fatal to the oaths considered in Cramp and Baggett v. Bullitt. '[M]en of common intelligence must necessarily guess at its meaning and differ as to its application . . . .' Baggett v. Bullitt, supra, at 367.
rationale: Speiser is cited as part of a string of cases illustrating the chilling effect of vague statutes on First Amendment rights. The Acting Decision applies its reasoning without criticism or limitation.

quote: But 'even though the governmental purpose be legitimate and substantial, that purpose cannot be pursued by means thatbroadly' stiHe fundamental personal liberties when the end can be more narrowly achieved.' Shelton v. Tucker, 364 U. S. 479, 488.
rationale: Shelton is cited as authority for the principle that laws affecting fundamental liberties must be narrowly tailored. The Acting Decision relies on Shelton's reasoning without criticizing or limiting it.

quote: This is not a case where abstention pending state court interpretation would be appropriate, Baggett v. Bullitt, supra, at 375-379; Dombrowski v. Pfister, 380 U. S. 479, 489-490. Wieman v. Updegraff, 344 U. S. 183, 195 (Frankfurter, J., concurring). Whether or not loss of public employment constitutes 'punishment,' cf. United States v. Lovett, 328 U. S. 303, there can be no doubt that the repressive impact of the threat of discharge will be no less direct or substantial. See Lazarsfeld & Thielens, The Academic Mind 92-112, 192-217; Biddle, The Fear of Freedom 155 et seq.; Jahoda & Cook, *608 Security Measures and Freedom of Thought: An Exploratory Study of the Impact of Loyalty and Security Programs, 61 Yale L. J. 295 (1952). See generally, Maclver, Academic Freedom in Our Time; Hullfish, Educational Freedom in an Age of Anxiety; Konvitz, Expanding Liberties 86-108; Morris, Academic Freedom and Loyalty Oaths, 28 Law & Contemp. Prob. 487 (1963). In light of our disposition, we need not consider appellants’ contention that the burden placed on the employee of coming forward with substantial rebutting evidence upon proof of membership in a listed organization is constitutionally impermissible. Compare Speiser v. Randall, 357 U. S. 513. Now section 105. Now section 105.
rationale: Yates is cited as part of a string of cases supporting the proposition that mere advocacy of abstract doctrine is not sufficient for criminal sanction. The Acting Decision applies Yates' reasoning without criticizing or limiting it.

cited_decision: Cramp v. Board of Public Instruction of Orange Cty. (1961)
quote: The regulatory maze created by New York is wholly lacking in 'terms susceptible of objective measurement.' Cramp v. Board of Public Instruction, supra, at 286. It has the quality of 'extraordinary ambiguity' found to be fatal to the oaths considered in Cramp and Baggett v. Bullitt. '[M]en of common intelligence must necessarily guess at its meaning and differ as to its application . . . .' Baggett v. Bullitt, supra, at 367.
rationale: Cramp is cited as precedent for the unconstitutionality of vague statutes, particularly loyalty oaths. The Acting Decision applies Cramp's reasoning without criticizing or limiting it.

quote: The federal habeas corpus statute does not require this result, and Parker v. Ellis must be overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Parker v. Ellis is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value.

quote: Thereafter, complex proceedings took place in which petitioner sought in both federal and state courts to obtain relief by writ of habeas corpus, based on his claim that illegally seized evidence was used against him. 334 F. 2d 331 (1964); petition for writ of certiorari denied, 381 U. S. 951 (1965).
rationale: The Acting Decision references this case as part of the procedural history without discussing or analyzing its reasoning or outcome.

quote: We granted the petition, 389 U. S. 896 (1967), to consider whether, because of facts to which we later refer, the Court of Appeals’ dismissal conformed to our holding in Nowakowski v. Maroney, 386 U. S. 542 (1967).
rationale: Nowakowski is cited as controlling precedent for the procedural requirements in habeas appeals, but the Acting Decision applies its holding without criticizing, limiting, or otherwise altering its authority.

quote: Because of these “disabilities or burdens [which] may flow from” petitioner’s conviction, he has “a substantial stake in the judgment of conviction which survives the satisfaction of the sentence imposed on him.” Fiswick v. United States, 329 U. S. 211, 222 (1946).
rationale: Fiswick is cited to support the proposition regarding collateral consequences of conviction, but its reasoning is neither questioned nor altered.

cited_decision: Nathan Thomas v. W. K. Cunningham, Jr., Superintendent of the Virginia State Penitentiary (1964)
quote: See Thomas v. Cunningham, 335 F. 2d 67 (C. A. 4th Cir. 1964).
rationale: The Acting Decision references this case in a footnote without discussion or analysis, indicating a mere mention.

quote: Cf. Eskridge v. Washington Prison Board, 357 U. S. 214 (1958); see also Linkletter v. Walker, 381 U. S. 618, 628 , n. 13 and 639, n. 20 (1965); Tehan v. Shott, 382 U. S. 406, 416 (1966).
rationale: Linkletter is cited as an example in a string citation, with no discussion or analysis of its reasoning.

quote: On direct appeal (following Mapp v. Ohio, 367 U. S. 643 (1961)), petitioner claimed that illegally obtained evidence had been introduced against him at trial.
rationale: Mapp v. Ohio is referenced as background for the petitioner's legal argument, not for its reasoning or holding.

quote: On account of these “collateral consequences,” 8 the case is *238 not moot. Ginsberg v. New York, 390 U. S. 629, 633-634, n. 2 (1968); Fiswick v. United States, supra, at 222, n. 10; United States v. Morgan, 346 U. S. 502, 512-513 (1954).
rationale: Ginsberg is cited as supporting authority for the proposition about collateral consequences, without further discussion.

quote: If there has been, or will be, an unconditional release from custody before inquiry can be made into the legality of detention, it has been held that there is no habeas corpus jurisdiction. See *239 Parker v. Ellis, supra, at 582, n. 8 (WARREN, C. J., dissenting); Ex parte Baez, 177 U. S. 378 (1900); United States ex rel. Rivera v. Reeves, 246 F. Supp. 599 (D. C. S. D. N. Y. 1965); Burnett v. Gladden, 228 F. Supp. 527 (D. C. D. Ore. 1964).
rationale: Ex Parte Baez is cited as an example of prior authority on habeas jurisdiction, but the Acting Decision does not discuss or alter its reasoning.

cited_decision: United States Ex Rel. Rivera v. Reeves (1965)
quote: See *239 Parker v. Ellis, supra, at 582, n. 8 (WARREN, C. J., dissenting); Ex parte Baez, 177 U. S. 378 (1900); United States ex rel. Rivera v. Reeves, 246 F. Supp. 599 (D. C. S. D. N. Y. 1965); Burnett v. Gladden, 228 F. Supp. 527 (D. C. D. Ore. 1964).
rationale: This case is cited in a string citation as background authority, with no discussion or analysis.

quote: On account of these “collateral consequences,” 8 the case is *238 not moot. Ginsberg v. New York, 390 U. S. 629, 633-634, n. 2 (1968); Fiswick v. United States, supra, at 222, n. 10; United States v. Morgan, 346 U. S. 502, 512-513 (1954).
rationale: United States v. Morgan is cited as supporting authority for the collateral consequences doctrine, without further discussion.

quote: See Peyton v. Rowe, supra; Walker v. Wainwright, 390 U. S. 335 (1968). Cf. Ex parte Hull, 312 U. S. 546 (1941).
rationale: Walker v. Wainwright is cited as supporting authority for the breadth of habeas relief, with no further discussion.

cited_decision: Eskridge v. Washington State Board of Prison Terms & Paroles (1958)
quote: Cf. Eskridge v. Washington Prison Board, 357 U. S. 214 (1958); see also Linkletter v. Walker, 381 U. S. 618, 628 , n. 13 and 639, n. 20 (1965); Tehan v. Shott, 382 U. S. 406, 416 (1966).
rationale: Eskridge is cited in a string citation as a comparative authority, with no discussion or analysis.

quote: Cf. Ex parte Hull, 312 U. S. 546 (1941).
rationale: Ex Parte Hull is cited as a comparative authority in a string citation, with no discussion or analysis.

quote: We think that neither Shapiro nor the cases upon which it relied are applicable here. ... Each of the three principal elements of the doctrine, as it is described in Shapiro, is absent from this situation.
rationale: The Acting Decision explains that the facts and legal context of Shapiro are materially different from those in Marchetti, and explicitly states that Shapiro does not apply, thus distinguishing it.

quote: We conclude that nothing in the Court’s opinions in Kahriger and Lewis now suffices to preclude petitioner’s assertion of the constitutional privilege as a defense to the indictments under which he was convicted. To this extent Kahriger and Lewis are overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Kahriger is overruled to the extent it previously prevented assertion of the Fifth Amendment privilege in this context.

quote: The Court in Sullivan was evidently concerned, first, that the claim before it was an unwarranted extension of the scope of the privilege, and, second, that to accept a claim of privilege not asserted at the time the return was due would 'make the taxpayer rather than a tribunal the final arbiter of the merits of the claim.' ... The first is, as we have indicated, inapplicable, and we find the second unpersuasive in this situation.
rationale: The Acting Decision analyzes Sullivan and finds its reasoning inapplicable to the facts at hand, thus distinguishing it.

quote: We find this reasoning no longer persuasive. ... We conclude that nothing in the Court’s opinions in Kahriger and Lewis now suffices to preclude petitioner’s assertion of the constitutional privilege as a defense to the indictments under which he was convicted. To this extent Kahriger and Lewis are overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly overrules Lewis to the extent it previously denied the Fifth Amendment privilege in this context.

cited_decision: Albertson v. Subversive Activities Control Board
quote: Every aspect of petitioner’s wagering activities thus subjected him to possible state or federal prosecution. By any standard, in Connecticut and throughout the United States, wagering is 'an area permeated with criminal statutes,' and those engaged in wagering are a group 'inherently suspect of criminal activities.' Albertson v. SACB, 382 U. S. 70, 79.
