rationale: Albertson is cited for a general principle about groups 'inherently suspect of criminal activities,' but is not analyzed or applied to the facts, so it is merely mentioned.

cited_decision: Murphy v. Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor
quote: It is suggested that these restrictions might be similar to those imposed by the Court in Murphy v. Waterfront Commission, 378 U. S. 52. ... Nonetheless, we think that it would be entirely inappropriate in the circumstances here for the Court to impose such restrictions.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Murphy and explains why its approach is not appropriate in the present case, thus distinguishing it.

quote: Only last Term we found that the right to trial by jury in criminal cases was 'fundamental to the American scheme of justice,' Duncan v. Louisiana, 391 U. S. 145, 149 (1968), and held that the Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial was applicable to the States through the Fourteenth Amendment.
rationale: Duncan v. Louisiana is cited as an example of the Court's recent approach to incorporation of Bill of Rights guarantees, but its reasoning or holding is not criticized, overruled, or otherwise altered. It is referenced to support the Court's reasoning.

quote: Insofar as it is inconsistent with this holding, Palko v. Connecticut is overruled. Palko represented an approach to basic constitutional rights which this Court’s recent decisions have rejected.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Palko v. Connecticut is overruled to the extent it is inconsistent with the new holding that the Double Jeopardy Clause applies to the States.

quote: In any case, this argument was answered here over 70 years ago in United States v. Ball, 163 U. S. 662 (1896). ... The Court refused to allow the Government to allege its own error to deprive the defendant of the benefit of an acquittal by a jury. Id., at 667-668.
rationale: United States v. Ball is cited as precedent supporting the Acting Decision's reasoning, but its holding is not questioned, criticized, or otherwise altered.

quote: In Sibron v. New York, 392 U. S. 40 (1968), we held that a criminal case did not become moot upon the expiration of the sentence imposed. We noted 'the obvious fact of life that most criminal convictions do in fact entail adverse collateral legal consequences.' Id., at 55.
rationale: Sibron v. New York is cited as authority for the proposition that collateral consequences prevent mootness, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: Malloy v. Hogan, 378 U. S. 1, 10-11 (1964), 12 Only last Term we found that the right to trial by jury in criminal cases was 'fundamental to the American scheme of justice,' Duncan v. Louisiana, 391 U. S. 145, 149 (1968), and held that the Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial was applicable to the States through the Fourteenth Amendment. 13 For the same reasons, we today find that the double jeopardy prohibition of the Fifth Amendment represents a fundamental ideal in our constitutional heritage, and that it should apply to the States through the Fourteenth Amendment.
rationale: Malloy v. Hogan is cited as part of the Court's trend toward incorporating Bill of Rights protections against the States, but its reasoning or holding is not criticized, limited, or otherwise altered.

quote: Keeping these purposes of the writ in mind, we turn to consideration of the McNally holding and the reasons which compel us to overrule it. ... We overrule McNally and hold that a prisoner serving consecutive sentences is 'in custody' under any one of them for purposes of § 2241 (c)(3).
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that it is overruling McNally v. Hill, both in reasoning and in holding, thereby expressly nullifying its precedential value.

quote: What we said of the writ in a similar context in Jones v. Cunningham, 371 U. S. 236 (1963), is equally applicable here. '[The writ] is not now and never has been a static, narrow, formalistic remedy; its scope has grown to achieve its grand purpose — the protection of individuals against erosion of their right to be free from wrongful restraints upon their liberty.' Id., at 243.
rationale: Jones v. Cunningham is cited for its general statement about the evolving scope of habeas corpus, and the Acting Decision applies its reasoning but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: To that extent, it also undermines Moore v. Dempsey, supra, and is inconsistent with subsequent decisions of this Court which have reaffirmed Moore. E. g., Johnson v. Zerbst, 304 U. S. 458 (1938); Brown v. Allen, 344 U. S. 443 (1953); Fay v. Noia, 372 U. S. 391 (1963).
rationale: Moore v. Dempsey is referenced as a precedent that the overruled McNally decision was inconsistent with, but the Acting Decision does not criticize or limit Moore; rather, it treats it as good law and supportive authority.

quote: To that extent, it also undermines Moore v. Dempsey, supra, and is inconsistent with subsequent decisions of this Court which have reaffirmed Moore. E. g., Johnson v. Zerbst, 304 U. S. 458 (1938); Brown v. Allen, 344 U. S. 443 (1953); Fay v. Noia, 372 U. S. 391 (1963). ... Calendar congestion, considerations of federalism, see, e. g., Fay v. Noia, 372 U. S., at 415-420 ; Ex parte Royall, 117 U. S. 241 (1886), and the exigencies of appellate review account for largely unavoidable delays in the processing of criminal cases.
rationale: Fay v. Noia is cited as a reaffirmation of Moore and for its discussion of federalism and habeas corpus, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: "Reynolds v. Sims, 377 U. S. 533 , held that a State in an apportionment of state representatives and senators among districts and counties could not deprive voters in *818 the more populous counties of their proportionate share of representatives and senators. 'The right to vote freely for the candidate of one’s choice is of the essence of a democratic society, and any restrictions on that right strike at the heart of representative government. And the right of suffrage can be denied by a debasement or dilution of the weight of a citizen’s vote just as effectively as by wholly prohibiting the free exercise of the franchise.' 377 U. S., at 555."
rationale: Reynolds v. Sims is cited for its general principles regarding equal protection and voting rights, but the Acting Decision does not alter, criticize, or distinguish its holding; it simply applies its reasoning.

quote: "We have said enough to indicate why MacDougall v. Green is out of line with our recent apportionment cases... MacDougall v. Green is overruled. 7 Reversed."
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that MacDougall v. Green is 'overruled,' directly nullifying its precedential value.

quote: "Dusch v. Davis, 387 U. S. 112 , is not relevant to the problem of this case. There each councilman was required to be a resident of the borough from which he was elected. Like the residence requirement for state senators from a multi-district county (Fortson v. Dorsey, 379 U. S. 433 ), the place of residence did not mark the voting unit; for in Dusch all the electors in the city voted for each councilman."
rationale: The Acting Decision explains why Dusch v. Davis does not apply to the present facts, distinguishing it based on the differences in the electoral systems at issue.

quote: "While the majority cited Colegrove v. Green, 328 U. S. 549 , as their authority for denying relief and while a few who took part in Colegrove put this type of question in the 'political' as distinguished from the 'justiciable' category, 328 U. S., at 552 , that matter was authoritatively resolved in Baker v. Carr, 369 U. S. 186, 202 ."
rationale: The Acting Decision questions the continuing validity of Colegrove v. Green by noting that its justiciability holding has been superseded by Baker v. Carr.

quote: "that matter was authoritatively resolved in Baker v. Carr, 369 U. S. 186, 202 . When a State makes classifications of voters which favor residents of some counties over residents of other counties, a justiciable controversy is presented. 369 U. S., at 198-204 ."
rationale: Baker v. Carr is cited as establishing the justiciability of equal protection claims in voting cases, but the Acting Decision does not alter or criticize its holding.

quote: But Whitney has been thoroughly discredited by later decisions. See Dennis v. United States, 341 U. S. 494, at 507 (1951). These later decisions have fashioned the principle that the constitutional guarantees of free speech and free press do not permit a State to forbid or proscribe advocacy of the use of force or of law violation except where such advocacy is directed to inciting or producing imminent lawless action and is likely to incite or produce such action.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Dennis as part of a line of cases that have moved away from the reasoning in Whitney, but also criticizes Dennis for distorting the 'clear and present danger' test. The concurrence is even more explicit in its criticism, stating, 'But in Dennis v. United States, 341 U. S. 494, we opened wide the door, distorting the “clear and present danger” test beyond recognition.' Thus, Dennis is criticized but not overruled.

quote: As we *448 said in Noto v. United States, 367 U. S. 290, 297-298 (1961), 'the mere abstract teaching ... of the moral propriety or even moral necessity for a resort to force and violence, is not the same as preparing a group for violent action and steeling it to such action.' See also Herndon v. Lowry, 301 U. S. 242, 259-261 (1937); Bond v. Floyd, 385 U. S. 116, 134 (1966).
rationale: Herndon v. Lowry is cited as supporting authority for the distinction between abstract advocacy and incitement, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise limit it. It is simply mentioned as precedent consistent with the new rule.

quote: Cf. Yates v. United States, 354 U. S. 298 (1957); De Jonge v. Oregon, 299 U. S. 353 (1937); Stromberg v. California, 283 U. S. 359 (1931).
rationale: Yates is cited as part of a string of cases supporting the principle that mere advocacy is protected unless it incites imminent lawless action. There is no criticism or limitation; it is mentioned as consistent authority.

quote: Frohwerk v. United States, 249 U. S. 204 , also authored by Mr. Justice Holmes, involved prosecution and punishment for publication of articles very critical of the war effort in World War I. Schenck was referred to as a conviction for obstructing security 'by words of persuasion.' Id., at 206. And the conviction in Frohwerk was sustained because 'the circulation of the paper was *451 in quarters where a little breath would be enough to kindle a flame.' Id., at 209.
rationale: Frohwerk is discussed in the concurrence as part of the historical development of the 'clear and present danger' test, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or limit it. It is mentioned for historical context.

quote: Debs v. United States, 249 U. S. 211 , was the third of the trilogy of the 1918 Term. Debs was convicted of speaking in opposition to the war where his 'opposition was so expressed that its natural and intended effect would be to obstruct recruiting.' Id., at 215.
rationale: Debs is mentioned in the concurrence as part of the historical background of First Amendment jurisprudence. There is no indication that the Acting Decision criticizes, overrules, or limits Debs.

quote: The contrary teaching of Whitney v. California, supra, cannot be supported, and that decision is therefore overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Whitney v. California is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value.

quote: It is time, for the reasons we have stated, to hold that on their own facts, and insofar as the principles they stand for are inconsistent with those that we have endorsed today, they are no longer to be followed.
rationale: The lead opinion expressly states that Rabinowitz is no longer to be followed, overruling it both on its facts and as a precedent inconsistent with the new rule announced in Chimel.

quote: Decisions of this Court since Rabinowitz have applied the abstract doctrine of that case to various factual situations with divergent results. Compare Ker v. California, 374 U. S. 23, 42 ...
rationale: Ker v. California is referenced as an example of a case applying the Rabinowitz doctrine, but there is no discussion of its reasoning or validity; it is simply mentioned in passing.

quote: Compare Ker v. California, 374 U. S. 23, 42 ; Abel v. United States, 362 U. S. 217 ; and Draper v. United States, 358 U. S. 307 , with Kremen v. United States, 353 U. S. 346 (per curiam).
rationale: Abel v. United States is listed among other cases for comparative purposes, without any analysis or criticism of its holding or reasoning.

quote: Approval of a warrantless search incident to a lawful arrest seems first to have been articulated by the Court in 1914 as dictum in Weeks v. United States, 232 U. S. 383 , in which the Court stated: ...
rationale: Weeks is discussed as historical background for the development of the search-incident-to-arrest doctrine, but its reasoning is neither criticized nor overruled.

quote: Only a year after Harris , however, the pendulum swung again. In Trupiano v. United States, 334 U. S. 699 , ... The opinion stated: 'It is a cardinal rule that, in seizing goods and articles, law enforcement agents must secure and use search warrants wherever reasonably practicable.'
rationale: Trupiano is described as part of the historical development of the doctrine, but the Acting Decision does not criticize or overrule it; it is used to illustrate the shifting standards.

quote: That the Marron opinion did not mean all that it seemed to say became evident, however, a few years later in Go-Bart Importing Co. v. United States, 282 U. S. 344 , and United States v. Lefkowitz, 285 U. S. 452 . ... This limited characterization of Marron was reiterated in Lefkowitz ...
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly notes that Marron's broad language was later limited by subsequent cases, and it adopts this narrower interpretation, thus limiting Marron's scope.

cited_decision: Go-Bart Importing Co. v. United States
quote: This limited characterization of Marron was reiterated in Lefkowitz , a case in which the Court held unlawful a search of desk drawers and a cabinet despite the fact that the search had accompanied a lawful arrest.
rationale: Go-Bart is referenced as part of the historical narrative and as a limiting case on Marron, but the Acting Decision does not criticize or overrule it.

quote: Only last Term in Terry v. Ohio, 392 U. S. 1 , we emphasized that 'the police must, whenever practicable, obtain advance judicial approval of searches and seizures through the warrant procedure,' id., at 20 , ...
rationale: Terry is cited to support the general principle of warrant preference, but its reasoning is not criticized or distinguished; it is used as supporting authority.

quote: Eleven years later the case of Carroll v. United States, 267 U. S. 132 , brought the following embellishment of the Weeks statement: ...
rationale: Carroll is referenced as part of the historical development of the doctrine, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or overrule it.

quote: It is time, for the reasons we have stated, to hold that on their own facts, and insofar as the principles they stand for are inconsistent with those that we have endorsed today, they are no longer to be followed.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Harris, like Rabinowitz, is no longer to be followed, thereby overruling it.

quote: As its text reveals, the Thirteenth Amendment 'is not a mere prohibition of State laws establishing or upholding slavery, but an absolute declaration that slavery or involuntary servitude shall not exist in any part of the United States.' Civil Rights Cases, 109 U. S. 3, 20. It has never been doubted, therefore, 'that the power vested in Congress to enforce the article by appropriate legislation,' ibid., includes the power to enact laws 'direct and primary, operating upon the acts of individuals, whether sanctioned by State legislation or not.' Id., at 23.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites the Civil Rights Cases for general principles about the Thirteenth Amendment and congressional power, but distinguishes its holding by emphasizing that the present case involves a different statute and context. The Court uses the Civil Rights Cases to support its reasoning but does not treat it as controlling or limiting precedent.

quote: This Court last had occasion to consider the scope of 42 U. S. C. § 1982 in 1948, in Hurd v. Hodge, 334 U. S. 24 . ... It is true that a dictum in Hurd said that § 1982 was directed only toward 'governmental action,' 334 U. S., at 31 , but neither Hurd nor any other case *420 before or since has presented that precise issue for adjudication in this Court. 25 Today we face that issue for the first time.
rationale: The Acting Decision acknowledges Hurd v. Hodge as precedent but distinguishes it by noting that Hurd did not address the precise issue now before the Court—whether § 1982 applies to purely private discrimination. The Court explicitly states that it is deciding this issue for the first time.

quote: The conclusion of the majority in Hodges rested upon a concept of congressional power under the Thirteenth Amendment irrecon *443 cilable with the position taken by every member of this Court in the Civil Rights Cases and incompatible with the history and purpose of the Amendment itself. Insofar as Hodges is inconsistent with our holding today, it is hereby overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly overrules Hodges v. United States to the extent it is inconsistent with the present holding, thereby nullifying its precedential value on the relevant point.

quote: It is true that a dictum in Hurd v. Hodge, 334 U. S. 24, 31 , characterized Corrigan v. Buckley, 271 U. S. 323 , as having 'held' that '[t]he action toward which the provisions of the statute . . . [are] directed is governmental action.' 334 U. S., at 31. But no such statement appears in the Corrigan opinion, and a careful examination of Corrigan reveals that it cannot be read as authority for the proposition attributed to it in Hurd.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Corrigan v. Buckley, clarifying that Corrigan did not decide the issue at hand and cannot be read as authority for limiting § 1982 to governmental action. The Court thus limits Corrigan's relevance to the present case.

quote: Two of this Court’s early opinions contain dicta to the general effect that § 1982 is limited to state action. Virginia v. Rives, 100 U. S. 313, 317-318 ... But all that Virginia v. Rives, supra, actually held was that § 641 of the Revised Statutes of 1874 (derived from § 3 of the Civil Rights Act of 1866 and currently embodied in 28 U. S. C. § 1443 (1)) did not authorize the removal of a state prosecution where the defendants, without pointing to any statute discriminating against Negroes, could only assert that a denial of their rights might take place and might go uncorrected at trial. 100 U. S., at 319-322.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Virginia v. Rives, explaining that its holding was limited to a different statutory provision and did not decide the issue of whether § 1982 applies to private action. The Court clarifies the limited scope of Rives and declines to treat it as controlling.

quote: The judgment of the Supreme Court of California is vacated and the case is remanded to that court for further proceedings not inconsistent with this opinion.
rationale: The Acting Decision vacates and remands the judgment of the California Supreme Court in Adkins v. Lear, Inc., thereby reversing its holding regarding licensee estoppel and the enforceability of the royalty contract.

cited_decision: Compco Corp. v. Day-Brite Lighting, Inc. (1964)
quote: We granted certiorari in the present case, 391 U. S. 912 , to reconsider the validity of the Hazeltine rule in the light of our recent decisions emphasizing the strong federal policy favoring free competition in ideas which do not merit patent protection. Sears, Roebuck v. Stiffel Co., 376 U. S. 225 (1964); Compco Corp. v. Day-Brite Lighting, Inc., 376 U. S. 234 (1964).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Compco as part of the background of federal policy but does not analyze, criticize, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

cited_decision: Automatic Radio Manufacturing Co. v. Hazeltine Research, Inc. (1950)
quote: We are satisfied that Automatic Radio Manufacturing Co. v. Hazeltine Research, Inc., supra, itself the product of a clouded history, should no longer be regarded as sound law with respect to its 'estoppel' holding, and that holding is now overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly overrules the estoppel holding of Hazeltine, nullifying its precedential value on that point.

cited_decision: Sears, Roebuck & Co. v. Stiffel Co. (1964)
quote: We granted certiorari in the present case, 391 U. S. 912 , to reconsider the validity of the Hazeltine rule in the light of our recent decisions emphasizing the strong federal policy favoring free competition in ideas which do not merit patent protection. Sears, Roebuck v. Stiffel Co., supra; Compco Corp. v. Day-Brite Lighting, Inc., supra.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Sears, Roebuck as background for federal patent policy but does not analyze or alter its holding.

cited_decision: Westinghouse Electric & Manufacturing Co. v. Formica Insulation Co. (1924)
quote: Westinghouse Electric & Manufacturing Co. v. Formica Insulation Co., 266 U. S. 342 (1924), framed a rule to govern the recurring problem which arises when the original patent owner, after assigning his patent to another for a substantial sum, claims that the patent is worthless because it contains no new ideas. ... Nevertheless, Formica imposed a limitation upon estoppel which was radically inconsistent with the premises upon which the 'general rule' is based.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Formica as a limitation on the estoppel doctrine and acknowledges its narrowing effect, but does not overrule or criticize it; rather, it recognizes its limited scope.

cited_decision: Scott Paper Co. v. Marcalus Manufacturing Co. (1945)
quote: In Scott Paper Co. v. Marcalus Manufacturing Co., 326 U. S. 249 (1945), this Court adopted a position similar to the Seventh Circuit’s, undermining the basis of patent estoppel even more than Formica had done.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Scott Paper as part of the historical development of the law but does not criticize, distinguish, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: In McGoldrick v. Compagnie Generale Transatlantique, 309 U. S. 430 (1940), the Court, while recognizing it had jurisdiction to determine whether a New York tax was an unconstitutional burden on interstate commerce, refused to consider whether the tax was a prohibited impost or duty on imports and exports, saying: '[I]t is only in exceptional cases, and then only in cases coming from the federal courts, that [the Court] considers questions urged by a petitioner or appellant not pressed or passed upon in the courts below. ...'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites McGoldrick for a procedural principle regarding Supreme Court review, not for its substantive holding.

quote: Wilson v. Cook, 327 U. S. 474 (1946), reached a similar conclusion. There the Court denied a government contractor the benefit of the implied constitutional immunity of the Federal Government from taxation by the State, but at the same time declined to consider whether the state tax at issue placed a forbidden tax directly on the United States.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Wilson v. Cook for its approach to issues not raised or decided below, not for its substantive law.

quote: Such a distinction may be valid, and pre-1960 royalties recoverable; but if so, what of post-1960 royalties which are attributable to the headstart Lear obtained over the rest of the industry as a result of pre-issuance disclosure of Adkins’ idea? Today’s bar to collection of post-1960 royalties would seem to be inflexible, and yet those royalties arguably are recoverable to the extent they represent payment for the pre-1960 disclosure of Adkins’ idea; to that extent, they seem indistinguishable from pre-1960 royalties, at least for purposes of federal patent law. Cf. Brulotte v. Thys Co., 379 U. S. 29, 31 (1964).
rationale: Brulotte is cited in a concurring opinion as a comparative reference, but the Acting Decision does not analyze, criticize, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: Having concluded that Sinclair was erroneously decided and that subsequent events have undermined its continuing validity, we overrule that decision and reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals.
rationale: The lead opinion explicitly states that Sinclair was 'erroneously decided' and is 'overruled,' making this a clear instance of the Acting Decision expressly nullifying the precedential value of the cited decision.

cited_decision: Textile Workers v. Lincoln Mills of Ala. (1957)
quote: Lincoln Mills held generally that 'the substantive law to apply in suits under § 301 (a) is federal law, which the courts must fashion from the policy of our national labor laws,' 353 U. S., at 456, and more specifically that a union can obtain specific performance of an employer’s promise to arbitrate grievances.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Lincoln Mills to explain the development of federal labor law and arbitration policy, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its holding; it is used as background and support.

cited_decision: Avco Corp. v. Aero Lodge No. 735, International Ass'n of MacHinists & Aerospace Workers (1968)
quote: Furthermore, in light of developments subsequent to Sinclair, in particular our decision in Avco Corp. v. Aero Lodge 735, 390 U. S. 557 (1968), it has become clear that the Sinclair decision does not further but rather frustrates realization of an important goal of our national labor policy. Nor can we agree that conclusive weight should be accorded to the failure of Congress to respond to Sinclair on the theory that congressional silence should be interpreted as acceptance of the decision.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Avco as a development that, when combined with Sinclair, creates an 'anomalous situation,' but does not overrule, criticize, or question Avco; instead, it distinguishes the effects and implications of Avco from those of Sinclair.

quote: We fully recognize that important policy considerations militate in favor of continuity and predictability in the law. Nevertheless, as Mr. Justice Frankfurter wrote for the Court, '[S]tare decisis is a principle of policy and not a mechanical formula of adherence to the latest decision, however recent and questionable, when such adherence involves collision with a prior doctrine more embracing in its scope, intrinsically sounder, and verified by experience.' Helvering v. Hallock, 309 U. S. 106, 119 (1940).
rationale: Helvering v. Hallock is cited for a general principle about stare decisis and not for its holding or reasoning on the merits; it is used illustratively and not substantively discussed.

quote: Similar double jeopardy issues did not fully claim the Court’s attention until the Court heard argument in Green v. United States, 355 U. S. 184 (1957). ... The rationale of the Green holding applies here.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses and applies the reasoning of Green v. United States as controlling precedent, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority. It is cited as the basis for the Court's holding.

quote: The Georgia Court of Appeals then heard the appeal and affirmed the second conviction, rejecting petitioner’s argument, among others, that his retrial for murder constituted double jeopardy. ... We granted the writ, 395 U. S. 975 (1969), and now reverse.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly overturns the outcome of Price v. State (1968) by reversing the conviction affirmed in that decision.

quote: While the Brantley holding may have had some vitality at the time the Georgia courts rendered their decisions in this case, it is no longer a viable authority and must now be deemed to have been overruled by subsequent decisions of this Court.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Brantley is no longer viable and has been overruled by subsequent Supreme Court decisions.

quote: In United States v. Ball, 163 U. S. 662, 669 (1896), this Court observed: ... The 'twice put in jeopardy' language of the Constitution thus relates to a potential, i. e., the risk that an accused for a second time will be convicted of the 'same offense' for which he was initially tried.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Ball for foundational principles regarding double jeopardy, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: Petitioner sought direct review of his second conviction in the Supreme Court of Georgia, 1 but that court transferred the case to the Court of Appeals of Georgia, declaring that '[o]nly questions as to the application of plain and unambiguous provisions of the Constitution of the United States being involved, . . the case is one for the consideration of the Court of Appeals . . . Price v. State, 224 Ga. 306, 307 , 161 S. E. 2d 825, 826 (1968).'
rationale: The Acting Decision merely recounts the procedural history and transfer of the case by the Georgia Supreme Court, without discussing or altering its authority.

cited_decision: United States ex rel. Hetenyi v. Wilkins (1965)
quote: He relied on Green v. United States, 355 U. S. 184 (1957), and *326 United States ex rel. Hetenyi v. Wilkins, 348 F., 2d 844 (C. A. 2d Cir. 1965), cert. denied, 383 U. S. 913 (1966). His contention was rejected. ... See United States ex rel. Hetenyi v. *332 Wilkins, 348 F. 2d 844 (C. A. 2d Cir. 1965), cert. denied, 383 U. S. 913 (1966).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Hetenyi v. Wilkins as part of the petitioner's argument and for illustrative purposes, but does not discuss, criticize, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: As the District Court and the Court of Appeals correctly noted, the operative facts here are virtually identical to those of Hoag v. New Jersey, supra. ... The doctrine of Benton v. Maryland, 395 U. S. 784, puts the issues in the present case in a perspective quite different from that in which the issues were perceived in Hoag v. New Jersey, supra. ... We do not hesitate to hold that it [collateral estoppel] is [embodied in the Fifth Amendment guarantee against double jeopardy].
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly rejects the reasoning and holding of Hoag v. New Jersey by applying a new constitutional rule (collateral estoppel as part of double jeopardy) to facts virtually identical to Hoag, thus overruling Hoag's contrary result and rationale.

quote: Abbate v. United States, 359 U. S. 187, 196-201 (1959) (separate opinion). My conclusion is not precluded by the Courts decision in Hoag v. New Jersey, 356 U. S. 464 (1958), although the basic fact situation there was identical to that in this case.
rationale: Abbate v. United States is cited in a parenthetical as a reference to a separate opinion and for historical context, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes, distinguishes, nor overrules it, nor does it engage in substantive discussion of its holding.

quote: There can be no doubt of the 'retroactivity' of the Court’s decision in Benton v. Maryland. In North Carolina v. Pearce, 395 U. S. 711, decided the same day as Benton, the Court unanimously accorded fully 'retroactive' effect to the Benton doctrine.
rationale: North Carolina v. Pearce is cited solely for its holding on the retroactivity of Benton v. Maryland, without any criticism, limitation, or substantive engagement with its reasoning.

quote: In Benton v. Maryland, 395 U. S. 784, the Court held that the Fifth Amendment guarantee against double jeopardy is enforceable against the States through the Fourteenth Amendment.
rationale: Benton v. Maryland is cited as controlling precedent and foundational to the Acting Decision’s analysis, but its reasoning is not questioned, criticized, or limited; it is treated as authoritative and applied.

quote: For whatever else that constitutional guarantee may embrace, North Carolina v. Pearce, 395 U. S. 711, 717, it surely protects a man who has been acquitted from having to 'run the gantlet' a second time. Green v. United States, 355 U. S. 184, 190.
rationale: Green v. United States is quoted for a phrase and cited as support for the general principle of double jeopardy, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, distinguish, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

quote: We can no longer adhere to the aberrational doctrine of Kesler and Reitz that state law may frustrate the operation of federal law as long as the state legislature in passing its law had some purpose in mind other than one of frustration. ... Thus, we conclude that Kesler and Reitz can have no authoritative effect to the extent they are inconsistent with the controlling principle that any state legislation which frustrates the full effectiveness of federal law is rendered invalid by the Supremacy Clause.
rationale: The lead opinion expressly states that the Court can no longer adhere to the doctrine of Reitz and removes its authoritative effect, thereby overruling it to the extent of its inconsistency with the Supremacy Clause analysis adopted in Perez.

quote: In Schecter v. Killingsworth, 93 Ariz. 273, 380 P. 2d 136 (1963), the Supreme Court of Arizona held that '[t]he Financial Responsibility Act has for its principal purpose the protection of the public using the highways from financial hardship which may result from the use of automobiles by financially irresponsible persons.' 93 Ariz., at 280, 380 P. 2d, at 140.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Schecter v. Killingsworth solely to describe the Arizona Supreme Court's interpretation of the purpose of the statute at issue; it does not criticize, question, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

cited_decision: Adolfo Perez and Emma Perez, Husband and Wife, and Emma Perez for Her Separate Self v. David H. Campbell, Superintendent, Motor Vehicle Division, Arizona Highwaydept., Etc.
quote: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed and the case is remanded for further proceedings consistent with this opinion. It is so ordered.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly reverses the judgment of the Court of Appeals in this case.

cited_decision: Kesler v. Department of Public Safety of Utah (1962)
quote: We can no longer adhere to the aberrational doctrine of Kesler and Reitz that state law may frustrate the operation of federal law as long as the state legislature in passing its law had some purpose in mind other than one of frustration. ... Thus, we conclude that Kesler and Reitz can have no authoritative effect to the extent they are inconsistent with the controlling principle that any state legislation which frustrates the full effectiveness of federal law is rendered invalid by the Supremacy Clause.
rationale: The lead opinion expressly states that Kesler is no longer authoritative and is overruled to the extent it conflicts with the new Supremacy Clause analysis.

quote: There can be no doubt, given Lewis v. Roberts, 267 U. S. 467 (1925), that Congress intended this 'new opportunity' to include freedom from most kinds of pre-existing tort judgments.
rationale: Lewis v. Roberts is cited as supporting authority for the interpretation of the Bankruptcy Act, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes nor alters its precedential value.

quote: In view of these developments since Ahrens v. Clark , we can no longer view that decision as establishing an *500 inflexible jurisdictional rule, dictating the choice of an inconvenient forum even in a class of cases which could not have been foreseen at the time of our decision.
rationale: The lead opinion explicitly states that the Court can no longer follow Ahrens as an inflexible jurisdictional rule, and the dissent directly accuses the majority of overruling Ahrens. The majority's reasoning and holding effectively overrule the prior precedent.

quote: In Smith v. Hooey, 393 U. S. 374 (1969), we considered a speedy trial claim similar to the one presented in the ease before us, and we held that a State which had lodged a detainer against a petitioner in another State must, on the prisoner’s demand, “make a diligent, good-faith effort” to bring the prisoner to trial. Id,., at 383. But that ease arose on direct review of the denial of relief by the state court, and we had no occasion to consider whether the same or similar claims could have been raised on federal habeas corpus.
rationale: Smith v. Hooey is referenced as precedent for the speedy trial right, but the Acting Decision does not alter, criticize, or limit its holding; it simply uses it as background for the present case.

quote: Yet it logically follows from Peyton v. Rowe, 391 U. S. 54 (1968), that the claims can be raised on collateral attack. In this context, as opposed to the situation presented in Peyton , the “future custody” under attack will not be imposed by the same sovereign which holds the petitioner in his current confinement. Nevertheless, the considerations which were held in Peyton to warrant a prompt resolution of the claim also apply with full force in this context.
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on Peyton v. Rowe to support its reasoning but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its holding. It extends Peyton's logic to a new context, but this is an application, not a limitation or criticism.

quote: It is also true, as our Brother Rehnquist points out in dissent, that federal habeas corpus does not lie, absent “special circumstances,” to adjudicate the merits of an affirmative defense to a state criminal charge prior to a judgment of conviction by a state court. Ex parte Royall, 117 U. S. 241, 253 (1886). Petitioner does not, however, seek at this time to litigate a federal defense to a criminal charge, but only *490 to demand enforcement of the Commonwealth’s affirmative constitutional obligation to bring him promptly to trial.
rationale: The Acting Decision acknowledges the general rule from Ex Parte Royall but distinguishes the present case on its facts and purpose, explaining why Royall does not bar relief here.

quote: Nor does petitioner challenge the “present effect being given the [Kentucky] detainer by the [Alabama] authorities . . . .” Nelson v. George, 399 U. S. 224, 225 (1970).
rationale: Nelson v. George is cited as a factual reference and for a procedural point, but the Acting Decision does not analyze, criticize, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: The constitutionality of § 1985 (3) might once have appeared to have been settled adversely by United States v. Harris, 106 U. S. 629 , and Baldwin v. Franks, 120 U. S. 678 , which held unconstitutional its criminal counterpart, then § 5519 of the Revised Statutes. 11 The Court in those cases, however, followed a severability rule that required invalidation of an entire statute if any part of it was unconstitutionally overbroad, unless its different parts could be read as wholly independent provisions. E. g., Baldwin v. Franks, supra, at 685 . This Court has long since firmly rejected that rule in such cases as United States v. Raines, 362 U. S. 17, 20-24 . Consequently, we need not find the language of § 1985 (3) now before us Constitutional in all its possible applications in order to uphold its facial constitutionality and its application to the complaint in this case.
rationale: The Acting Decision acknowledges Harris but limits its precedential value by explaining that the severability rule it relied on has since been rejected, and thus Harris does not control the outcome regarding the constitutionality of § 1985(3) as applied here.

quote: Our cases have firmly established that the right of interstate travel is constitutionally protected, does not necessarily rest on the Fourteenth Amendment, and is assertable against private as well as governmental interference. Shapiro v. Thompson, 394 U. S. 618, 629-631 ; id., at 642-644 (concurring opinion); United States *106 v. Guest, 383 U. S. 745 , 757-760 and n. 17; Twining v. New Jersey, 211 U. S. 78, 97 ; Slaughter-House Cases, 16 Wall. 36, 79-80 ; Crandall v. Nevada, 6 Wall. 35, 44, 48-49 ; Passenger Cases, 7 How. 283, 492 (Taney, . C. J., dissenting).
rationale: United States v. Guest is cited as supporting authority for the proposition that the right of interstate travel is constitutionally protected, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, distinguish, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

cited_decision: Jones v. Alfred H. Mayer Co.
quote: It has long been settled that 18 U. S. C. § 241 , a criminal statute of far broader phrasing (see n. 4, supra), reaches wholly private conspiracies and is constitutional. E. g., In re Quarles, 158 U. S. 532 ; Logan v. United States, 144 U. S. 263, 293-295 ; United States v. Waddell, 112 U. S. 76, 77-81 ; Ex parte Yarbrough, 110 U. S. 651 . See generally Twining v. New Jersey, 211 U. S. 78, 97-98 . Our inquiry, therefore, need go only to identifying a source of congressional power to reach the private conspiracy alleged by the complaint, in this case. . A Even as it struck down Rev. Stat. §5519 in United States v. Harris , the Court indicated that parts of its coverage would, if severable, be constitutional under the *105 Thirteenth Amendment. 106 U. S., at 640-641 . And surely there has never been any doubt of the power of Congress to impose liability on private persons under § 2 of that amendment, “for the amendment is not a mere prohibition of State laws .establishing or upholding slavery, but an absolute declaration that slavery or involuntary servitude shall not exist in any part of the United States.” Civil Rights Cases, 109 U. S. 3, 20 . See also id., at 23 ; Clyatt V. United States, 197 U. S. 207, 216, 218 ; Jones v. Alfred H. Mayer Co., 392 U. S., at 437-440 . Not only may Congress impose such liability, but the varieties of private conduct that it may make criminally punishable or civilly remediable extend far beyond the actual imposition of slavery or involuntary servitude. By the Thirteenth Amendment, we committed ourselves as a Nation to the proposition that the former slaves and their descendants should be forever free. To keep that promise, “Congress has the power under the Thirteenth Amendment rationally to determine what are the badges and the incidents of slavery, and the authority to translate that determination into effective legislation.” Jones v. Alfred H. Mayer Co., supra, at 440.
rationale: Jones v. Alfred H. Mayer Co. is cited as supporting authority for Congress's power under the Thirteenth Amendment, but the Acting Decision does not alter, criticize, or limit its holding.

quote: Our cases have firmly established that the right of interstate travel is constitutionally protected, does not necessarily rest on the Fourteenth Amendment, and is assertable against private as well as governmental interference. Shapiro v. Thompson, 394 U. S. 618, 629-631 ; id., at 642-644 (concurring opinion); United States *106 v. Guest, 383 U. S. 745 , 757-760 and n. 17; Twining v. New Jersey, 211 U. S. 78, 97 ; Slaughter-House Cases, 16 Wall. 36, 79-80 ; Crandall v. Nevada, 6 Wall. 35, 44, 48-49 ; Passenger Cases, 7 How. 283, 492 (Taney, . C. J., dissenting). The “right to pass freely from State to State” has been explicitly recognized as “among the rights and privileges of National citizenship.” Twining v. New Jersey, supra, at 97 .
rationale: Twining v. New Jersey is cited as supporting authority for the right of interstate travel as a privilege of national citizenship, but the Acting Decision does not otherwise discuss or alter its precedential value.

quote: Whether or not Collins v. Hardyman was correctly decided on its own facts is a question with which we need not here be concerned. But it is clear, in the light of *96 the evolution of decisional law in the years that have passed since that case was decided, that many of the constitutional problems there perceived simply do not exist. Little reason remains, therefore, not to accord to the words of the statute their apparent meaning. .That meaning is confirmed by judicial construction of related laws, by the structural setting of § 1985 (3) itself, and by its legislative history. And a fair reading of the allegations of the complaint in this case clearly brings them within this meaning of the statutory language. As so construed, and as applied to this complaint, we have no doubt that the statute was within the constitutional power of Congress to enact.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly rejects the restrictive construction of § 1985(3) adopted in Collins v. Hardyman, holding that the statute does reach private conspiracies and thus overrules Collins to the extent it held otherwise.

cited_decision: Carmichael v. Southern Coal & Coke Co.
quote: Thus, in Carmichael v. Southern Coal Co., 301 U. S. 495 , the Court, in sustaining an unemployment tax on employers, 6 said: “A state legislature, in the enactment of laws, has the widest possible latitude within the limits of the Constitution. In the nature of the case it cannot record a complete catalogue of, the considerations which move its members to enact laws. In the absence of such a record courts cannot assume that its action is capricious, or that, with its informed acquaintance with local conditions to which the legis *365 lation is to be applied, it was not aware of facts which afford reasonable basis for its action. Only by faithful adherence to this guiding principle of judicial review of legislation is it possible to preserve to the legislative branch its rightful independence and its ability to function.” Id., at 510 .
rationale: The Acting Decision quotes Carmichael v. Southern Coal & Coke Co. as support for the principle of legislative latitude in taxation, but does not criticize, distinguish, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

cited_decision: Lake Shore Auto Parts Co. v. Korzen
quote: As so construed, the Illinois Supreme Court held that the tax violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. Id., at 151 , 273 N. E. 2d, at 599 , one Justice dissenting. ... Reversed.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that it is reversing the judgment of the Illinois Supreme Court in Lake Shore Auto Parts Co. v. Korzen.

cited_decision: Madden v. Kentucky Ex Rel. Commissioner
quote: In Madden v. Kentucky, 309 U. S. 83 , a State laid an ad valorem tax of 50$ per $100 on deposits in banks outside the State and only 10(i per $1,000 on deposits within the State. The classification was sustained against the charge of invidious discrimination, the Court noting that “in taxation, even more than in other fields, legislatures possess the greatest freedom in classification.” Id., at 88 .
rationale: The Acting Decision references Madden v. Kentucky as precedent for legislative freedom in tax classification, but does not criticize, distinguish, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: Each of these dissenters thought Flint v. Stone Tracy Co., 220 U. S. 107 , should govern Quaker City Cab. The Flint case involved a federal tax upon the privilege of doing business in a corporate capacity, but it was not laid on businesses carried on by a partnership or private individual. ... But the Court in dictum stated: '[I]t could not be said, even if the principles of the Fourteenth Amendment were applicable to the present case, that there is no substantial difference be *362 tween the carrying on of business by the corporations taxed, and the same business when conducted by a private firm or individual.'
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Flint v. Stone Tracy Co. as background and precedent, quoting its reasoning, but does not criticize, distinguish, or otherwise alter its authority.

cited_decision: Quaker City Cab Co. v. Commonwealth of Pennsylvania
quote: Quaker City Cab Co. v. Pennsylvania is only a relic of a bygone era. We cannot follow it and stay within the narrow confines of judicial review, which is an important part of our constitutional tradition.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that it cannot follow Quaker City Cab and characterizes it as a 'relic of a bygone era,' thereby overruling its precedential value.

cited_decision: Louis K. Liggett Co. v. Baldridge (1928)
quote: The Liggett case, being a derelict in the stream of the law, is hereby overruled. We reverse and remand the judgment below and free the courts and agencies of North Dakota from what the State Supreme Court deemed to be the mandate of Liggett.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Liggett is 'hereby overruled,' making the treatment clear and direct.

quote: Mills v. Alabama, 384 U. S. 214 , involved the constitutionality of a state statute in effect making it a crime for a newspaper editor on election day to urge people to vote a certain way on the issues being submitted. The state court held the act did not violate the Federal Constitution and remanded the case for trial. It was argued that the judgment was not 'final' for purposes of 28 U. S. C. § 1257 . We noted that the point had 'a surface plausibility, since it is true the judgment of the State Supreme Court did not literally end the case.' 384 U. S., at 217 . We held it 'final,' however, because if the Act were constitutional the editor wbuld in reality have no defense.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Mills v. Alabama as an example in its discussion of finality for appellate jurisdiction, but does not criticize, distinguish, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

quote: The exceptions noted 5 have a long lineage dating back *162 to Mr. Chief Justice Taney’s opinion in Forgay v. Conrad, 6 How. 201 , where the Court held 'final' an interlocutory decree requiring a litigant 'to deliver up property which he claims,' even though a final accounting has yet to be made.
rationale: Forgay v. Conrad is cited as historical precedent for the concept of finality in appellate review, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

cited_decision: Radio Station Wow, Inc. v. Johnson (1945)
quote: Mr. Justice Frankfurter, writing for the Court in Radio Station WOW v. Johnson, 326 U. S. 120, 124 , summarized the requirement by Congress that in appeals from federal district courts as well as in review of state court decisions the judgments be 'final'... But, as he pointed out, this concept of 'finality' has a 'penumbral area.' Ibid. Speaking for the Court in that case, he held that Nebraska’s ruling on the legality of a radio license issued by the Federal Communications Commission could be reviewed even though the state court had not yet determined the final accounting.
rationale: Radio Station Wow, Inc. v. Johnson is discussed as an illustrative precedent regarding the doctrine of finality, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes nor limits its authority.

cited_decision: Nancy Dukes, D/B/A Louisiana Concessions v. The City of New Orleans and Honorable Moon Landrieu, No. 73-3979 Summary Calendar. Rule 18, 5 Cir. See Isbell Enterprises, Inc. v. Citizens Casualty Company of New York, 5 Cir. 1970, 431 F.2d 409, Part I
quote: We hold that we have jurisdiction of appellant’s appeal, and on the merits reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that it is reversing the judgment of the Court of Appeals, which is the cited decision.

quote: Actually, the reliance on the statutes potential irrationality in Morey v. Doud , as the dissenters in that case correctly pointed out, see 354 U. S., at 474-475 (Frankfurter, J., joined by Harlan, J., dissenting), was a needlessly intrusive judicial infringement on the States legislative powers, and we have concluded that the equal protection analysis employed in that opinion should no longer be followed. ... Morey is, as appellee and the Court of Appeals properly recognized, essentially indistinguishable from this case, but the decision so far departs from proper equal protection analysis in cases of exclusively economic regulation that it should be, and it is, overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Morey v. Doud 'should be, and it is, overruled,' making the treatment clear.

cited_decision: Williamson v. Lee Optical of Oklahoma, Inc.
quote: Legislatures may implement their program step by step, Katzenbach v. Morgan, 384 U. S. 641 (1966), in such economic areas, adopting regulations that only partially ameliorate a perceived evil and deferring complete elimination of the evil to future regulations. See, e. g., Williamson v. Lee Optical Co., 348 U. S. 483, 488-489 (1955).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Williamson v. Lee Optical as an example supporting a general legal principle, without criticizing, limiting, or otherwise altering its precedential value.

quote: in the local economic sphere, it is only the in *304 vidious discrimination., the wholly arbitrary act, which cannot stand consistently with the Fourteenth Amendment. See, e. g., Ferguson v. Skrupa, 372 U. S. 726, 732 (1963).
rationale: Ferguson v. Skrupa is cited as authority for a general proposition about equal protection and economic regulation, with no indication of criticism or limitation.

quote: The governing constitutional principle was stated in Katzenbach v. Morgan, supra, at 657: '[W]e are guided by the familiar principles that a statute is not invalid under the Constitution because it might have gone farther than it did,' ...
rationale: Katzenbach v. Morgan is quoted for a general principle and its reasoning is adopted, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: To the extent that Durham v. United States, 401 U. S. 481 (1971), may be inconsistent with this ruling, Durham is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Durham is overruled to the extent it is inconsistent with the current ruling, which is a clear and direct overruling.

quote: In Duncan v. Louisiana, 391 U. S. 145 (1968), we held that the Fourteenth Amendment guarantees a right to trial by jury in all criminal cases that — were they to be tried in a federal court — would come within the Sixth Amendment’s guarantee.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Duncan v. Louisiana as precedent for the proposition that the right to jury trial applies to the states, but does not criticize, limit, or overrule it. The decision builds upon Duncan, treating it as settled law.

quote: This Court’s earlier decisions have assumed an affirmative answer to this question. The leading case so construing the Sixth Amendment is Thompson v. Utah, 170 U. S. 343 (1898)... We conclude, in short, as we began: the fact that the jury at common law was composed of precisely 12 is a historical accident, unnecessary to effect the purposes of the jury system and wholly without significance 'except to mystics.' ... To read the Sixth Amendment as forever codifying a feature so incidental to the real purpose of the Amendment is to ascribe a blind formalism to the Framers which would require considerably more evidence than we have been able to discover in the history and language of the Constitution or in the reasoning of our past decisions.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly rejects the holding of Thompson v. Utah that the Sixth Amendment requires a 12-person jury, thereby overruling it.

quote: Similarly, cases interpreting the jury trial provisions of the Seventh Amendment generally leap from the fact that the jury possessed a certain feature at common law to the conclusion that that feature must have been preserved by the Amendment’s simple reference to trial by 'jury.' E. g., Capital Traction Co. v. Hof, 174 U. S. 1, 13-14 (1899); American Publishing Co. v. Fisher, 166 U. S. 464, 468 (1897). While much of our discussion in this case may be thought to bear equally on the interpretation of the Seventh Amendment’s jury trial provisions, we emphasize that the question is not before us; we do not decide whether, for example, additional references to the 'common law' that occur in the Seventh Amendment might support a different interpretation.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Capital Traction Co. v. Hof by noting that its reasoning about the Seventh Amendment does not control the Sixth Amendment issue before the Court.

quote: Given Malloy v. Hogan, 378 U. S. 1 (1964), I join that part of the Court’s opinion in No. 927 relating to the Florida 'alibi' procedure.
rationale: Malloy v. Hogan is mentioned as precedent for incorporation of the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination, but is not discussed or altered in any substantive way.

quote: A ruling that the Sixth Amendment refers to a common-law jury was essential to the holding in Rassmussen v. United States, 197 U. S. 516 (1905), where the Court held invalid a conviction by a six-man jury in Alaska. The ruling was accepted at the Government’s concession without discussion or citation; the major focus of the case was on the question whether the Sixth Amendment was applicable to the territory in question at all. See 197 U. S., at 519.
rationale: The Acting Decision questions the precedential value of Rassmussen v. United States, noting that its holding was based on an assumption rather than analysis, and suggesting that its reasoning is not controlling.

quote: It is to the distinction between 'petty' and 'serious' offenses, rooted in the common law, that this Court has looked to ascertain the metes and bounds of the federal right guaranteed by the Sixth Amendment. See District of Columbia v. Clawans, 300 U. S. 617 (1937); Schick v. United States, 195 U. S. 65 (1904); Callan v. Wilson, 127 U. S. 540, 552 (1888).
rationale: Callan v. Wilson is cited as historical support for the distinction between petty and serious offenses, but the Acting Decision does not discuss, criticize, or alter its holding.

quote: In Ker v. California, 374 U. S. 23 (1963), I noted in an opinion concurring in the result that: 'The rule [of ‘incorporation’] is unwise because the States, with their differing law enforcement problems, should not be put in a constitutional strait jacket ....'
rationale: Ker v. California is mentioned in a concurring opinion to illustrate a point about incorporation, but is not substantively discussed or altered.

quote: It is to the distinction between 'petty' and 'serious' offenses, rooted in the common law, that this Court has looked to ascertain the metes and bounds of the federal right guaranteed by the Sixth Amendment. See District of Columbia v. Clawans, 300 U. S. 617 (1937); Schick v. United States, 195 U. S. 65 (1904); Callan v. Wilson, 127 U. S. 540, 552 (1888).
rationale: District of Columbia v. Clawans is cited as precedent for the petty/serious offense distinction, but is not discussed or altered.

quote: Although I have disagreed with particular holdings like Gilbert v. California, supra, where the Court held that the *133 States must arrange presence of counsel at lineups, see Mr. Justice White’s separate opinion in United States v. Wade, 388 U. S. 218, 250 (1967), which I joined, this is because those decisions incorrectly require, in my view, counsel in circumstances where his presence is not necessary under either the Sixth Amendment or the Due Process Clause.
rationale: United States v. Wade is mentioned in a discussion of the right to counsel, but the Acting Decision does not discuss, criticize, or alter its holding.

quote: The closest decision in theory, Marsh v. Alabama, supra, involved the assumption by a private enterprise of all of the attributes of a state-created municipality and the exercise by that enterprise of semiofficial municipal functions as a delegate of the State. In effect, thé owner of the company town was performing the full spectrum of municipal powers and stood in the shoes of the State. In the instant case there is no comparable assumption or exercise of municipal functions or power.
rationale: The Acting Decision explains that Marsh involved a company town with all the attributes of a municipality, whereas the present case does not, thereby distinguishing Marsh on its facts and limiting its applicability.

cited_decision: Amalgamated Food Employees Union Local 590 v. Logan Valley Plaza, Inc. (1968)
quote: And in the performance of that duty we make clear now, if it was not clear before, that the rationale of Logan Valley did not survive the Court’s decision in the Lloyd case.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that the rationale of Logan Valley is no longer valid and makes clear that it is overruled, removing its precedential value.

quote: The Court in its Lloyd opinion did not say that it was overruling the Logan Valley decision. Indeed, a substantial portion of the Court’s opinion in Lloyd was devoted to pointing out the differences between the two cases, noting particularly that, in contrast to the hand-billing in Lloyd, the picketing in Logan Valley had been *518 specifically directed to a store in the shopping center and the pickets had had no other reasonable opportunity to reach their intended audience. 407 U. S., at 561-567.
rationale: Lloyd Corp. v. Tanner is discussed at length for its reasoning and its effect on Logan Valley, but the Acting Decision neither overrules, criticizes, nor limits Lloyd; it simply analyzes and applies it.

cited_decision: National Labor Relations Board v. Babcock & Wilcox Co. (1956)
quote: This result was ostensibly reached under the statutory criteria set forth in NLRB v. Babcock & Wilcox Co., 351 U. S. 105, a case which held that union organizers who seek to solicit for union membership may intrude on an employer’s private property if no alternative means exist for communicating with the employees.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Babcock & Wilcox as providing the statutory standard for balancing § 7 rights and property rights, but does not alter, criticize, or limit its holding.

cited_decision: Central Hardware Co. v. National Labor Relations Board (1972)
quote: The task of the Board and the reviewing courts under the Act, therefore, stands in conspicuous contrast to the duty of a court in applying the standards of the First Amendment, which requires 'above all else' that expression must not be restricted by government 'because of its message, its ideas, its subject matter, or its content.' In the Central Hardware case, and earlier in the case of NLRB v. Babcock & Wilcox Co., 351 U. S. 105, the Court considered the nature of the Boards task in this area under the Act.
rationale: Central Hardware is cited as precedent for the statutory balancing required under the NLRA, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: A three-judge court convened under 28 U. S. C. § 2281 sustained the constitutionality of the statutory differential and dismissed the action. 399 F. Supp. 1304 (1975). We noted probable jurisdiction of appellants’ appeal, 423 U. S. 1047 (1976). We reverse.
rationale: Walker v. Hall is referenced as the district court decision being appealed and reversed, but the Supreme Court does not analyze or critique its reasoning in detail; it is simply the procedural predecessor.

quote: And only two Terms ago, Stanton v. Stanton, 421 U. S. 7 (1975), expressly stating that Reed v. Reed was 'controlling,' 421 U. S., at 13, held that Reed required invalidation of a Utah differential age-of-majority statute, notwithstanding the statute’s coincidence with and furtherance of the State’s purpose of fostering 'old notions' of role typing and preparing boys for their expected performance in the economic and political worlds. 421 U. S., at 14-15.
rationale: Stanton v. Stanton is cited as precedent supporting the application of Reed v. Reed, but the Acting Decision does not distinguish, criticize, or otherwise alter its holding; it is used as supporting authority.

quote: Analysis may appropriately begin with the reminder that Reed emphasized that statutory classifications that distinguish between males and females are 'subject to scrutiny under the Equal Protection Clause.' 404 U. S., at 75. To withstand constitutional challenge, previous cases establish that classifications by gender must serve important governmental objectives and must be substantially related to achievement of those objectives. Thus, in Reed, the objectives of 'reducing the workload on probate courts,' id., at 76, and 'avoiding intrafamily controversy,' id., at 77, were deemed of insufficient importance to sustain use of an overt gender criterion in the appointment of administrators of intestate decedents’ estates.
rationale: Reed v. Reed is treated as controlling precedent and is repeatedly cited as the standard for gender discrimination analysis, but the Acting Decision does not alter, criticize, or limit it; it applies Reed as binding authority.

quote: our decisions have settled that limitations on a litigant’s assertion of jus tertii are not constitutionally mandated, but rather stem from a salutary 'rule of self-restraint' designed to minimize unwarranted intervention into controversies where the applicable constitutional questions are ill-defined and speculative. See, e. g., Barrows v. Jackson, 346 U. S. 249, 255, 257 (1953); see also Singleton v. Wulff, 428 U. S. 106, 123-124 (1976) (Powell, J.; dissenting).
rationale: Barrows v. Jackson is cited as precedent for third-party standing, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes nor distinguishes it; it is referenced as supporting authority.

quote: Decisions following Reed similarly have rejected administrative ease and convenience as sufficiently important objectives to justify gender-based classifications. See, e. g., Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U. S. 645, 656 (1972); Frontiero v. Richardson, 411 U. S. 677, 690 (1973); cf. Schlesinger v. Ballard, 419 U. S. 498, 506-507 (1975).
rationale: Stanley v. Illinois is cited as an example of a case rejecting administrative convenience as a justification for gender discrimination, but the Acting Decision does not alter or question its holding.

quote: Kahn v. Shevin, 416 U. S. 351 (1974) and Schlesinger v. Ballard, 419 U. S. 498 (1975), upholding the use of gender-based classifications, rested upon the Court’s perception of the laudatory purposes of those laws as remedying disadvantageous conditions suffered by women in economic and military life. See 416 U. S., at 353-354; 419 U. S., at 508. Needless to say, in this case Oklahoma does not suggest that the age-sex differential was enacted to ensure the availability of 3.2% beer for women as compensation for previous deprivations. That this was the true purpose is not at all self-evident.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Kahn v. Shevin by noting that the justification for the gender-based classification in Kahn (remedying disadvantage to women) is not present in the Oklahoma statute at issue.

quote: Decisions following Reed similarly have rejected administrative ease and convenience as sufficiently important objectives to justify gender-based classifications. See, e. g., Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U. S. 645, 656 (1972); Frontiero v. Richardson, 411 U. S. 677, 690 (1973); cf. Schlesinger v. Ballard, 419 U. S. 498, 506-507 (1975).
rationale: Frontiero v. Richardson is cited as precedent supporting the application of heightened scrutiny to gender classifications, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, distinguish, or limit it.

quote: Indeed, the jus tertii question raised here is answered by our disposition of a like argument in Eisenstadt v. Baird, supra. There, as here, a state statute imposed legal duties and disabilities upon the claimant, who was convicted of distributing a package of contraceptive foam to a third party. ... Since the statute was directed at Baird and penalized his conduct, the Court did not hesitate — again as here — to conclude that the 'case or controversy' requirement of Art. Ill was satisfied. 405 U. S., at 443.
rationale: Eisenstadt v. Baird is cited as directly analogous precedent for third-party standing, but the Acting Decision does not alter or criticize its holding.

quote: Kahn v. Shevin, 416 U. S. 351 (1974) and Schlesinger v. Ballard, 419 U. S. 498 (1975), upholding the use of gender-based classifications, rested upon the Court’s perception of the laudatory purposes of those laws as remedying disadvantageous conditions suffered by women in economic and military life. See 416 U. S., at 353-354; 419 U. S., at 508. Needless to say, in this case Oklahoma does not suggest that the age-sex differential was enacted to ensure the availability of 3.2% beer for women as compensation for previous deprivations.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Schlesinger v. Ballard by noting that the justification for the gender-based classification in Schlesinger (remedying disadvantage to women) is not present in the Oklahoma statute at issue.

quote: Insofar as Goesaert v. Cleary, 335 U. S. 464 (1948), may be inconsistent, that decision is disapproved. Undoubtedly reflecting the view that Goesaert’s equal protection analysis no longer obtains, the District Court made no reference to that decision in upholding Oklahoma’s-statute. Similarly, the opinions of the federal and state courts cited earlier in the text invalidating gender lines with respect to alcohol regulation uniformly disparaged the contemporary vitality of Goesaert.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly disapproves Goesaert v. Cleary to the extent it is inconsistent with current equal protection analysis, indicating that its reasoning is no longer valid.

quote: Ex parte Young was a watershed case in which this Court held that the Eleventh Amendment did not bar an action in the federal courts seeking to enjoin the Attorney General of Minnesota from enforcing a statute claimed to violate the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution. This holding has permitted the Civil War Amendments to the Constitution to serve as a sword, rather than merely as a shield, for those whom they were designed to protect. But the relief awarded in Ex parte Young was prospective only... But the retroactive portion of the District Court’s order here, which requires the payment of a very substantial amount of money which that court held should have been paid, but was not, stands on quite a different footing.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Ex parte Young by holding that while prospective injunctive relief is permitted under Ex parte Young, retroactive monetary relief is not, thus limiting the scope of Ex parte Young to prospective relief only.

cited_decision: Parden v. Terminal Railway of Alabama State Docks Department
quote: Both Parden and Employees involved a congressional enactment which by its terms authorized suit by designated plaintiffs against a general class of defendants which literally included States or state instrumentalities... But in this case the threshold fact of congressional authorization to sue a class of defendants which literally includes States is wholly absent. Thus respondent is not only precluded from relying on this Court’s holding in Employees, but on this Court’s holdings in Parden and Petty as well.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Parden by noting that, unlike in Parden, there is no congressional authorization to sue states in the relevant statute, so the precedent does not apply.

cited_decision: Employees of Department of Public Health v. Department of Public Health
quote: Both Parden and Employees involved a congressional enactment which by its terms authorized suit by designated plaintiffs against a general class of defendants which literally included States or state instrumentalities... But in this case the threshold fact of congressional authorization to sue a class of defendants which literally includes States is wholly absent. Thus respondent is not only precluded from relying on this Court’s holding in Employees, but on this Court’s holdings in Parden and Petty as well.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Employees by stating that the necessary congressional authorization to sue states is absent in the present case, so Employees does not control.

quote: Similarly, Petty v. Tennessee-Missouri Bridge Comm’n, supra, involved congressional approval, pursuant to the Compact Clause, of a compact between Tennessee and Missouri, which provided that each compacting State would have the power 'to contract, to sue, and be sued in its own name.' ... But in this case the threshold fact of congressional authorization to sue a class of defendants which literally includes States is wholly absent. Thus respondent is not only precluded from relying on this Court’s holding in Employees, but on this Court’s holdings in Parden and Petty as well.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Petty by explaining that, unlike in Petty, there is no congressional authorization for suit against states in the present context.

cited_decision: Ford Motor Co. v. Department of Treasury
quote: Thus the rule has evolved that a suit by private parties seeking to impose a liability which must be paid from public funds in the state treasury is barred by the Eleventh Amendment. Great Northern Life Insurance Co. v. Read, supra; Kennecott Copper Corp. v. State Tax Comm’n, 327 U. S. 573 (1946). ... Were we to uphold this portion of the District Court’s decree, we would be obligated to overrule the Court’s holding in Ford Motor Co. v. Department of Treasury, supra. ... We reach a similar conclusion with respect to the retroactive portion of the relief awarded by the District Court in this case.
rationale: The Acting Decision applies and affirms the rule from Ford Motor Co. v. Department of Treasury, using it as direct precedent for its holding, but does not overrule, criticize, or limit it.

cited_decision: John Jordan, by His Next Friend, Jeanette Bryant, Individually and on Behalf of All Other Persons Similarly Situated, Cross-Appellees v. Edward T. Weaver, Cross-Appellants
quote: For the foregoing reasons we decide that the Court of Appeals was wrong in holding that the Eleventh Amendment did not constitute a bar to that portion of the District Court decree which ordered retroactive payment of benefits found to have been wrongfully withheld. The judgment of the Court of Appeals is therefore reversed and the cause remanded for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly reverses the judgment of the cited Court of Appeals decision.

quote: It is, of course, true that Rosado v. Wyman, 397 U. S. 397 (1970), held that suits in federal court under § 1983 are proper to secure compliance with the provisions of the Social Security Act on the part of participating States. 18 But it has not hereto *676 fore been suggested that § 1983 was intended to create a waiver of a State’s Eleventh Amendment immunity merely because an action could be brought under that *677 section against state officers, rather than against the State itself. ... We do not regard Rosado as controlling either way since the Court was not faced with a district court judgment ordering retroactive payments or with a challenge based on the Eleventh Amendment.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Rosado v. Wyman, stating that it did not address the Eleventh Amendment issue or retroactive payments, and thus is not controlling.

quote: We adhere to King v. Smith, 392 U. S. 309 (1968), which implicitly rejected the argument that the statutory provisions for HEW review of plans should be read to curtail judicial relief and held Alabama’s ‘substitute father’ regulation to be inconsistent with the federal statute.
rationale: The Acting Decision references King v. Smith as precedent for judicial review of state welfare plans, but does not discuss, criticize, or limit its holding.

quote: Because of an apparent conflict on the Eleventh Amendment issue with the decision of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Rothstein v. Wyman, 467 F. 2d 226 (1972), cert. denied, 411 U. S. 921 (1973), we granted the petition for certiorari... Addressing himself to a similar situation in Rothstein v. Wyman, 467 F. 2d 226 *665 (CA2 1972), cert. denied, 411 U. S. 921 (1973), Judge McGowan 10 observed for the court: ... We agree with Judge McGowan’s observations.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Rothstein v. Wyman for its reasoning and agrees with its analysis, but does not overrule, criticize, or distinguish it.

quote: Monaco v. Mississippi, 292 U. S. 313 (1934), reaffirmed the principle that the Eleventh Amendment was no bar to a suit by the United States against a State. Id., at 329.
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions Monaco v. Mississippi to clarify the rule regarding suits by the United States, but does not discuss or alter its holding.

quote: Shapiro v. Thompson, 394 U. S. 618 (1969), is the only instance in which the Eleventh Amendment objection to such retroactive relief was actually presented to this Court in a case which was orally argued. ... This case, therefore, is the first opportunity the Court has taken to fully explore and treat the Eleventh Amend *671 ment aspects of such relief in a written opinion. Shapiro v. Thompson and these three summary affirmances obviously are of precedential value in support of the contention that the Eleventh Amendment does not bar the relief awarded by the District Court in this case. Equally obviously, they are not of the same precedential value as would be an opinion of this Court treating the question on the merits. Since we deal with a constitutional question, we are less constrained by the principle of stare decisis than we are in other areas of the law. 14 Having now had an opportunity to more fully consider the Eleventh Amendment issue after briefing and argument, we disapprove the Eleventh Amendment holdings of those cases to the extent that they are inconsistent with our holding today.
rationale: The Acting Decision limits the precedential value of Shapiro v. Thompson regarding the Eleventh Amendment, stating that any contrary holdings are disapproved to the extent they conflict with the present decision.

quote: Decisions of this Court in which we summarily affirmed a decision of a lower federal court which ordered the payment of retroactive awards and in which the jurisdictional statement filed in this Court raised the Eleventh Amendment defense include: ... Wyman v. Bowens, 397 U. S. 49 (1970). ... Shapiro v. Thompson and these three summary affirmances obviously are of precedential value in support of the contention that the Eleventh Amendment does not bar the relief awarded by the District Court in this case. Equally obviously, they are not of the same precedential value as would be an opinion of this Court treating the question on the merits. ... we disapprove the Eleventh Amendment holdings of those cases to the extent that they are inconsistent with our holding today.
