rationale: The Acting Decision limits the precedential value of Wyman v. Bowens regarding the Eleventh Amendment, disapproving any contrary holdings.

cited_decision: Sterrett v. Mothers' & Children's Rights Organization, 409 U.S. 809 (1972)
quote: Decisions of this Court in which we summarily affirmed a decision of a lower federal court which ordered the payment of retroactive awards and in which the jurisdictional statement filed in this Court raised the Eleventh Amendment defense include: ... Sterrett v. Mothers’ and Children’s Rights Organization, 409 U. S. 809 (1972), aff’g unreported order and judgment of District Court (ND Ind. 1972) on remand from Carpenter v. Sterrett, 405 U. S. 971 (1972); ... Shapiro v. Thompson and these three summary affirmances obviously are of precedential value in support of the contention that the Eleventh Amendment does not bar the relief awarded by the District Court in this case. Equally obviously, they are not of the same precedential value as would be an opinion of this Court treating the question on the merits. ... we disapprove the Eleventh Amendment holdings of those cases to the extent that they are inconsistent with our holding today.
rationale: The Acting Decision limits the precedential value of Sterrett v. Mothers' & Children's Rights Organization regarding the Eleventh Amendment, disapproving any contrary holdings.

cited_decision: State Department of Health & Rehabilitative Services of Florida v. Zarate, 407 U.S. 918 (1972)
quote: Decisions of this Court in which we summarily affirmed a decision of a lower federal court which ordered the payment of retroactive awards and in which the jurisdictional statement filed in this Court raised the Eleventh Amendment defense include: State Dept. of Health and Rehabilitative Services v. Zarate, 407 U. S. 918 (1972), aff’g 347 F. Supp. 1004 (SD Fla. 1971); ... Shapiro v. Thompson and these three summary affirmances obviously are of precedential value in support of the contention that the Eleventh Amendment does not bar the relief awarded by the District Court in this case. Equally obviously, they are not of the same precedential value as would be an opinion of this Court treating the question on the merits. ... we disapprove the Eleventh Amendment holdings of those cases to the extent that they are inconsistent with our holding today.
rationale: The Acting Decision limits the precedential value of State Department of Health & Rehabilitative Services of Florida v. Zarate regarding the Eleventh Amendment, disapproving any contrary holdings.

quote: And the potential unfairness of the division is magnified by the application of the rule of The Pennsylvania, 19 Wall. 125, whereby a ship’s relatively minor statutory violation will require her to bear half the collision damage unless she can satisfy the heavy burden of showing 'not merely that her fault might not have been one of the causes, or that it probably was not, but that it could not have been.' Id., at 136 (emphasis added).
rationale: The Acting Decision references The Pennsylvania to illustrate the harshness of the divided damages rule but does not overrule, criticize, or otherwise alter its holding. It is used as an example in the discussion.

cited_decision: Moragne v. States Marine Lines, Inc. (1970)
quote: But even if we could find guidance in such negative legislation, Moragne v. States Marine Lines, 398 U. S. 375, 405 n. 17, it appears that the Senate took no action with respect to the Convention...
rationale: Moragne is cited in a parenthetical to support a point about legislative inaction and negative legislation, not for its substantive holding. There is no discussion or alteration of its precedential value.

cited_decision: Oriental Trading & Transport Co. v. Gulf Oil Corp. (1949)
quote: And Judge Hand had all but invited this Court to overturn the rule when, in an earlier opinion for the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, he stated that 'we have no power to divest ourselves of this vestigial relic; we can only go so far as to close our eyes to doubtful delinquencies.' Oriental Trading & Transport Co. v. Gulf Oil Corp., 173 F. 2d 108, 111.
rationale: The decision is quoted to show Judge Hand's criticism of the divided damages rule, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter the cited case itself.

quote: The divided damages rule has been said to be justified by the difficulty of determining comparative degrees of negligence when both parties are concededly guilty of contributing fault. The Max Morris, 137 U. S. 1, 12.
rationale: The Max Morris is cited as an example of a justification for the divided damages rule, but the Acting Decision does not criticize or alter its holding.

quote: and in our own admiralty law a rule of comparative negligence has long been applied with no untoward difficulties in personal injury actions. See, e. g., Pope & Talbot, Inc. v. Hawn, 346 U. S. 406, 409.
rationale: The case is cited as an example of comparative negligence in personal injury actions, not for its holding or reasoning. There is no criticism or alteration.

cited_decision: Fitzgerald v. United States Lines Co. (1963)
quote: the Judiciary has traditionally taken the lead in formulating flexible and fair remedies in the law maritime, and 'Congress has largely left to this Court the responsibility for fashioning the controlling rules of admiralty law.' Fitzgerald v. United States Lines Co., 374 U. S. 16, 20.
rationale: Fitzgerald is cited for a general principle about the Court's role in admiralty law, not for its specific holding. There is no criticism or alteration.

quote: See also Moragne v. States Marine Lines, 398 U. S. 375, 405 n. 17; Kermarec v. Compagnie Generate Transatlantique, 358 U. S. 625, 630-632.
rationale: Kermarec is cited as an example of the Court's role in admiralty law, not for its holding or reasoning. There is no criticism or alteration.

quote: The operation of the rule was described in The Sapphire, 18 Wall. 51, 56: 'It is undoubtedly the rule in admiralty that where both vessels are in fault the sums representing the damage sustained by each must be added together and the aggregate divided between the two...'
rationale: The Sapphire is quoted to describe the divided damages rule, but the Acting Decision does not criticize or overrule it directly.

quote: Similarly, in The North Star, 106 U. S. 17, 22, the rule was thus stated: '[According to the general maritime law, in cases of collision occurring by the fault of both parties, the entire damage to both ships is added together in one common mass and equally divided between them...'
rationale: The North Star is cited to describe the traditional rule, not to criticize or alter its holding.

cited_decision: White Oak Transportation Co. v. Boston, Cape Cod & New York Canal Co. (1922)
quote: See also, e. g., White Oak Transportation Co. v. Boston, Cape Cod & New York Canal Co., 258 U. S. 341;
rationale: The case is cited as an example of the application of the divided damages rule, not for criticism or alteration.

quote: See also, e. g., White Oak Transportation Co. v. Boston, Cape Cod & New York Canal Co., 258 U. S. 341; The Eugene F. Moran, 212 U. S. 466.
rationale: The Eugene F. Moran is cited as an example of the application of the divided damages rule, not for criticism or alteration.

quote: Atlee v. Packet Co., 21 Wall. 389 (barge struck pier because of mutual fault of barge and of pier owner);
rationale: Atlee is cited as an example of the application of the divided damages rule, not for criticism or alteration.

cited_decision: Morley Construction Co. v. Maryland Casualty Co. (1937)
quote: However, absent a cross-petition for certiorari, the respondent may not now challenge the judgment of the Court of Appeals to enlarge its rights thereunder. Morley Constr. Co. v. Maryland Casualty Co., 300 U. S. 185, 190;
rationale: Morley Construction is cited for a procedural point about cross-petitions, not for its substantive holding.

cited_decision: Graver Tank & Mfg. Co. v. Linde Air Products Co. (1949)
quote: the findings of fact with respect to comparative negligence were concurred in by both the District Court and the Court of Appeals, and the respondent could not in this case meet its heavy burden under the 'two-court rule.' Graver Mfg. Co. v. Linde Co., 336 U. S. 271, 275.
rationale: Graver Tank is cited for the 'two-court rule' regarding factual findings, not for its substantive holding.

cited_decision: Berenyi v. District Director, Immigration & Naturalization Service (1966)
quote: See Berenyi v. Immigration Director, 385 U. S. 630, 635.
rationale: Berenyi is cited for a procedural point about factual findings, not for its substantive holding.

cited_decision: Weyerhaeuser Steamship Co. v. United States (1963)
quote: The Court has acknowledged the continued existence of the divided damages rule in at least two recent cases. See Weyerhaeuser S. S. Co. v. United States, 372 U. S. 597, 603;
rationale: Weyerhaeuser is cited as an example of the Court's acknowledgment of the divided damages rule, not for criticism or alteration.

cited_decision: Halcyon Lines v. Haenn Ship Ceiling & Refitting Corp. (1952)
quote: The Court has acknowledged the continued existence of the divided damages rule in at least two recent cases. See Weyerhaeuser S. S. Co. v. United States, 372 U. S. 597, 603; Halcyon Lines v. Haenn Ship Ceiling & Refitting Corp., 342 U. S. 282, 284.
rationale: Halcyon Lines is cited as an example of the Court's acknowledgment of the divided damages rule, not for criticism or alteration.

cited_decision: Union Oil Co. of Cal. v. the San Jacinto (1972)
quote: The Court granted certiorari in Union Oil Co. v. The San Jacinto, 409 U. S. 140, to reconsider the divided damages rule, but did not reach the issue because of our conclusion that one of the vessels involved in that case was totally free of contributing fault.
rationale: Union Oil is mentioned as a case where the Court considered but did not decide the divided damages rule. There is no criticism or alteration.

quote: The Court has long implicitly recognized the patent harshness of an equal division of damages in the face of disparate blame by applying the 'major-minor' fault doctrine to find a grossly negligent party solely at fault. 12 See, e. g., The City of New York, 147 U. S. 72, 85:
rationale: The City of New York is cited as an example of the major-minor fault doctrine, not for criticism or alteration.

quote: See also The Victory & The Plymothian, 168 U. S. 410;
rationale: The Victory & the Plymothian is cited as an example of the major-minor fault doctrine, not for criticism or alteration.

quote: See also The Umbria, 166 U. S. 404;
rationale: The Umbria is cited as an example of the major-minor fault doctrine, not for criticism or alteration.

quote: See also The Oregon, 158 U. S. 186;
rationale: The Oregon is cited as an example of the major-minor fault doctrine, not for criticism or alteration.

quote: See also The Ludvig Holberg, 157 U. S. 60.
rationale: The Ludvig Holberg is cited as an example of the major-minor fault doctrine, not for criticism or alteration.

cited_decision: Burnet v. Coronado Oil & Gas Co. (1932)
quote: This Court, in other appropriate contexts, has not hesitated to overrule an earlier decision and settle a matter of continuing concern, even though relief might have been obtained by legislation. See Burnet v. Coronado Oil & Gas Co., 285 U. S. 393, 406 n. 1 (Brandéis, J., dissenting) (collecting cases).
rationale: Burnet is cited as an example of the Court overruling precedent, not for its substantive holding.

quote: We hold that when two or more parties have contributed by their fault to cause property damage in a maritime collision or stranding, liability for such damage is to be allocated among the parties proportionately to the comparative degree of their fault, and that liability for such damages is to be allocated equally only when the parties are equally at fault or when it is not possible fairly to measure the comparative degree of their fault.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly replaces the rule of equal division of damages established in The Schooner Catharine v. Dickinson with a rule of proportional fault, thereby overruling it.

cited_decision: National Labor Relations Board v. Insurance Agents' International Union (1960)
quote: We held that such tactics would not support a finding by the NLRB that the union had failed to bargain in good faith as required by § 8 (b) (3) and rejected the per se rule applied by the Board that use of 'economically harassing activities' alone sufficed to prove a vio *143 lation of that section. The Court assumed 'that the activities in question here were not protected’ under § 7 of the Act,' 361 U. S., at 483 n. 6, but held that the per se rule was beyond the authority of the NLRB to apply.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Insurance Agents at length, using its reasoning to support the current holding, but does not overrule, criticize, or otherwise alter its precedential value. The case is analyzed and relied upon, but its authority is not questioned or limited.

cited_decision: International Union, U. A. W. A., A. F. of L., Local 232 v. Wisconsin Employment Relations Board (1949)
quote: Briggs-Stratton is expressly overruled. Its authority 'has been ‘so restricted by our later decisions’ . . . that [it] must be regarded as having ‘been worn away by the erosion of time’ . . . and of contrary authority.' United States v. Raines, 362 U. S. 17, 26 (1960).
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the holding of Briggs-Stratton (the short name for this cited case) is 'expressly overruled,' leaving no doubt that its precedential value is nullified.

cited_decision: San Diego Building Trades Council v. Garmon (1959)
quote: Federal labor policy as reflected in the National Labor Relations Act, as amended, has been construed not to preclude the States from regulating aspects of labor relations that involve 'conduct touch [ing] interests so deeply rooted in local feeling and responsibility that ... we could not infer that Congress had deprived the States of the power to act.' San Diego Unions v. Garmon, 359 U. S. 236, 244 (1959).
rationale: Garmon is cited as a foundational precedent for the pre-emption doctrine and is quoted and discussed, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes, limits, nor overrules it. Its authority is accepted and applied.

cited_decision: Hanna Mining Co. v. District 2, Marine Engineers Beneficial Ass'n (1965)
quote: '[T]he legislative purpose may . . . dictate that certain activity neither protected nor prohibited’ be deemed privileged against state regulation.' Hanna Mining Co. v. Marine Engineers, 382 U. S. 181, 187 (1965).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Hanna Mining to support its analysis of pre-emption but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority. The case is used as supporting precedent.

cited_decision: Local 20, Teamsters, Chauffeurs & Helpers Union v. Morton (1964)
quote: But the analysis of Garner and Insurance Agents came full bloom in the pre-emption area in Teamsters Union v. Morton, 377 U. S. 252 (1964), which held pre-empted the application *146 of state law to award damages for peaceful union secondary picketing.
rationale: Teamsters Union v. Morton is cited as a key precedent in the development of pre-emption doctrine and is relied upon for its reasoning, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or overrule it.

cited_decision: Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen v. Jacksonville Terminal Co. (1969)
quote: The critical inquiry with respect to pre-emption as whether 'the exercise of plenary state authority to curtail or entirely prohibit self-help would frustrate effective implementation of the Act’s processes.' Railroad Trainmen v. Jacksonville Terminal Co., 394 U. S. 369, 380 (1969).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Jacksonville Terminal Co. as authority for the pre-emption standard but does not criticize, limit, or overrule it. The case is used to support the current holding.

quote: While Furman did not hold that the infliction of the death penalty per se violates the Constitutions ban on cruel and unusual punishments, it did recognize that the penalty of death is different in kind from any other punishment imposed under our system of criminal justice. Because of the uniqueness of the death penalty, Furman held that it could not be imposed under sentencing procedures that created a substantial risk that it would be inflicted in an arbitrary and capricious manner... The new Georgia sentencing procedures, by contrast, focus the jury’s attention on the particularized nature of the crime and the particularized characteristics of the individual defendant.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Furman by holding that the constitutional deficiencies identified in Furman are not present under Georgia's revised procedures, thus upholding the death penalty under a different statutory scheme.

quote: As Mr. Chief Justice Warren said, in an oft-quoted phrase, '[t]he Amendment must draw its meaning from the evolving standards of decency that mark the progress of a maturing society.' Trop v. Dulles, supra, at 101.
rationale: Trop v. Dulles is cited for its articulation of the 'evolving standards of decency' principle, but the Acting Decision does not alter, criticize, or limit its holding.

quote: As an important additional safeguard against arbitrariness and caprice, the Georgia statutory scheme provides for automatic appeal of all death sentences to the State’s Supreme Court... In Coley, it held that '[t]he prior cases indicate that the past practice among juries faced with similar factual situations and like aggravating circumstances has been to impose only the sentence of life imprisonment for the offense of rape, rather than death.' 231 Ga., at 835, 204 S. E. 2d, at 617.
rationale: Coley v. State is referenced as an example of how the Georgia Supreme Court applies proportionality review, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes nor distinguishes its reasoning.

quote: The only case in which the court upheld a conviction in reliance on this aggravating circumstance involved a man who stood up in a church and fired a gun indiscriminately into the audience. See Chenault v. State, 234 Ga. 216, 216 S. E. 2d 223 (1975). On the other hand, the court expressly reversed a finding of great risk when the victim was simply kid-naped in a parking lot. See Jarrell v. State, 234 Ga. 410, 424, 216 S. E. 2d 258, 269 (1975).
rationale: Jarrell v. State is cited as an example of how the Georgia Supreme Court has interpreted statutory aggravating circumstances, but the Acting Decision does not alter or criticize its holding.

quote: The Supreme Court of Georgia affirmed the convictions and the imposition of the death sentences for murder. 233 Ga. 117, 210 S. E. 2d 659 (1974). After reviewing the trial transcript and the record... the court concluded that... the sentences of death had not resulted from prejudice or any other arbitrary factor and were not excessive or disproportionate to the penalty applied in similar cases.
rationale: Gregg v. State is the direct lower court decision under review and is described factually; the Acting Decision affirms it but does not otherwise analyze or alter its reasoning.

quote: The Court early recognized that 'a principle to be vital must be capable of wider application than the mischief which gave it birth.' Weems v. United States, 217 U. S. 349, 373 (1910). Thus the Clause forbidding 'cruel and unusual' punishments 'is not fastened to the obsolete but may acquire meaning as public opinion becomes enlightened by a humane justice.' Id., at 378.
rationale: Weems is cited for its principle of proportionality and evolving standards, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or distinguish it.

quote: In the only statewide referendum occurring since Fur-man and brought to our attention, the people of California adopted a constitutional amendment that authorized capital punishment, in effect negating a prior ruling by the Supreme Court of California in People v. Anderson, 6 Cal. 3d 628, 493 P. 2d 880, cert. denied, 406 U. S. 958 (1972), that the death penalty violated the California Constitution.
rationale: People v. Anderson is mentioned as background to legislative and popular responses to Furman, not for its legal reasoning or holding.

quote: The court on another occasion stated that 'we view it to be our duty under the similarity standard to assure that no death sentence is affirmed unless in similar cases throughout the state the death penalty has been imposed generally . . . Moore v. State, 233 Ga. 861, 864, 213 S. E. 2d 829, 832 (1975).
rationale: Moore v. State is cited as an example of the Georgia Supreme Court's proportionality review, not for its substantive holding.

quote: Indeed, a recent regression study, based on Ehrlich’s theoretical model but using cross-section state data for the years 1950 and 1960, found no support for the conclusion that executions act as a deterrent. 12 The Ehrlich study, in short, is of little, if any, assistance in assessing the deterrent impact of the death penalty. Accord, Commonwealth v. O’Neal, -Mass. -, -, 339 N. E. 2d 676, 684 (1975).
rationale: Commonwealth v. O'NEAL is cited in a dissenting opinion as agreeing with the lack of deterrent effect of the death penalty; it is not analyzed or criticized.

quote: The substantive limits imposed by the Eighth Amendment on what can be made criminal and punished were discussed in Robinson v. California, 370 U. S. 660 (1962). The Court found unconstitutional a state statute that made the status of being addicted to a narcotic drug a criminal offense.
rationale: Robinson v. California is cited as precedent for the Eighth Amendment's application to the substance of criminal laws, but the Acting Decision does not alter or distinguish its holding.

quote: In McGautha v. California, supra, this Court held that the *196 Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment did not require that a jury be provided with standards to guide its decision whether to recommend a sentence of life imprisonment or death or that the capital-sentencing proceeding be separated from the guilt-determination process. McGautha was not an Eighth Amendment decision, and to the extent it purported to deal with Eighth Amendment concerns, it must be read in light of the opinions in Furman v. Georgia. There the Court ruled that death sentences imposed under statutes that left juries with untrammeled discretion to impose or withhold the death penalty violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments. While Furman did not overrule Mc-Gautha, it is clearly in substantial tension with a broad reading of McGautha’s holding.
rationale: The Acting Decision limits McGautha by stating that its holding must be read in light of Furman and that it cannot be broadly applied to Eighth Amendment challenges to capital sentencing procedures.

cited_decision: Memphis Natural Gas Co. v. Stone (1948)
quote: The narrowing of the rule to one of draftsmanship and phraseology began with another Mississippi case, Memphis Gas Co. v. Stone, 335 U. S. 80 (1948). ... The Mississippi Supreme Court upheld the tax, and this Court affirmed.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Memphis Natural Gas Co. v. Stone as part of the historical development of the law, describing its facts and outcome, but does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

quote: The unsatisfactory operation of the Spector rule is well demonstrated by our recent case of Colonial Pipeline Co. v. Traigle, 421 U. S. 100 (1975). ... By a 7-to-1 vote, this Court affirmed. ... Accordingly, on the authority of Memphis Gas, the tax was held to be constitutional.
rationale: The Acting Decision uses Colonial Pipeline Co. v. Traigle as an example of the application of the Spector rule and describes its holding, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise change its authority.

cited_decision: Spector Motor Service, Inc. v. O'Connor (1951)
quote: Accordingly, we now reject the rule of Spector Motor Service, Inc. v. O’Connor, that a state tax on the 'privilege of doing business' is per se unconstitutional when it is applied to interstate commerce, and that case is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Spector Motor Service, Inc. v. O'Connor is overruled, nullifying its precedential value.

cited_decision: Western Live Stock v. Bureau of Revenue (1938)
quote: Appellee, in its turn, relies on decisions of this Court stating that '[i]t was not the purpose of the commerce clause to relieve those engaged in interstate commerce from their just share of state tax burden even though it increases the cost of doing the business,' Western Live Stock v. Bureau of Revenue, 303 U. S. 250, 254 (1938).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Western Live Stock v. Bureau of Revenue to support a general principle but does not criticize, distinguish, or otherwise alter its authority.

cited_decision: Railway Express Agency, Inc. v. Virginia (1959)
quote: Virginia thereupon revised the wording of its statute to impose a 'franchise tax' on 'intangible property' in the form of 'going concern' value as measured by gross receipts. The tax was again asserted against the Agency which in Virginia was engaged exclusively in interstate commerce. This Court’s opinion, buttressed by two concurring opinions and one concurrence in the result, upheld the reworded statute as not violative of the Spector rule. Railway Express Agency v. Virginia, 358 U. S. 434 (1959) (Railway Express II).
rationale: The Acting Decision describes the facts and holding of Railway Express Agency, Inc. v. Virginia, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

cited_decision: United States v. Arnold, Schwinn & Co. (1967)
quote: Accordingly, we conclude that the per se rule stated in Schwinn must be overruled.
rationale: The lead opinion explicitly states that the per se rule from Schwinn is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value regarding vertical nonprice restrictions.

cited_decision: Gte Sylvania Incorporated v. Continental T v.  Inc., a Corporation (1976)
quote: In two short paragraphs, the majority disposes of the view, adopted after careful analysis by the Ninth Circuit en banc below, that these differences provide a 'principled basis for distinguishing Schwinn,' ante, at 46, despite holdings by three Courts of Appeals and the District Court on remand in Schwinn that the per se rule established in that case does not apply to location clauses such as Sylvania’s.
rationale: The Acting Decision references the Ninth Circuit's en banc decision as background and context for the Supreme Court's analysis, but does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise materially alter its precedential value.

cited_decision: Northern Pacific Railway Co. v. United States (1958)
quote: Per se rules of il *50 legality are appropriate only when they relate to conduct that is manifestly anticompetitive. As the Court explained in Northern Pac. R. Co. v. United States, 356 U. S. 1, 5 (1958), 'there are certain agreements or practices which because of their pernicious effect on competition and lack of any redeeming virtue are conclusively presumed to be unreasonable and therefore illegal without elaborate inquiry as to the precise harm they have caused or the business excuse for their use.'
rationale: Northern Pacific Railway Co. is cited as authority for the general standard regarding per se rules, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes nor limits its holding, instead using it as a foundational reference.

cited_decision: United States v. Arnold, Schwinn & Co. (1965)
quote: The District Court in that case found that '[e]ach one of [Schwinn’s franchised retailers] knows also that he is not a wholesaler and that he cannot sell as a wholesaler or act as an agent for some other unfranchised dealer, such as a discount house retailer who has not been franchised as a dealer by Schwinn.' 237 F. Supp. 323, 333 (ND Ill. 1965).
rationale: The Acting Decision references the District Court's factual findings and procedural history from the 1965 Schwinn case, but does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

quote: In New York v. United States, 326 U. S. 572 (1946), Mr. Chief Justice Stone, speaking for four Members of an eight-Member Court 13 in rejecting the proposition that Congress could impose taxes on the States so long as it did so in a nondiscriminatory manner, observed: ...
rationale: The Acting Decision references New York v. United States to illustrate a point about state sovereignty and federal taxation, but does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

quote: With regard to Fry , we disagree with appellee. There the Court held that the Economic Stabilization Act of 1970 was constitutional as applied to temporarily freeze the wages of state and local government employees. ... These factors distinguish the statute in Fry from the provisions at issue here.
rationale: The Acting Decision explains why Fry does not control the present case, distinguishing it based on the temporary and emergency nature of the statute in Fry versus the permanent and intrusive nature of the statute at issue.

quote: Indeed upon full consideration of the question we have decided that the 'far-reaching implications' of Wirtz should be overruled, ... We are therefore persuaded that Wirtz must be overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Maryland v. Wirtz is overruled and is no longer authoritative.

quote: Wirtz relied heavily on the Court’s decision in United States v. California, 297 U. S. 175 (1936). ... We think the dicta 18 from United States v. California, simply wrong.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly criticizes the reasoning (dicta) of United States v. California, stating it is 'simply wrong,' but does not expressly overrule the holding.

quote: This Court unanimously upheld the Act as a valid exercise of congressional authority under the commerce power in United States v. Darby, 312 U. S. 100 (1941), observing: 'Whatever their motive and purpose, regulations of commerce which do not infringe some constitutional prohibition are within the plenary power conferred on Congress by the Commerce Clause.' Id., at 115.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Darby as background precedent for the Commerce Clause, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: That authority is, in the words of Mr. Chief Justice Marshall in Gibbons v. Ogden, 9 Wheat. 1 (1824), 'the power to regulate; that is, to prescribe the rule by which commerce is to be governed.' Id., at 196.
rationale: The Acting Decision quotes Gibbons v. Ogden as a foundational statement of the Commerce Clause, without criticism or limitation.

quote: It also seems appropriate to note that Case v. Bowles, 327 U. S. 92 (1946), has not been overruled as the dissent asserts. Indeed that decision, *855 upon which our Brother heavily relies, has no direct application to the questions we consider today at all.
rationale: The Acting Decision states that Case v. Bowles does not apply to the present issues, distinguishing it from the case at hand.

quote: No direct quote provided, but the case is referenced in the context of federal taxation and state sovereignty.
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions Helvering v. Gerhardt as part of the historical discussion of state immunity from federal taxation, but does not discuss or alter its authority.

quote: In Coyle v. Oklahoma, 221 U. S. 559 (1911), the Court gave this example of such an attribute: 'The power to locate its own seat of government and to determine when and how it shall be changed from one place to another, and to appropriate its own public funds for that purpose, are essentially and peculiarly state powers.'
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Coyle v. Smith as an example of state sovereignty, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: In Lane County v. Oregon, 7 Wall. 71 (1869), his opinion for the Court said: 'Both the States and the United States existed before the Constitution. ...'
rationale: The Acting Decision references Lane County v. Oregon to support its discussion of state sovereignty, without criticism or limitation.

cited_decision: Parden v. Terminal Railway of Alabama State Docks Department (1964)
quote: For the same reasons, despite Mr. Justice Brennan’s claims to the contrary, the holdings in Parden v. Terminal R. Co., 377 U. S. 184 (1964), and California v. Taylor, 353 U. S. 553 (1957), are likewise unimpaired by our decision today.
rationale: The Acting Decision states that its holding does not affect or overrule Parden, thus merely mentioning it.

cited_decision: Employees of Department of Public Health v. Department of Public Health (1973)
quote: No direct quote provided, but the case is referenced in the context of the scope of federal power over state employment.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Employees of Department of Public Health v. Department of Public Health in passing, without discussion or alteration of its authority.

quote: Pollard’s Lessee v. Hagan, supra, holds that the State receives absolute title to the beds of navigable waterways within its boundaries upon admission to the Union, and contains not the slightest suggestion that such title is 'defeasible' in the technical sense of that term.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses and applies the rule from Pollard’s Lessee v. Hagan as foundational precedent, but does not alter, criticize, or limit its holding. The case is treated as authoritative and is used to support the Court's reasoning.

quote: Upon full reconsideration of our decision in Bonelli, we conclude that it was wrong in treating the equal-footing doctrine as a source of federal common law after that doctrine had vested title to the riverbed in the State of Arizona as of the time of its admission to the Union... For all of these reasons, we have now decided that Bonelli’s application of federal common law to cases such as this must be overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly overrules Bonelli Cattle Co. v. Arizona, stating that its application of federal common law was incorrect and must be abandoned.

quote: And in Shively v. Bowlby, 152 U. S. 1 (1894), the Court recounted in extenso the many cases which had followed the doctrine of Pollard’s Lessee... In summarizing its holding, 152 U. S., at 57-58, the Court stated: 'The new States admitted into the Union since the adoption of the Constitution have the same rights as the original States in the tide waters, and in the lands under them, within their respective jurisdictions. The title and rights of riparian or littoral proprietors in the soil below [the] high water mark, therefore, are governed by the laws of the several States, subject to the rights granted to the United States by the Constitution.'
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on Shively v. Bowlby as supporting precedent for its holding, summarizing and applying its rule, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

cited_decision: Borax Consolidated, Ltd. v. Los Angeles
quote: In Borax, the city of Los Angeles brought suit to quiet title in certain land in Los Angeles Harbor... The Court went on to hold that the boundary between the upland and tideland was to be determined by federal law... This same principle would require that determination of the initial boundary between a riverbed, which the State acquired under the equal-footing doctrine, and riparian fast lands likewise be decided as a matter of federal law rather than state law. But that determination is solely for the purpose of fixing the boundaries of the riverbed acquired by the State at the time of its admission to the Union; thereafter the role of the equal-footing doctrine is ended, and the land is subject to the laws of the State.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Borax by limiting its application to the determination of initial boundaries at statehood, clarifying that it does not support the broader federal common law rule applied in Bonelli.

quote: In Barney v. Keokuk, 94 U. S. 324, 338 (1877), the Court extended the doctrine to waters which were nontidal but nonetheless navigable, consistent with its earlier extension of admiralty jurisdiction to such waters in The Propeller Genesee Chief v. Fitzhugh, 12 How. 443 (1852).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Barney v. Keokuk as part of the historical development of the law, using it to support its reasoning, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

cited_decision: County of St. Clair v. Lovingston
quote: This statement of the law was quoted by the Court in County of St. Clair v. Lovingston, 23 Wall. 46, 68 (1874).
rationale: The Acting Decision references County of St. Clair v. Lovingston as an example of the common law doctrine of accretion, but does not discuss, criticize, or limit its holding.

quote: Amici Utah and New Mexico also urge us to reconsider our decision in Hughes v. Washington, 389 U. S. 290 (1967). They advance the same reasons for such reconsideration as they do with respect to Bonelli. But Hughes was not cited by the Oregon courts below, and in Bonelli we expressly declined to rely upon it as a basis for our decision there, see 414 U. S., at 321 n. 11. We therefore have no occasion to address the issue. We are aware of the fact that Hughes gave to Borax the same sort of expansive construction as did Bonelli, but we are likewise aware that Hughes dealt with oceanfront property, a fact which the Court thought sufficiently different from the usual situation so as to justify a 'federal common law' rule of riparian proprietorship...
rationale: The Acting Decision expresses doubt about the continuing validity of Hughes v. Washington, noting its expansive reading and suggesting it may be overruled in the future, but stops short of formally overruling it.

cited_decision: Joy v. City of St. Louis
quote: For example, this Court has held that subsequent changes in the contour of the land, as well as subsequent transfers of the land, are governed by the state law. Joy v. St. Louis, 201 U. S. 332, 343 (1906).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Joy v. City of St. Louis as supporting precedent for the proposition that state law governs subsequent changes in land, but does not criticize or limit its authority.

quote: Wilcox v. Jackson, 13 Pet. 498 (1839); ... As long ago as 1839, the Court said: 'We hold the true principle to be this, that whenever the question in any Court, state or federal, is, whether a title to land which had once been the property of the United States has passed, that question must be resolved by the laws of the United States; but that whenever, according to those laws, the title shall have passed, then that property, like all other property in the state, is subject to state legislation; so far as that legislation is consistent with the admission that the title passed and vested according to the laws of the United States.' Wilcox v. Jackson, 13 Pet., at 517.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Wilcox v. Jackson as historical authority for the principle that state law governs property after federal title has passed, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its holding.

cited_decision: Pittsburgh Press Co. v. Pittsburgh Commission on Human Relations (1973)
quote: That simplistic approach, which by then had come under criticism or was regarded as of doubtful validity by Members of the Court, 16 was avoided in Pittsburgh Press Co. v. Human Relations Comm’n, 413 U. S. 376 (1973). There the Court upheld an ordinance prohibiting newspapers from listing employment advertisements in columns according to whether male or female employees were sought to be hired. The Court, to be sure, characterized the advertisements as 'classic examples of commercial speech,' id., at 385 , and a newspaper’s printing of the advertisements as of the same character. The Court, however, upheld the ordinance on the ground that the restriction it imposed was permissible because the discriminatory hirings proposed by the advertisements, and by their newspaper layout, were themselves illegal.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Pittsburgh Press by noting that the restriction there was upheld because the underlying conduct was illegal, whereas the present case involves truthful, legal activity. The distinction is explicitly drawn and the reasoning is not adopted as controlling.

quote: Last Term, in Bigelow v. Virginia, 421 U. S. 809 (1975), the notion of unprotected 'commercial speech' all but passed from the scene. We reversed a conviction for violation of a Virginia statute that made the circulation of any publication to encourage or promote the *760 processing of an abortion in Virginia a misdemeanor. ... We rejected the contention that the publication was unprotected because it was commercial. Chrestenserís continued validity was questioned, and its holding was described as 'distinctly a limited one' that merely upheld 'a reasonable regulation of the manner in which commercial advertising could be distributed.' 421 U. S., at 819.
rationale: Bigelow is cited as a recent precedent that questioned the validity of a blanket commercial speech exception, but the Acting Decision goes further and addresses the issue more directly. The case is mentioned as part of the doctrinal development.

cited_decision: New York Times Co. v. Sullivan (1964)
quote: Moreover, the Court several times has stressed that communications to which First Amendment protection was given were not 'purely commercial.' New York Times Co. v. Sullivan, 376 U. S. 254, 266 *759 (1964); Thomas v. Collins, 323 U. S., at 533 ; Murdock v. Pennsylvania, 319 U. S. 105, 111 (1943); Jamison v. Texas, 318 U. S. 413, 417 (1943).
rationale: New York Times Co. v. Sullivan is referenced as an example of the Court previously distinguishing between commercial and non-commercial speech, but it is not analyzed or criticized; it is simply mentioned as part of the historical context.

quote: Shortly after the phrase was added to the statute in 1968, 8 a suit seeking to enjoin its operation was instituted by a drug retailing company and one of its pharmacists. Although the First Amendment was invoked, the challenge appears to have been based primarily on the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment. In any event, the prohibition on drug price advertising was upheld. Patterson Drug Co. v. Kingery, 305 F. Supp. 821 (WD Va. 1969). ... The District Court seized on the identity of the plaintiff-appellees as consumers as a feature distinguishing the *755 present case from Patterson Drug Co. v. Kingery, supra. Because the unsuccessful plaintiffs in that earlier case were pharmacists, the court said, 'theirs was a prima facie commercial approach,' 373 F. Supp., at 686 . The present plaintiffs, on the other hand, were asserting an interest in their own health that was 'fundamentally deeper than a trade consideration.' Ibid.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Patterson Drug Co. v. Kingery on the basis of the parties involved and the nature of the challenge, noting that the earlier case was brought by pharmacists and focused on due process and equal protection, not the First Amendment rights of consumers.

quote: It was observed in Thornhill that 'the practices in a single factory may have economic repercussions upon a whole region and affect widespread systems of marketing.' Id., at 103 .
rationale: Thornhill v. Alabama is cited for a general principle about the economic impact of speech, but the Acting Decision does not analyze or alter its holding. It is used illustratively.

cited_decision: Virginia Citizens Consumer Council, Inc. v. State Board of Pharmacy (1974)
quote: The three-judge District Court declared the quoted portion of the statute 'void and of no effect,' Jurisdictional Statement, App. 1, and enjoined the defendant-appellants, the Virginia State Board of Pharmacy and the individual members of that Board, from enforcing it. 373 F. Supp. 683 (ED Va. 1974). We noted probable jurisdiction of the appeal. 420 U. S. 971 (1975).
rationale: The Acting Decision references the lower court decision as the procedural posture of the case under review, but does not discuss or critique its reasoning independently.

quote: In Valentine v. Chrestensen, supra, the Court upheld a New York statute that prohibited the distribution of any 'handbill, circular ... or other advertising matter whatsoever in or upon any street.' The Court concluded that, although the First Amendment would forbid the banning of all communication by handbill in the public thoroughfares, it imposed 'no such restraint on government as respects purely commercial advertising.' 316 U. S., at 54 . ... Chrestenserís continued validity was questioned, and its holding was described as 'distinctly a limited one' that merely upheld 'a reasonable regulation of the manner in which commercial advertising could be distributed.' 421 U. S., at 819 .
rationale: The Acting Decision directly questions the continued validity of Valentine v. Chrestensen, describes its holding as limited, and moves away from its reasoning, thus criticizing its precedential value.

cited_decision: Williamson v. Lee Optical of Oklahoma, Inc. (1955)
quote: The District Court recognized that this Court had upheld — against federal constitutional challenges other than on First Amendment grounds — state restric *756 tions on the advertisement of prices for optometrists’ services, Head v. New Mexico Board, 374 U. S. 424 (1963), for eyeglass frames, Williamson v. Lee Optical Co., 348 U. S. 483 (1955), and for dentists’ services, Semler v. Dental Examiners, 294 U. S. 608 (1935). 13 ... The challenge now made, however, is based on the First Amendment. This casts the Board’s justifications in a different light, for on close inspection it is seen that the State’s protectiveness of its citizens rests in large measure on the advantages of their being kept in ignorance.
rationale: Williamson v. Lee Optical is distinguished because it addressed due process and equal protection, not the First Amendment, and the Acting Decision finds the First Amendment challenge to be materially different.

cited_decision: National Labor Relations Board v. Gissel Packing Co. (1969)
quote: It has long been settled that both the employee and the employer are protected by the First Amendment when they express themselves on the merits of the dispute in order to influence its outcome. See, e. g., NLRB v. Gissel Packing Co., 395 U. S. 575, 617-618 (1969); NLRB v. Virginia Electric & Power Co., 314 U. S. 469, 477 (1941); AFL v. Swing, 312 U. S. 321, 325-326 (1941); Thornhill v. Alabama, 310 U. S., at 102 .
rationale: Gissel Packing Co. is cited as an example of First Amendment protection in the labor context, but the Acting Decision does not analyze or alter its holding. It is used to support a general proposition.

cited_decision: Dun & Bradstreet, Inc. v. C. R. Grove, Trustee (1971)
quote: See Dun & Bradstreet, Inc. v. Grove, 404 U. S. 898, 904-906 (1971) (Douglas, J., dissenting from denial of certiorari).
rationale: Dun & Bradstreet, Inc. v. Grove is cited only in reference to a dissenting opinion and is not discussed or analyzed by the Acting Decision. It is merely mentioned.

quote: In Michelin the Court upheld the application of a general ad valorem property tax to imported tires and tubes. The Court surveyed the history and purposes of the Import-Export-Clause to determine, for the first time, which taxes fell within the absolute ban on 'Imposts or Duties.' ... Michelin initiated a different approach to Import-Export Clause cases. It ignored the simple question whether the tires and tubes were imports. Instead, it analyzed the nature of the tax to determine whether it was an 'Impost or Duty.' 423 U. S., at 279, 290-294.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses and applies the analytical framework from Michelin, using it as precedent for its own analysis, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority. Thus, Michelin is mentioned and followed.

cited_decision: Complete Auto Transit, Inc. v. Brady (1977)
quote: We conclude that Complete Auto Transit, Inc. v. Brady, where the Court held that a State under appropriate conditions may tax directly the privilege of conducting interstate business, requires such rejection. ... The principles of Complete Auto also lead us now to question the underpinnings of the Stevedoring Cases.
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on Complete Auto as controlling precedent and uses its reasoning to overrule earlier cases, but does not criticize or limit Complete Auto itself. It is mentioned as authoritative and applied.

cited_decision: Joseph v. Carter & Weekes Stevedoring Co. (1947)
quote: To the extent that Puget Sound Stevedoring Co. v. State Tax Comm’n and Joseph v. Carter & Weekes Stevedoring Co. stand to the contrary, each is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Joseph v. Carter & Weekes Stevedoring Co. is overruled to the extent it conflicts with the new analysis, thus nullifying its precedential value.

quote: In Canton R. Co. v. Rogan, 340 U. S. 511 (1951), the Court upheld a gross-receipts tax on a steam railroad operating exclusively within the Port of Baltimore. ... The Court rejected that argument primarily on the ground that immunity of services incidental to importing and exporting was not so broad as the immunity of the goods themselves.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses and applies the reasoning from Canton Railroad v. Rogan as supportive precedent, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority. It is mentioned and followed.

cited_decision: Western Live Stock v. Bureau of Revenue (1938)
quote: Petitioner replied that this Court had invited rejection *741 of those cases by casting doubt on the Commerce Clause analysis that distinguished between direct and indirect taxation of interstate commerce. Id., at 25-37, citing, e. g., Interstate Pipe Line Co. v. Stone, 337 U. S. 662 (1949); Western Live Stock v. Bureau of Revenue, 303 U. S. 250 (1938). ... The Court repeatedly has sustained taxes that are applied to activity with a substantial nexus with the State, that are fairly apportioned, that do not discriminate against interstate commerce, and that are fairly related to the services provided by the State. E. g., General Motors Corp. v. Washington, 377 U. S. 436 (1964); Northwestern Cement Co. v. Minnesota, 358 U. S. 450 (1959); Memphis Gas Co. v. Stone, 335 U. S. 80 (1948); Wisconsin v. J. C. Penney Co., 311 U. S. 435 (1940); see Complete Auto Transit, Inc. v. Brady, 430 U. S., at 279 , and n. 8.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Western Live Stock as part of the line of cases supporting the modern approach to state taxation and the Commerce Clause, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority. It is mentioned as supportive precedent.

cited_decision: Puget Sound Stevedoring Co. v. State Tax Commission (1937)
quote: To the extent that Puget Sound Stevedoring Co. v. State Tax Comm’n and Joseph v. Carter & Weekes Stevedoring Co. stand to the contrary, each is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Puget Sound Stevedoring Co. v. State Tax Commission is overruled to the extent it conflicts with the new analysis, thus nullifying its precedential value.

quote: But the opinion in Brown v. Maryland cannot properly be read to propose such a broad definition of 'imposts' or 'duties.' ... Despite the language and objectives of the Import-Export Clause, and despite the limited nature of the holding in Brown v. Maryland, the Court in Low v. Austin ignored the warning that the boundary between the power of States to tax persons and property within their jurisdictions and the limitations on the power of the States to impose imposts or duties with respect to 'imports' was a subtle and difficult line which must be drawn, as the cases arise.
rationale: The Acting Decision carefully analyzes Brown v. Maryland, explains its limited holding, and distinguishes its facts and reasoning from the present case, concluding that Brown does not control the outcome here.

quote: It follows from the foregoing that Low v. Austin was wrongly decided. That decision therefore must be, and is, overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Low v. Austin is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value.

cited_decision: Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Bowers (1959)
quote: Taxes imposed after an initial sale, after the breakup of the shipping packages, or the moment goods imported for use are committed to current operational needs are also all likely to have an incidental effect on the volume of goods imported; yet all are permissible. See, e. g., Waring v. The Mayor, 8 Wall. 110 (1869) (taxation after initial sale); May v. New Orleans, supra (taxation after breakup of shipping packages); Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Bowers, 358 U. S. 534 (1959) (taxation of goods committed to current operational needs by manufacturer).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Bowers as an example of permissible taxation but does not analyze, criticize, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

quote: Low v. Austin compounded the error in misreading the Brown opinion by the further error of misreading the views of Mr. Chief Justice Taney as expressed in his opinion in the License Cases, 5 How. 504 (1847) (six Justices wrote separately in the cases).
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions the License Cases (which includes Thurlow v. Massachusetts) in the context of discussing Chief Justice Taney's views, but does not analyze or alter the holding of Thurlow v. Massachusetts.

quote: The automatic standing, rule of Jones v. United States, supra, is therefore overruled.
rationale: The lead opinion explicitly states that the automatic standing rule established in Jones v. United States is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value on this point.

quote: This Court has held that testimony given by a defendant in support of a motion to suppress cannot be admitted as evi-denee of his guilt at trial. Simmons v. United States, 390 U. S. 377 (1968).
rationale: Simmons is discussed as a development that eliminated the self-incrimination dilemma central to Jones, but its reasoning is neither criticized nor overruled; it is cited as controlling law.

quote: Thus, as we stated in Brown v. United States, 411 U. S., at 228 , '[t]he self-incrimination dilemma, so central to the Jones decision, can no longer occur under the prevailing interpretation of the Constitution [in Simmons].'
rationale: Brown v. United States is referenced to support the Court's analysis of the self-incrimination issue, but its reasoning is not criticized or altered; it is used to clarify the current state of the law.

quote: The same argument has been rejected by this Court as a sufficient basis for allowing persons whose Fourth Amendment rights were not violated to nevertheless claim the benefits of the exclusionary rule. In Alderman v. United States, 394 U. S., at 174-175 , we explicitly stated: ...
rationale: Alderman is cited to reinforce the Court's position on the limits of the exclusionary rule, but the decision is not criticized or limited; it is referenced as settled authority.

quote: Our consideration of the foundations for the privilege and its history satisfy us that reason and experience’ no longer justify so sweeping a rule as that found acceptable by the Court in Hawkins. Accordingly, we conclude that the existing rule should be modified so that the witness-spouse alone has a privilege to refuse to testify adversely; the witness may be neither compelled to testify nor foreclosed from testifying.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly rejects and replaces the rule established in Hawkins, stating that it is no longer justified and modifying the law so that the privilege is vested only in the witness-spouse. This constitutes an overruling of Hawkins.

quote: Indeed, it was not until 1933, in Funk v. United States, 290 U. S. 371, that this Court abolished the testimonial disqualification in the federal courts, so as to permit the spouse of a defendant to testify in the defendant’s behalf. Funk, however, left undisturbed the rule that either spouse could prevent the other from giving adverse testimony.
rationale: Funk is referenced for historical context regarding the evolution of spousal testimonial privileges, but its holding is not criticized, overruled, or otherwise materially altered.

quote: Accord, Wyatt v. United States, 362 U. S. 525, 528 (1960). 7 However, in so doing, the Court made clear that its decision was not meant to 'foreclose whatever changes in the rule may eventually be dictated by ‘reason and experience.’' 358 U. S., at 79.
rationale: Wyatt is cited as an accord to Hawkins and for noting an exception to the Hawkins rule, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter Wyatt's holding.

quote: This Court recognized just such a confidential marital communications privilege in Wolfle v. United States, 291 U. S. 7 (1934), and in Blau v. United States, 340 U. S. 332 (1951). In neither case, however, did the Court adopt the Wigmore view that the communications privilege be substituted in place of the privilege against adverse spousal testimony. The privilege as to confidential marital communications is not at issue in the instant case; accordingly, our holding today does not disturb Wolfle and Blau.
rationale: Wolfle is referenced to clarify that the confidential marital communications privilege remains undisturbed by the present decision, indicating it is merely mentioned.

quote: It was applied by this Court in Stein v. Bowman, 13 Pet. 209, 220-223 (1839), in Graves v. United States, 150 U. S. 118 (1893), and again in Jin Fuey Moy v. United States, 254 U. S. 189, 195 (1920), where it was deemed so well established a proposition as to 'hardly requir[e] mention.'
rationale: Stein is cited as an example of the historical application of the spousal disqualification rule, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, distinguish, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: This Court recognized just such a confidential marital communications privilege in Wolfle v. United States, 291 U. S. 7 (1934), and in Blau v. United States, 340 U. S. 332 (1951). ... The privilege as to confidential marital communications is not at issue in the instant case; accordingly, our holding today does not disturb Wolfle and Blau.
rationale: Blau is referenced to clarify that the confidential marital communications privilege is not affected by the present decision, indicating it is merely mentioned.

quote: Geer v. Connecticut, 161 U. S. 519 (1896), on which the Court of Criminal Appeals relied, is overruled. In that circumstance, § 4-115 (B) cannot survive appellant’s Commerce Clause attack. ... We hold that time has revealed the error of the early resolution reached in that case, and accordingly Geer is today overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Geer v. Connecticut is overruled, both in summary and in the body of the opinion, leaving no doubt as to its treatment.

cited_decision: Lacoste v. Department of Conservation of Louisiana (1924)
quote: The law challenged in Foster-Fountain Packing Co. was passed in July 1926. The state legislature may have been encouraged to take such action by certain language in Lacoste v. Louisiana Dept. of Conservation, 263 U. S. 545 (1924), language also relied on by the Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals in this case. ... Nevertheless, Lacoste expressly declined to uphold the tax 'by virtue of the power of the State to prohibit, and therefore to condition, the removal of wild game from the State.' Ibid. Rather than reach this issue, the Court upheld the measure as a valid police regulation designed to conserve and protect wild animals, noting that the tax applied to all skins taken within the State, whether kept within the State or shipped out. Id., at 550-551. Thus, despite its citation of Geer, Lacoste is actually more compatible with the cases following the views of the Justices dissenting in Geer.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Lacoste by explaining that, although it cited Geer, it was actually decided on different grounds and is more compatible with later cases that rejected Geer's rationale.

quote: Foster-Fountain Packing struck down the statute as economic protectionism abhorrent to the Commerce Clause. The analysis resembled that employed in the natural gas cases, which were cited with approval, id., at 10-11, 13. ... Geer was distinguished on the ground that there '[n]o part of the game was permitted by the statute to become an article of interstate commerce.' 278 U. S., at 12.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses how Foster-Fountain Packing Co. v. Haydel moved away from Geer's reasoning and distinguished Geer on specific grounds, using a different analytical approach.

cited_decision: H. P. Hood & Sons, Inc. v. Du Mond (1949)
quote: See H. P. Hood & Sons, Inc. v. Du Mond, 336 U. S. 525, 533-534 (1949). The Commerce Clause has accordingly been interpreted by this Court not only as an authorization for congressional action, but also, even in the absence of a conflicting federal statute, as a restriction on permissible state regulation.
rationale: The Acting Decision references H. P. Hood & Sons, Inc. v. Du Mond to provide background on Commerce Clause jurisprudence, but does not analyze or alter its holding.

cited_decision: West v. Kansas Natural Gas Co. (1911)
quote: The erosion of Geer began only 15 years after it was decided. A Commerce Clause challenge was addressed to an Oklahoma statute designed to prohibit the transportation beyond the State of natural gas produced by wells within the State. West v. Kansas Natural Gas Co., 221 U. S. 229 (1911). ... In subsequent Commerce Clause challenges to state regulation of exports of natural resources, the West analysis emerged as the dominant approach.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses West v. Kansas Natural Gas Co. as part of the historical development of Commerce Clause doctrine, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: Today’s principle is that stated in Pike v. Bruce Church, Inc., 397 U. S. 137, 142 (1970): 'Where the statute regulates evenhandedly to effectuate a legitimate local public interest, and its effects on interstate commerce are only incidental, it will be upheld unless the burden imposed on such commerce is clearly excessive in relation to the putative local benefits. ...'
rationale: The Acting Decision quotes and applies the balancing test from Pike v. Bruce Church, Inc. as the controlling standard, but does not criticize or limit it.

quote: Douglas v. Seacoast Products, Inc., 431 U. S. 265 (1977), dispelled any doubts on that score. In rejecting the argument that Virginia’s 'ownership' of fish swimming in its territorial waters empowered the State to forbid fishing by federally licensed ships owned by nonresidents while permitting residents to fish, Seacoast Products explicitly embraced the analysis of the Geer dissenters...
rationale: The Acting Decision references Douglas v. Seacoast Products, Inc. as part of the evolution away from Geer's rationale, but does not criticize or limit its holding.

cited_decision: Baldwin v. Fish and Game Comm'n of Mont. (1978)
quote: Baldwin v. Montana Fish & Game Comm’n, 436 U. S. 371, 385-386 (1978). See, e. g., Douglas v. Seacoast Products, Inc., 431 U. S. 265 , 285 n. 21 (1977).
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions Baldwin v. Montana Fish & Game Comm’n as an example of a case recognizing limits on state power, but does not analyze or alter its authority.

cited_decision: City of Philadelphia v. New Jersey (1978)
quote: This formulation was employed only last Term to strike down New Jersey’s attempt to 'conserve' the natural resource of landfill areas within the State for the disposal of waste generated within the State. Philadelphia v. New Jersey, 437 U. S. 617, 624 (1978).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites City of Philadelphia v. New Jersey as a recent application of the Commerce Clause balancing test, but does not criticize or limit its holding.

quote: Toomer v. Witsell, 334 U. S. 385, 402 (1948), which struck down as violations of the Commerce Clause and the Privileges and *334 Immunities Clause certain South Carolina laws discriminating against out-of-state commercial fishermen: 'The whole ownership theory, in fact, is now generally regarded as but a fiction expressive in legal shorthand of the importance to its people that a State have power to preserve and regulate the exploitation of an important resource.'
rationale: The Acting Decision references Toomer v. Witsell as part of the doctrinal shift away from the state ownership theory, but does not criticize or limit its holding.

cited_decision: United States v. Martin Linen Supply Co. (1977)
quote: Only last Term, this Court relied upon these precedents in United States v. Martin Linen Supply Co., 430 U. S. 564 (1977), and held that the Government could not appeal the granting of a motion to acquit pursuant to Fed. Rule Crim. Proc. 29 where a second trial would be required upon remand. The Court, quoting language in Ball, supra, at 671, stated: 'Perhaps the most fundamental rule in the history of double jeopardy jurisprudence has been that [a] verdict of acquittal . . . could not be reviewed, on error or otherwise, without putting [a defendant] twice in jeopardy, and thereby violating the Constitution.' 430 U. S., at 571.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Martin Linen as precedent for the rule that acquittals cannot be appealed if a new trial would be required, but does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its holding. It is used as supporting authority and not distinguished or limited.

quote: However, only last Term, in Lee, supra, the Government was permitted to institute a second prosecution after a midtrial dismissal of an indictment. The Court found the circumstances presented by that case 'functionally indistinguishable from a declaration of mistrial.' 432 U. S., at 31. Thus, Lee demonstrated that, at least in some cases, the dismissal of an indictment may be treated on the same basis as the declaration of a mistrial.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Lee by explaining that Lee involved circumstances similar to a mistrial, whereas the present case involves a midtrial dismissal on the defendant's motion for reasons unrelated to guilt or innocence. The distinction is drawn to clarify why the rule in Lee does not control the outcome here.

quote: In our first encounter with the new statute, we concluded that 'Congress intended to remove all statutory, barriers to Government appeals and to allow appeals whenever the Constitution would permit.' United States v. Wilson, 420 U. S. 332, 337 (1975).
rationale: Wilson is cited for its interpretation of the statutory framework for government appeals, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its holding. It is used as background authority.

quote: We have therefore decided to overrule Jenkins, and thus to reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals in this case... Accordingly, the contrary holding of United States v. Jenkins is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Jenkins is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value.

quote: As this Court has described the purpose underlying the prohibition against double jeopardy: 'The underlying idea, one that is deeply ingrained in at least the Anglo-American system of jurisprudence, is that the State with all its resources and power should not be allowed to make repeated attempts to convict an individual for an alleged offense, thereby subjecting him to embarrassment, expense and ordeal and compelling him to live in a continuing state of anxiety and insecurity, as well as enhancing the possibility that even though innocent he may be found guilty.' Green, supra, at 187-188.
rationale: Green is quoted for its articulation of the policy behind the Double Jeopardy Clause, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its holding. It is used as supporting authority.

quote: And, in the very first case presenting the issues, United States v. Ball, 163 U. S. 662 (1896), the Court established principles that have been adhered to ever since.
rationale: Ball is referenced as a foundational case for double jeopardy principles, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: In our recent decision in Arizona v. Washington, 434 U. S. 497 (1978), we reviewed this Court’s attempts to give content to the term 'manifest necessity.' That case, like Doumum, supra, 8, arose from a motion of the prosecution for a mistrial, and we noted that the trial court’s discretion must be exercised with a, careful regard for the interests first described in United States v. Perez. Arizona v. Washington, supra, at 514-516.
rationale: Arizona v. Washington is cited for its discussion of 'manifest necessity' in mistrial situations, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: Because of the statutory restrictions upon Government appeals in criminal cases, this Court in the years after Ball was faced with that question only in unusual circumstances, such as were present in Kepner v. United States, 195 U. S. 100 (1904).
rationale: Kepner is referenced as historical precedent for double jeopardy principles, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: Since up to that point Government appeals had been subject to statutory restrictions independent of the Double Jeopardy Clause, our previous cases construing the statute proved to be of little assistance in determining when the Double Jeopardy Clause of the Fifth Amendment would *86 prohibit further prosecution. A detailed canvass of the history of the double jeopardy principles in English and American law led us to conclude that the Double Jeopardy Clause was primarily 'directed at the threat of multiple prosecutions,' and posed no bar to Government appeals 'where those appeals would not require a new trial.' Id., at 342.
rationale: Serfass is cited for its analysis of the Double Jeopardy Clause and government appeals, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: Such a motion ,by the defendant is deemed to be a deliberate election on his part to forgo his valued right to have his guilt or innocence determined before the first trier of fact. 'The important considera *94 tion, for purposes of the Double Jeopardy Clause, is that the defendant retain primary control over the course to be followed in the event of such error.' United States v. Dinitz, 424 U. S. 600, 609 (1976). But '[t]he Double Jeopardy Clause does protect a defendant against governmental actions intended to provoke mistrial requests and thereby to subject defendants to the substantial burdens imposed by multiple prosecutions.' Id., at 611.
rationale: Jorn is cited for its discussion of the defendant's control over mistrial motions and double jeopardy, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: More than 50 years later, in Fong Foo v. United States, 369 U. S. 141 (1962), this Court reviewed the issuance of a writ of mandamus by the Court of Appeals for the First Circuit instructing a District Court to vacate certain judgments of acquittal. Although indicating its agreement with the Court of Appeals that the judgments had been entered erroneously, this Court nonetheless held that a second trial was barred by the Double Jeopardy Clause. Id., at 143.
rationale: Fong Foo is referenced as precedent for the rule that acquittals, even if erroneous, bar retrial, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: That other day has come and we now overrule Monroe v. Pape, supra, insofar as it holds that local governments are wholly immune from suit under § 1983.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that it is overruling Monroe v. Pape to the extent that it held local governments are immune from suit under § 1983, thus directly nullifying a key holding of Monroe.

quote: Of legislation mentioned by Shellabarger, the closest analog of the Sherman amendment, ironically, was the statute implementing the fugitives from justice and fugitive slave provisions of Art. IV — the Act of Feb. 12, 1793, 1 Stat. 302 — the constitutionality of which had been sustained in 1842, in Prigg v. Pennsylvania, 16 Pet. 539.
rationale: Prigg v. Pennsylvania is referenced as historical context for constitutional arguments about federal power, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes, overrules, nor distinguishes it.

quote: Nothing we say today affects the conclusion reached in Moor, see 411 U. S., at 703-704, that 42 U. S. C. § 1988 cannot be used to create a federal cause of action where § 1983 does not otherwise provide one...
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that its holding does not affect the conclusion in Moor regarding the use of § 1988, thereby limiting Moor's scope but not overruling or criticizing it.

cited_decision: 12 Fair empl.prac.cas. 836, 11 Empl. Prac. Dec. P 10,755 Jane Monell v. Department of Social Services of the City of New York, Defendants (1976)
quote: For the reasons stated above, the judgment of the Court of Appeals is Reversed.
rationale: The Acting Decision is a review of this lower court decision and explicitly reverses its judgment.

quote: See, e. g., Gelpcke v. Dubuque, 1 Wall. 175 (1864); Von Hoffman v. City of Quincy, 4 Wall. 535 (1867); Riggs v. Johnson County, 6 Wall. 166 (1868); Weber v. Lee County, 6 Wall. 210 (1868); Supervisors v. Rogers, 7 Wall. 175 (1869); Benbow v. Iowa City, 7 Wall. 313 (1869); Supervisors v. Durant, 9 Wall. 415 (1870).
rationale: Supervisors v. Durant is listed among several cases as historical context for federal enforcement against municipalities, but is not discussed or analyzed further.

quote: Now, only the other day, the Supreme Court . . . decided [in Collector v. Day, 11 Wall. 113 (1871)] that there is no power in the Government of the United States, under its authority to tax, to tax the salary of a State officer.
rationale: Collector v. Day is cited as an example of then-recent Supreme Court doctrine on federalism, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or distinguish it.

quote: And although in many of these cases jurisdiction was not questioned, we ought not 'disregard the implications of an exercise of judicial authority assumed to be proper for [100] years.' ... And although in many of these cases jurisdiction was not questioned, we ought not 'disregard the implications of an exercise of judicial authority assumed to be proper for [100] years.' ... especially as Monroe’s, immunizing principle was extended to suits for injunctive relief in City of Kenosha v. Bruno, 412 U. S. 507 (1973). ... Nothing we say today affects the conclusion reached in ... City of Kenosha, see 412 U. S., at 513, that nothing . . . suggest [s] that the generic word person’ in § 1983 was intended to have a bifurcated application to municipal corporations depending on the nature of the relief sought against them.
rationale: The Acting Decision notes that its holding does not disturb the specific conclusion in City of Kenosha regarding the application of 'person' in § 1983, thus limiting its own impact on that precedent.

cited_decision: Bivens v. Six Unknown Named Agents of Federal Bureau of Narcotics (1971)
quote: lest our decision that such bodies are subject to suit under § 1983 'be drained of meaning,' Scheuer v. Rhodes, 416 U. S. 232, 248 (1974). Cf. Bivens v. Six Unknown Fed. Narcotics Agents, 403 U. S. 388, 397-398 (1971).
rationale: Bivens is cited in a parenthetical as a comparison for the principle that a right without a remedy is meaningless, but is not otherwise discussed or analyzed.

cited_decision: Cleveland Board of Education v. LaFleur (1974)
quote: The court did conclude, however, that the acts complained of were unconstitutional under LaFleur, supra.
rationale: LaFleur is referenced as the controlling precedent for the lower court's finding of unconstitutionality, but the Acting Decision does not analyze or alter its holding.

cited_decision: Mt. Healthy City School District Board of Education v. Doyle (1977)
quote: we indicated in Mt. Healthy City Board of Education v. Doyle, 429 U. S. 274, 279 (1977), last Term that the question presented here was open and would be decided 'another day.' That other day has come...
rationale: Mt. Healthy is cited for the proposition that the question of municipal liability under § 1983 was left open, but the Acting Decision does not criticize or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: Ex parte Virginia, 100 U. S. 339, 347-348 (1880); ... Indeed, a Circuit Judge, writing in 1873 in what is apparently the first reported case under § 1, read the Dictionary Act in precisely this way in a case involving a corporate plaintiff and a municipal defendant. ... There is certainly no constitutional impediment to municipal liability. 'The Tenth Amendment’s reservation of nondelegated powers to the States is not implicated by a federal-court judgment enforcing the express prohibitions of unlawful state conduct enacted by the Fourteenth Amendment.' Milliken v. Bradley, 433 U. S. 267, 291 (1977); see Ex parte Virginia, 100 U. S., at 347-348.
rationale: Ex Parte Virginia is cited as supporting authority for the proposition that federal courts can enforce the Fourteenth Amendment against state actors, but is not otherwise discussed or altered.

quote: Similarly, since this case clearly involves official policy and does not involve respondeat superior, we do not assay a view on how our cases which have relied on that aspect of Monroe that is overruled today — Moor v. County of Alameda, 411 U. S. 693 (1973); City of Kenosha v. Bruno, 412 U. S. 507 (1973); and Aldinger v. Howard, 427 U. S. 1 (1976) — should have been decided on a correct view of § 1983.
rationale: The Acting Decision acknowledges that its holding may affect Aldinger but expressly declines to decide how Aldinger should be treated in light of the new rule, thereby limiting its own impact on Aldinger.

cited_decision: State Ex Rel. Douglas v. Sporhase (1981)
quote: The Nebraska Supreme Court affirmed. 208 Neb. 703 , 305 N. W. 2d 614 (1981). ... The reciprocity requirement of Neb. Rev. Stat. §46-613.01 (1978) violates the Commerce Clause. We leave to the state courts the question whether the invalid portion is severable. The judgment of the Nebraska Supreme Court is reversed, and the case is remanded for proceedings not inconsistent with this opinion.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that it is reversing the judgment of the Nebraska Supreme Court in State Ex Rel. Douglas v. Sporhase (1981), making the treatment 'Reversed.'

cited_decision: City of Altus, Oklahoma v. Carr (1966)
quote: In summarily affirming the District Court in City of Altus, we did not necessarily adopt the court’s reasoning.
