S., at 750, and went on to hold that the cause-and-prejudice standard applicable to failure to raise a particular claim should apply as well to failure to appeal at all. Ibid.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Coleman v. Thompson as part of the development of the cause-and-prejudice standard, but does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

quote: Because the holding of Townsend v. Sain that Fay v. Noia’s deliberate bypass standard is applicable in a case like this had not been reversed, it is quite understandable that the Court of Appeals applied that standard in this case. However, in light of more recent decisions of this Court, Townsend’s holding in this respect must be overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that the relevant holding of Townsend v. Sain is overruled, thus nullifying its precedential value on this point.

quote: In McCleskey v. Zant, 499 U. S. 467 (1991), we held that the same standard used to excuse state procedural defaults should be applied in habeas corpus cases where abuse of the writ is claimed by the government. Id., at 493.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites McCleskey v. Zant as supporting authority for the cause-and-prejudice standard, but does not criticize or alter its holding.

quote: It also expressly stated that the rules it was announcing 'must be considered to supersede, to the extent of any inconsistencies, the opinions in Brown v. Allen[, 344 U. S. 443 (1953)].' Id., at 312. This was necessary because Brown was inconsistent with the holding of Townsend regarding habeas petitioners who failed to adequately develop federal claims in state-court proceedings.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Brown v. Allen as being inconsistent with Townsend and distinguishes its approach, but does not overrule or criticize it directly.

quote: In Wainwright v. Sykes, 433 U. S. 72 (1977), we rejected the application of Fay’s standard of 'knowing waiver' or 'deliberate bypass' to excuse a petitioner’s failure to comply with a state contemporaneous-objection rule, stating that the state rule deserved more respect than the Fay standard accorded it. 433 U. S., at 88.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Wainwright v. Sykes as part of the doctrinal evolution toward the cause-and-prejudice standard, but does not criticize or alter its holding.

quote: The writ strikes at finality of a state criminal conviction, a matter of particular importance in a federal system. Id., at 491, citing Murray v. Carrier, 477 U. S. 478, 487 (1986).
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Murray v. Carrier as supporting authority for the cause-and-prejudice standard, but does not criticize or alter its holding.

quote: Accordingly, the decision of the Court of Appeals is reversed, and the cause is remanded to the District Court for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
rationale: The Acting Decision directly overturns the outcome of the cited lower court decision.

quote: We have consistently reaffirmed that the 'cause-and-prejudice' standard embodies the correct accommodation between the competing concerns implicated in a federal court’s habeas power. Reed v. Ross, 468 U. S. 1, 11 (1984);
rationale: The Acting Decision references Reed v. Ross as supporting authority for the cause-and-prejudice standard, but does not criticize or alter its holding.

quote: In Francis v. Henderson, 425 U. S. 536 (1976), we acknowledged a federal court’s power to entertain an application for habeas even where the claim has been procedurally waived in state proceedings, but nonetheless examined the appropriateness of the exercise of that power and recognized, as we had in Fay, that considerations of comity and concerns for the orderly administration of criminal justice may in some circumstances require a federal court to forgo the exercise of its habeas corpus power. 425 U. S., at 538-539.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Francis v. Henderson as part of the doctrinal development, but does not criticize or alter its holding.

quote: VI Bmmblett is hereby overruled. We hold that a federal court is neither a “department” nor an “agency” within the meaning of § 1001.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Bramblett is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value regarding the interpretation of § 1001.

quote: Stare decisis is “a basic self-governing principle within the Judicial Branch, which is entrusted with the sensitive and difficult task of fashioning and preserving a jurisprudential system that is not based upon ‘an arbitrary discretion.’” Patterson v. McLean Credit Union, 491 U. S. 164, 172 (1989) (quoting The Federalist No. 78, p. 490 (H. Lodge ed. 1888) (A. Hamilton)). See also Planned Parenthood of Southeastern Pa. v. Casey, 505 U. S. 833, 854-855 (1992) (joint opinion of O’Connor, Kennedy, and Souter, JJ.).
rationale: Patterson is cited for a general principle about stare decisis and not discussed or altered in any way; it is merely referenced for its statement on precedent.

cited_decision: Daniel Jackson Oliver Wendel Holmes Morgan v. United States (1962)
quote: The seeds of the exception were planted by the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit only seven years after Bramblett was decided. In Morgan v. United States, 309 F. 2d 234 (1962), cert. denied, 373 U. S. 917 (1963), the defendant, who had falsely held himself out to be a bona fide member of the bar, was prosecuted on three counts of violating § 1001 for concealing from the court his name, identity, *709 and nonadmission to the bar. After first acknowledging that, but for Bramblett , it might well have accepted the argument that Congress did not intend § 1001 to apply to the courts, the Court of Appeals upheld the conviction.
rationale: Morgan is described as the origin of the 'judicial function exception' and its reasoning is summarized, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes nor overrules it; it is discussed as part of the historical development.

cited_decision: United States v. James Ralph Erhardt (1967)
quote: Relying on Morgan , the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit reversed a conviction several years later “because § 1001 does not apply to the introduction of false documents as evidence in a criminal proceeding.” United States v. Erhardt, 381 F. 2d 173, 175 (1967) (per curiam).
rationale: Erhardt is referenced as an example of a case applying the judicial function exception, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: Respect for precedent is strongest “in the area of statutory construction, where Congress is free to change this Court’s interpretation *712 of its legislation.” Illinois Brick Co. v. Illinois, 431 U. S. 720, 736 (1977).
rationale: Illinois Brick is cited for a general principle about statutory stare decisis and is not discussed or altered; it is merely referenced for its statement on precedent.

cited_decision: Burnet v. Coronado Oil & Gas Co. (1932)
quote: Justice Brandéis’ dissenting opinion in Burnet v. Coronado Oil & Gas Co., 285 U. S. 393 (1932), made the point this way: “Stare decisis is usually the wise policy, because in most matters it is more important that the applicable rule of law be settled than that it be settled right. This is commonly true even where the error is a matter of serious concern, provided correction can be had by legislation.” Id., at 406 (citations omitted).
rationale: Burnet is quoted for a general principle about the value of stare decisis and is not otherwise discussed or affected by the Acting Decision.

cited_decision: Garcia v. San Antonio Metropolitan Transit Authority (1985)
quote: The Tenth Amendment limits on Congress’ authority to regulate state activities are set out in Garcia v. San Antonio Metropolitan Transit Authority, 469 U. S. 528 (1985). Garcia holds that the limits are structural, not substantive— i. e., that States must find their protection from congressional regulation through the national political process, not through judicially defined spheres of unregulable state activity. Id., at 537-554.
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on Garcia as the controlling precedent for Tenth Amendment analysis, summarizing its holding and applying its framework, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: For a time, only the States’ governmental, as opposed to proprietary, activities enjoyed tax immunity, see e. g., Helvering v. Powers, 293 U. S. 214, 227 (1934); South Carolina v. United States, 199 U. S. 437, 454-463 (1905), but this distinction was subsequently abandoned as untenable by all eight Justices participating in *524 New York v. United States, 326 U. S. 572 (1946). See id., at 579-581, 583 (opinion of Frankfurter, J., joined by Rutledge, J.); id., at 586 (Stone, C. J., concurring, joined by Reed, Murphy, and Burton, JJ.); id., at 591 (Douglas, J., dissenting, joined by Black, J.).
rationale: The Acting Decision references New York v. United States to illustrate the historical development of tax immunity doctrine, but does not criticize, distinguish, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

cited_decision: Graves v. New York Ex Rel. O'Keefe (1939)
quote: In Graves v. New York ex rel. O’Keefe, 306 U. S. 466 (1939), the Court announced: “The theory . . . that a tax on income is legally or economically a tax on its source, is no longer tenable.” Id., at 480.
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Graves as a key authority for the modern doctrine rejecting the burden theory of intergovernmental tax immunity, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: Prior to that the Court had already confined Collector v. Day to its facts in Helvering v. Gerhardt, 304 U. S. 405 (1938), which upheld the constitutionality of a federal tax on the salaries of state employees involved in state construction projects.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Helvering v. Gerhardt as part of the historical development of the doctrine, using it to support its reasoning, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

cited_decision: Federal Energy Regulatory Commission v. Mississippi (1982)
quote: They cite FERC v. Mississippi, 456 U. S. 742 (1982), which left open the possibility that the Tenth Amendment might set some limits on Congress’ power to compel States to regulate on behalf of federal interests, id., at 761-764 . ... Because, by hypothesis, § 310 effectively prohibits issuing unregistered bonds, it presents the very situation FERC distinguished from a commandeering of state regulatory machinery: the extent to which the Tenth Amendment “shields the States from generally applicable federal regulations.” 456 U. S., at 759.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes FERC by explaining that the statute at issue in FERC involved commandeering state regulatory machinery, whereas the present case involves generally applicable federal regulation of state activities.

cited_decision: Indian Motocycle Co. v. United States (1931)
quote: The commonality of the rationale underlying all these immunities for government contracts *520 was highlighted by Indian Motocycle, 283 U. S. 570 (1931). In that case, the Court reviewed the then current status of intergovernmental tax immunity doctrine, observing that a tax on interest earned on a state or federal bond was unconstitutional because it would burden the exercise of the government’s power to borrow money and that a tax on the salary of a State or Federal Government employee was unconstitutional because it would burden the government’s power to obtain the employee’s services. Id., at 576-578.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Indian Motocycle Co. v. United States as part of the historical rationale for intergovernmental tax immunity, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

cited_decision: Pollock v. Farmers' Loan & Trust Co. (1895)
quote: We thus confirm that subsequent case law has overruled the holding in Pollock that state bond interest is immune from a nondiscriminatory federal tax. We see no constitutional reason for treating persons who receive interest on government bonds differently than persons who receive income from other types of contracts with the government, and no tenable rationale for distinguishing the costs imposed on States by a tax on state bond interest from the costs imposed *525 by a tax on the income from any other state contract.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that it is overruling the holding in Pollock regarding the immunity of state bond interest from nondiscriminatory federal taxation.

quote: Other reasoning in Sinclair, not yet repudiated, we repudiate now... We do not minimize the role that stare decisis plays in our jurisprudence... And we think stare decisis cannot possibly be controlling when, in addition to those factors, the decision in question has been proved manifestly erroneous, and its underpinnings eroded, by subsequent decisions of this Court... The judgment of the Court of Appeals is affirmed.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that it is repudiating the reasoning of Sinclair and cannot adhere to its holding, thereby overruling Sinclair v. United States.

quote: As to the latter, in United States v. Olano, 507 U. S. 725, 732 (1993), the Court noted the limitations on 'plain error' review by the courts of appeals under Rule 52(b).
rationale: Olano is cited for its articulation of the standard for 'plain error' review, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, distinguish, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

cited_decision: United States v. Michael E. Gaudin
quote: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is affirmed. It is so ordered.
rationale: The Acting Decision is a review of the Ninth Circuit's en banc decision in United States v. Michael E. Gaudin and explicitly affirms it.

quote: We have held that these provisions require criminal convictions to rest upon a jury determination that the defendant is guilty of every element of the crime with which he is charged, beyond a reasonable doubt. 1 Sullivan v. Louisiana, 508 U. S. 275, 277-278 (1993).
rationale: Sullivan is cited as authority for the proposition that the jury must determine every element of a crime, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes nor distinguishes it.

quote: The Government’s position is that 'materiality,' whether as a matter of logic or history, is a 'legal' question, and that although we have sometimes spoken of 'requiring the jury to decide ‘all the elements of a criminal offense,’ e. g., Estelle v. McGuire, [ 502 U. S. 62, 69 ] (1991); see Victor v. Nebraska, [ 511 U. S. 1, 5 ] (1994); Patterson v. New York, 432 U. S. 197, 210 (1977), the principle actually applies to only the factual components of the essential elements.'
rationale: Patterson is referenced as part of a string citation for the general principle about jury determination of elements, without further discussion or alteration.

quote: Sparf, supra, the case on which the Government relies, had nothing to do with the issue before us here... But our decision in no way undermined the historical and constitutionally guaranteed right of criminal defendants to demand that the jury decide guilt or innocence on every issue, which includes application of the law to the facts.
rationale: The Acting Decision explains that Sparf addressed a different issue (jury's power to decide pure questions of law) and does not control the present question, thus distinguishing it.

quote: The Government also claims stare decisis benefit from our decision in Kungys v. United States, 485 U. S. 759 (1988)... It is hard to imagine questions more diverse than, on the one hand, whether an appellate court must remand to a district court for a determination of materiality in a denaturalization proceeding (Kungys) and, on the other hand, whether the Constitution requires the finding of the element of materiality in a criminal prosecution to be made by the jury (the present case).
rationale: Kungys is distinguished on the grounds that it involved a different procedural context (appellate review in a civil denaturalization proceeding) and not the Sixth Amendment right at issue here.

cited_decision: Complete Auto Transit, Inc. v. Brady (1977)
quote: With respect to the Commerce Clause, the court emphasized that Complete Auto Transit, Inc. v. Brady, 430 U. S. 274 (1977), rejected the line of cases holding that the direct taxation of interstate commerce was *304 impermissible and adopted instead a 'consistent and rational method of inquiry [that focused on] the practical effect of [the] challenged tax.' ... Complete Auto emphasized the importance of looking past 'the formal language of the tax statute [to] its practical effect,' 430 U. S., at 279, and set forth a four-part test that continues to govern the validity of state taxes under the Commerce Clause.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Complete Auto at length, explaining its test and how it fits into the evolution of Commerce Clause jurisprudence, but does not overrule, criticize, or otherwise alter its precedential value. It is used as a framework for analysis.

cited_decision: State Ex Rel. Heitkamp v. Quill Corp. (1991)
quote: Having granted certiorari, 502 U. S. 808, we must either reverse the State Supreme Court *302 or overrule Bellas Hess. While we agree with much of the state court’s reasoning, we take the former course. ... The judgment of the Supreme Court of North Dakota is reversed, and the case is remanded for further proceedings not inconsistent with this opinion. It is so ordered.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that it is reversing the judgment of the North Dakota Supreme Court in this case.

cited_decision: National Bellas Hess, Inc. v. Department of Revenue (1967)
quote: Thus, to the extent that our decisions have indicated that the Due Process Clause requires physical presence in a State for the imposition of duty to collect a use tax, we overrule those holdings as superseded by developments in the law of due process. ... To the contrary, the continuing value of a bright-line rule in this area and the doctrine and principles of stare deci-sis indicate that the Bellas Hess rule remains good law.
rationale: The Acting Decision overrules Bellas Hess only as to its Due Process Clause holding, but expressly retains its Commerce Clause holding, thus narrowing (limiting) its scope and precedential value.

cited_decision: National Geographic Society v. California Board of Equalization (1977)
quote: Thus, three weeks after Complete Auto was handed down, we cited Bellas Hess for this proposition and discussed the case at some length. In National Geographic Society v. California Bd. of Equalization, 430 U. S. 551, 559 (1977), we affirmed the continuing vitality of Bellas Hess’ 'sharp distinction . . . between mail-order sellers with [a physical presence in the taxing] State and those ... who do no more than communicate with customers in the State by mail or common carrier as part of a general interstate business.' ... Although we agree with the state court’s assessment of the evolution of our cases, we do not share its conclusion that this evolution indicates that the Commerce Clause ruling of Bellas Hess is no longer good law. First, as the state court itself noted, 470 N. W. 2d, at 214, all of these cases involved taxpayers who had a physical presence in the taxing State and therefore do not directly conflict with the rule of Bellas Hess or compel that it be overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes National Geographic by noting that it involved taxpayers with a physical presence in the state, unlike the present case, and thus does not conflict with or overrule Bellas Hess.

quote: For example, in Goldberg v. Sweet, 488 U. S. 252, 263 (1989), we expressed 'doubt that termination of an interstate telephone call, by itself, provides a substantial enough nexus for a State to tax a call. See National Bellas Hess . . . (receipt of mail provides insufficient nexus).' See also D. H. Holmes Co. v. McNamara, 486 U. S. 24, 33 (1988); Commonwealth Edison Co. v. Montana, 453 U. S. 609, 626 (1981); Mobil Oil Corp. v. Commissioner of Taxes, 445 U. S., at 437; National Geographic Society, 430 U. S., at 559.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Commonwealth Edison Co. v. Montana as part of a string citation to illustrate the continued citation of Bellas Hess, but does not analyze, criticize, or otherwise alter its holding.

cited_decision: D. H. Holmes Co., Ltd. v. McNamara (1988)
quote: For example, in Goldberg v. Sweet, 488 U. S. 252, 263 (1989), we expressed 'doubt that termination of an interstate telephone call, by itself, provides a substantial enough nexus for a State to tax a call. See National Bellas Hess . . . (receipt of mail provides insufficient nexus).' See also D. H. Holmes Co. v. McNamara, 486 U. S. 24, 33 (1988); Commonwealth Edison Co. v. Montana, 453 U. S. 609, 626 (1981); Mobil Oil Corp. v. Commissioner of Taxes, 445 U. S., at 437; National Geographic Society, 430 U. S., at 559.
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions D. H. Holmes Co. v. McNamara as part of a list of cases that have cited Bellas Hess, but does not discuss or alter its holding.

cited_decision: Northwestern States Portland Cement Co. v. Minnesota (1959)
quote: It is worth noting that Congress has, at least on one occasion, followed a similar approach in its regulation of state taxation. In response to this Court’s indication in Northwestern States Portland Cement Co. v. Minnesota, 368 U. S. 450, 452 (1959), that, so long as the taxpayer has an adequate nexus with the taxing State, 'net income from the interstate operations of a foreign corporation may be subjected to state taxation,' Congress enacted Pub. L. 86-272, codified at 15 U. S. C. § 381.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Northwestern States Portland Cement Co. v. Minnesota to explain the historical context for congressional action, but does not analyze or alter its holding.

cited_decision: Arkansas Electric Cooperative Corp. v. Arkansas Public Service Commission (1983)
quote: For example, in Arkansas Electric Cooperative Corp. v. Arkansas Pub. Serv. Comm’n, 461 U. S. 375 (1983), we reconsidered a bright-line test set forth in Public Util. Comm’n of R. I. v. Attleboro Steam & Electric Co., 273 U. S. 83 (1927). ... In deciding to reject the Attleboro analysis, we were influenced by the fact that the 'mechanical test' was 'anachronistic,' that the Court had rarely relied on the test, and that we could 'see no strong reliance interests' that would be upset by the rejection of that test. 461 U. S., at 391-392. None of those factors obtains in this case.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Arkansas Electric Cooperative Corp. v. Arkansas Public Service Commission as an example of the Court reconsidering a bright-line rule, but does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: The fountainhead of the same-conduct rule, he asserts, is In re Nielsen, 131 U. S. 176 (1889). That is demonstrably wrong. Nielsen simply applies the common proposition, entirely in accord with Blockburger, that prosecution for a greater offense (cohabitation, defined to require proof of adultery) bars prosecution for a lesser included offense (adultery).
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Nielsen at length, explaining that it is not the source of the 'same-conduct' rule and instead applies the Blockburger test regarding greater and lesser included offenses. The Court distinguishes Nielsen from the present case, clarifying its limited application.

quote: We have concluded, however, that Grady must be overruled... We therefore accept the Government's invitation to overrule Grady, and Counts II, III, IV, and V of Foster's subsequent prosecution are not barred.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Grady v. Corbin is overruled, rejecting its 'same-conduct' test as inconsistent with precedent and unworkable.

quote: In both the multiple punishment and multiple prosecution contexts, this Court has concluded that where the two offenses for which the defendant is punished or tried cannot survive the same-elements test, the double jeopardy bar applies. See, e. g., Brown v. Ohio, 432 U. S. 161, 168-169 (1977); Blockburger v. United States, 284 U. S. 299, 304 (1932) (multiple punishment); Gavieres v. United States, 220 U. S. 338, 342 (1911) (successive prosecutions).
rationale: Brown v. Ohio is cited as an example of the application of the Blockburger test, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its precedential value.

quote: But the dual sovereignty doctrine is limited, by its own terms, to cases where the two entities that seek successively to prosecute a defendant for the same course of conduct can be termed separate sovereigns. Heath, 474 U. S., at 88 . This determination, we explained, turns on whether the two entities draw their authority to punish the offender from distinct sources of power, ibid. , not on whether they are pursuing separate interests. Indeed, the Court has rejected the United States precise argument in the past, perhaps nowhere more resolutely than in Grafton v. United States, 206 U. S. 333 (1907).
rationale: Grafton is referenced to illustrate the limits of the dual sovereignty doctrine, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes nor overrules it, nor does it distinguish it in a way that limits its application.

quote: There we held that a subsequent prosecution for robbery with a firearm was barred by the Double Jeopardy Clause, because the defendant had already been tried for felony murder based on the same underlying felony. We have described our terse per curiam in Harris as standing for the proposition that, for double jeopardy purposes, the crime generally described as felony murder is not a separate offense distinct from its various elements. Illinois v. Vitale, 447 U. S. 410, 420-421 (1980). Accord, Whalen v. United States, 445 U. S. 684, 694 (1980).
rationale: Harris v. Oklahoma is discussed as precedent for the Blockburger test and its application to greater and lesser included offenses. The Acting Decision does not overrule, criticize, or limit Harris, but applies its reasoning.

quote: We have described our terse per curiam in Harris as standing for the proposition that, for double jeopardy purposes, the crime generally described as felony murder is not a separate offense distinct from its various elements. Illinois v. Vitale, 447 U. S. 410, 420-421 (1980). Accord, Whalen v. United States, 445 U. S. 684, 694 (1980).
rationale: Illinois v. Vitale is cited to support the interpretation of Harris and the Blockburger test. The Acting Decision does not alter its precedential value.

cited_decision: Young v. United States Ex Rel. Vuitton Et Fils S. A. (1987)
quote: Indeed, we recognized in Young, supra, that contempt proceedings are not intended to punish conduct proscribed as harmful by the general criminal laws. Rather, they are designed to serve the limited purpose of vindicating the authority of the court.
rationale: Young is referenced to explain the purpose of contempt proceedings, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise affect its authority.

quote: In both the multiple punishment and multiple prosecution contexts, this Court has concluded that where the two offenses for which the defendant is punished or tried cannot survive the same-elements test, the double jeopardy bar applies. See, e. g., Brown v. Ohio, 432 U. S. 161, 168-169 (1977); Blockburger v. United States, 284 U. S. 299, 304 (1932) (multiple punishment); Gavieres v. United States, 220 U. S. 338, 342 (1911) (successive prosecutions).
rationale: Gavieres is cited as an example of the application of the Blockburger test. The Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or limit its authority.

quote: In both Gavieres v. United States, 220 U. S., at 343 , and Burton v. United States, 202 U. S. 344, 379-381 (1906), the Court upheld subsequent prosecutions after concluding that the Blockburger test (and only the Blockburger test) was satisfied.
rationale: Burton is referenced as precedent for the application of the Blockburger test. The Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or limit its authority.

quote: It is well established that criminal contempt, at least the sort enforced through nonsummary proceedings, is a crime in the ordinary sense. Bloom, supra, at 201.
rationale: Bloom v. Illinois is cited to support the proposition that criminal contempt is a crime for constitutional purposes. The Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or limit its authority.

quote: The Double Jeopardy Clause prevents the government from mak[ing] repeated attempts to convict an individual for an alleged offense, thereby subjecting him to embarrassment, expense and ordeal and compelling him to live in a continuing state of anxiety and insecurity. Green v. United States, 355 U. S. 184, 187 (1957).
rationale: Green v. United States is cited for the policy rationale underlying the Double Jeopardy Clause. The Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or limit its authority.

quote: Of course, it follows that to the extent (if any) that Fullilove held federal racial classifications to be subject to a less rigorous standard, it is no longer controlling. But we need not decide today whether the program upheld in Fulli-love would survive strict scrutiny as our more recent cases have defined it.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Fullilove is no longer controlling to the extent it applied a less rigorous standard than strict scrutiny, but does not overrule its result or reasoning entirely. This narrows Fullilove's precedential scope.

cited_decision: City of Richmond v. J. A. Croson Co. (1989)
quote: With Croson, the Court finally agreed that the Fourteenth Amendment requires strict scrutiny of all race-based action by state and local governments. But Croson of course had no occasion to declare what standard of review the Fifth Amendment requires for such action taken by the Federal Government.
rationale: Croson is discussed as precedent for strict scrutiny in state and local government racial classifications, but the Acting Decision does not alter, criticize, or limit its holding.

cited_decision: Metro Broadcasting, Inc. v. Federal Communications Commission (1990)
quote: Accordingly, we hold today that all racial classifications, imposed by whatever federal, state, or local governmental actor, must be analyzed by a reviewing court under strict scrutiny... To the extent that Metro Broadcasting is inconsistent with that holding, it is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly overrules Metro Broadcasting to the extent it applied intermediate scrutiny to federal racial classifications.

cited_decision: Wygant v. Jackson Board of Education (1986)
quote: The issue in Wygant was whether a school board could adopt race-based preferences in determining which teachers to lay off. Justice Powell’s plurality opinion observed that 'the level of scrutiny does not change merely because the challenged classification operates against a group that historically has not been subject to governmental discrimination,' id., at 273 , and stated the two-part inquiry as 'whether the layoff provision is supported by a compelling state purpose and whether the means chosen to accomplish that purpose are narrowly tailored.'
rationale: Wygant is cited for its articulation of strict scrutiny but is not criticized, limited, or otherwise altered by the Acting Decision.

cited_decision: Regents of the University of California v. Bakke (1978)
quote: Bakke did not produce an opinion for the Court, but Justice Powell’s opinion announcing the Court’s judgment rejected the argument. In a passage joined by Justice White, Justice Powell wrote that '[t]he guarantee of equal protection cannot mean one thing when applied to one individual and something else when applied to a person of another color.' 438 U. S., at 289-290 . He concluded that '[r]acial and ethnic distinctions of any sort are inherently suspect and thus call for the most exacting judicial examination.' Id., at 291 .
rationale: Bakke is referenced for its reasoning on strict scrutiny and equal protection, but the Acting Decision does not alter or limit its holding.

quote: The Court observed — correctly—that '[distinctions between citizens solely because of their ancestry are by their very nature odious to a free people whose institutions are founded upon the doctrine of equality,' and that 'racial discrimina-tions are in most circumstances irrelevant and therefore prohibited.' Id., at 100 .
rationale: Hirabayashi is discussed for its statements on racial classifications but is not criticized, overruled, or otherwise limited.

quote: In Bolling v. Sharpe, 347 U. S. 497 (1954), the Court for the first time explicitly questioned the existence of any difference between the obligations of the Federal Government and the States to avoid racial classifications.
rationale: Bolling is cited for its reasoning about equal protection under the Fifth Amendment, but the Acting Decision does not criticize or limit its holding.

quote: The District Court granted the Government’s motion for summary judgment. Adarand Constructors, Inc. v. Skinner, 790 F. Supp. 240 (1992). The Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit affirmed. ... We therefore vacate the Court of Appeals’ judgment and remand the case for further proceedings.
rationale: The Acting Decision vacates the judgment of the lower courts, including Adarand v. Skinner, and remands for further proceedings, thus reversing the outcome below.

quote: This case concerns only classifications based explicitly on race, and presents none of the additional difficulties posed by laws that, although facially race neutral, result in racially disproportionate impact and are motivated by a racially discriminatory purpose. See generally Arlington Heights v. Metropolitan Housing Development Corp., 429 U. S. 252 (1977); Washington v. Davis, 426 U. S. 229 (1976).
rationale: Washington v. Davis is cited for the distinction between facially neutral and explicit racial classifications, but its holding is not altered or criticized.

quote: Korematsu v. United States, 323 U. S. 214 (1944), concerned an order that completely excluded such persons from particular areas. The Court did not address the view, expressed in cases like Hirabayashi and Detroit Bank , that the Federal Government’s obligation to provide equal protection differs significantly from that of the States. Instead, it began by noting that 'all legal restrictions which curtail the civil rights of a single racial group are immediately suspect . . . [and] courts must subject them to the most rigid scrutiny.' 323 U. S., at 216 .
rationale: Korematsu is discussed for its articulation of strict scrutiny and as a historical example, but the Acting Decision does not overrule, criticize, or limit it.

quote: As recently as 1987, for example, every Justice of this Court agreed that the Alabama Department of Public Safety’s 'pervasive, systematic, and obstinate discriminatory conduct' justified a narrowly tailored race-based remedy. See United States v. Paradise, 480 U. S., at 167 (plurality opinion of Brennan, J.); id., at 190 (Stevens, J., concurring in judgment); id., at 196 (O’Connor, J., dissenting).
rationale: Paradise is cited as an example where strict scrutiny was satisfied, but the Acting Decision does not alter, criticize, or limit its holding.

quote: We conclude that Albrecht should be overruled... After reconsidering Albrecht’s rationale and the substantial criticism the decision has received, however, we conclude that there is insufficient economic justification for per se invalidation of vertical maximum price fixing... In overruling Albrecht, we of course do not hold that all vertical maximum price fixing is per se lawful.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Albrecht is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value regarding the per se rule against vertical maximum price fixing.

cited_decision: Continental T. v.  Inc. v. GTE Sylvania Inc. (1977)
quote: Nine years later, in Continental T. V., Inc. v. GTE Sylvania Inc., 438 U. S. 36 (1977), the Court overruled Schwinn, thereby rejecting application of a per se rule in the context of vertical nonprice restrictions. The Court acknowledged the principle of stare decisis, but explained that the need for clarification in the law justified reconsideration of Schwinn...
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses GTE Sylvania as background and precedent for reconsidering per se rules, but does not alter, criticize, or limit its holding; it is referenced for context.

cited_decision: Barkat U. Khan and Khan & Associates, Inc. v. State Oil Company (1996)
quote: The Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit reversed. 93 F. 3d 1358 (1996)... We therefore vacate the judgment of the Court of Appeals and remand the case for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
rationale: The Acting Decision vacates and remands the judgment of the cited Court of Appeals decision, effectively reversing its outcome.

cited_decision: Atlantic Richfield Co. v. USA Petroleum Co. (1990)
quote: In light of Albrecht and Atlantic Richfield Co. v. USA Petroleum Co., 495 U. S. 328 (1990) (ARCO), the court found that respondents could have suffered antitrust injury from not being able to adjust gasoline prices... Most recently, in ARCO, 495 U. S. 328 (1990), although Al-brecht’s continuing validity was not squarely before the Court, some disfavor with that decision was signaled by our statement that we would 'assume, arguendo, that Albrecht correctly held that vertical, maximum price fixing is subject to the per se rule.'
rationale: The Acting Decision references ARCO for its discussion of Albrecht and the evolution of antitrust doctrine, but does not alter, criticize, or limit ARCO itself.

cited_decision: Arizona v. Maricopa County Medical Society (1982)
quote: See, e. g., Arizona v. Maricopa County Medical Soc., 457 U. S. 332, 342-343 (1982) (citing United States v. Joint Traffic Assn., 171 U. S. 505 (1898))... Per se treatment is appropriate '[o]nce experience with a particular kind of restraint enables the Court to predict with confidence that the rule of reason will condemn it.' Maricopa County, supra, at 344...
rationale: The Acting Decision cites Maricopa County for general antitrust principles and the distinction between per se and rule of reason analysis, without criticizing or limiting its holding.

cited_decision: United States v. Arnold, Schwinn & Co. (1967)
quote: Four years later, in United States v. Arnold, Schwinn & Co., 388 U. S. 365 (1967), the Court reconsidered the status of exclusive dealer territories and held that, upon the transfer of title to goods to a distributor, a supplier’s imposition of territorial restrictions on the distributor was 'so obviously destructive of competition' as to constitute a per se violation of the Sherman Act. Id., at 379.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Schwinn as part of the historical development of antitrust law, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its precedential value in this context.

quote: Our reasons for so holding in large part disavow the method of analysis used in United States v. Halper, 490 U. S. 435, 448 (1989), and reaffirm the previously established rule exemplified in United States v. Ward, 448 U. S. 242, 248-249 (1980). ... We believe that Halper’s deviation from longstanding double jeopardy principles was ill considered. 5 AlS subsequent *102 eases have demonstrated, Hamper’s test for determining whether a particular sanction is “punitive,” and thus subject to the strictures of the Double Jeopardy Clause, has proved unworkable. ... In sum, there simply is very little showing, to say nothing of the “clearest proof ” required by Ward , that OCC money penalties and debarment sanctions are criminal..
rationale: The lead opinion expressly disavows and rejects the analytical framework of Halper, stating that its approach was 'ill considered' and 'proved unworkable,' thereby overruling its central holding.

quote: In making this latter determination, the factors listed in Kennedy v. Mendoza-Martinez, 372 U. S. 144, 168-169 (1963), provide useful guideposts, including: (1) '[wjhether the sanction involves an affirmative disability or restraint'; ... It is important to note, however, that 'these factors must be considered in relation to the statute on its face,' id., at 169 , and 'only the clearest proof' will suffice to override legislative intent and transform what has been denominated a civil remedy into a criminal penalty, Ward, supra, at 249 (internal quotation marks omitted).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Kennedy v. Mendoza-Martinez as providing factors for analysis but does not alter, criticize, or limit its holding; it is used as a framework for analysis.

cited_decision: Department of Revenue of Mont. v. Kurth Ranch
quote: We have since recognized that all civil penalties have some deterrent effect. See Department of Revenue of Mont. v. Kurth Ranch, 511 U. S. 767, 777, n. 14 (1994); United States v. Ursery, 518 U. S. 267, 284-285, n. 2 (1996). ... In Kurth Ranch , we held that the presence a purpose effect is not dispositive of the double jeopardy question. 511 U. S., at 781 . Rather, we applied a Kennedy-like test, see 511 U. S., at 780-783 , before concluding that Montana’s dangerous drug tax was 'the functional equivalent of a successive criminal prosecution,' id., at 784 .
rationale: Kurth Ranch is cited as an example of applying the Kennedy factors and is not criticized, limited, or otherwise altered; it is simply referenced for its approach.

quote: Our reasons for so holding in large part disavow the method of analysis used in United States v. Halper, 490 U. S. 435, 448 (1989), and reaffirm the previously established rule exemplified in United States v. Ward, 448 U. S. 242, 248-249 (1980). ... A court must first ask whether the legislature, 'in establishing the penalizing mechanism, indicated either expressly or impliedly a preference for one label or the other.' Ward, 448 U. S., at 248 . ... It is important to note, however, that 'these factors must be considered in relation to the statute on its face,' id., at 169 , and 'only the clearest proof' will suffice to override legislative intent and transform what has been denominated a civil remedy into a criminal penalty, Ward, supra, at 249 (internal quotation marks omitted).
rationale: Ward is reaffirmed as the proper approach and is used as the controlling precedent; it is not criticized or limited, but rather followed.

quote: We have since recognized that all civil penalties have some deterrent effect. See Department of Revenue of Mont. v. Kurth Ranch, 511 U. S. 767, 777, n. 14 (1994); United States v. Ursery, 518 U. S. 267, 284-285, n. 2 (1996). ... Similarly, in Ursery , we rejected the notion that civil in rem forfeitures violate the Double Jeopardy Clause. 518 U. S., at 270-271 . We upheld such forfeitures, relying on the historical support for the notion that such forfeitures are civil and thus do not implicate double jeopardy. Id., at 292 .
rationale: Ursery is cited as supporting authority for the proposition that civil penalties do not necessarily implicate double jeopardy; it is not criticized or limited.

quote: The Clause protects only against the imposition of *99 all additional sanctions that could, 'in common parlance,' be described as punishment. United States ex rel. Marcus v. Hess, 317 U. S. 537, 549 (1943) (quoting Moore v. Illinois, 14 How. 13, 19 (1852)). The Clause protects only against the imposition of multiple criminal punishments for the same offense, Helvering v. Mitchell, 303 U. S. 391, 399 (1938); see also Hess, supra, at 548-549 ('Only' 'criminal punishment' 'subjeet[s] the defendant to ‘jeopardy 3 within the constitutional meaning'); ... As for the money penalties, both §§ 93(b)(1) and 504(a), which authorize the imposition of monetary penalties for violations of §§ 84 and 375b respectively, expressly provide that such penalties are 'civil.' ... That such authority was conferred upon administrative agencies is prima facie evidence that Congress intended to provide for a civil sanction. See Helvering, supra, at 402 ; ... We have long recognized that 'revocation of a privilege voluntarily granted,' such as a debarment, 'is characteristically free of the punitive criminal element.' Helvering, 303 U. S., at 399 , and n. 2. Similarly, 'the payment of fixed or variable sums of money [is a] sanction which ha[s] been recognized as enforeible by civil proceedings since the original revenue law of 1789.' Id., at 400 .
rationale: Helvering v. Mitchell is cited repeatedly as foundational authority for distinguishing civil from criminal penalties; it is not criticized or limited.

quote: While petitioners have been prohibited from further participating in the banking industry, this is 'certainly nothing approaching the infamous punishment’ of imprisonment.' Flemming v. Nestor, 363 U. S. 603, 617 (1960).
rationale: Flemming v. Nestor is cited as an example to support the proposition that certain sanctions are not punitive; it is not criticized or otherwise altered.

quote: Fourth, the conduct for which OCC sanctions are imposed may also be criminal (and in this ease formed the basis for petitioners’ indictments). This fact is insufficient to render the money penalties and debarment sanctions criminally punitive, Ursery, 518 U. S., at 292 , particularly in the double jeopardy context, see United States v. Dixon, 509 U. S. 688, 704 (1993) (rejecting 'same-conduct' test for double jeopardy purposes).
rationale: Dixon is cited for its holding rejecting the 'same-conduct' test in double jeopardy analysis; it is not criticized or limited.

quote: Our decision, we must acknowledge, is in direct conflict with the portion of our decision in House v. Mayo, 324 U. S. 42, 44 (1945) (per curiam), holding that we lack statutory certiorari jurisdiction to review refusals to issue certificates of probable cause. ... Its conclusion was erroneous, and it should not be followed. ... This consideration, when combined with our analysis of the legal issue in question, convinces us the contrary holding of House v. Mayo cannot stand. We hold this Court has jurisdiction under § 1254(1) to review denials of applications for certificates of appealability by a circuit judge or a panel of a court of appeals. The portion of House v. Mayo holding this Court lacks statutory certiorari jurisdiction over denials of certificates of probable cause is overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that the relevant holding of House v. Mayo is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value on the point at issue.

quote: In Ex parte Quirin, 317 U. S. 1 (1942), we confronted the analogous question whether a request for leave to file a petition for a writ of habeas corpus was a case in a district court for the purposes of the then-extant statute governing court of appeals review of district court decisions. ... We held the request for leave constituted a case in the district court over which the court of appeals could assert jurisdiction, even though the district court had denied the request.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Ex Parte Quirin as analogous precedent supporting its reasoning, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority; it is used as supporting analysis.

quote: Stare decisis is 'the preferred course because it promotes the evenhanded, predictable, and consistent development of legal principles, fosters reliance on judicial decisions, and contributes to the actual and perceived integrity of the judicial process.' Payne v. Tennessee, 501 U. S. 808, 827 (1991). ... The role of stare decisis, furthermore, is 'somewhat reduced ... in the case of a procedural rule ... which does not serve as a guide to lawful behavior.' United States v. Gaudin, 515 U. S. 506, 521 (1995) (citing Payne, supra, at *252 828 ).
rationale: Payne v. Tennessee is cited for general principles regarding stare decisis and the overruling of precedent, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, distinguish, or limit its holding.

quote: For example, we have felt less constrained to follow precedent where, as here, the opinion was rendered without full briefing or argument. Gray v. Mississippi, 481 U. S. 648, 651, n. 1 (1987) (questioning the prece-dential value of Davis v. Georgia, 429 U. S. 122 (1976) (per curiam)).
rationale: Gray v. Mississippi is referenced to illustrate a point about the precedential value of opinions rendered without full briefing or argument, but the Acting Decision does not alter or criticize its holding.

quote: That presupposition, first observed over a century ago in Hans v. Louisiana, 134 U. S. 1 (1890), has two parts: first, that each State is a sovereign entity in our federal system; and second, that “ ‘[i]t is inherent in the nature of sovereignty not to be amenable to the suit of an individual without its consent,’ ” id., at 13 (emphasis deleted), quoting The Federalist No. 81, p. 487 (C. Rossiter ed. 1961) (A. Hamilton).
rationale: The Acting Decision references Hans v. Louisiana as the origin of the presupposition regarding state sovereign immunity, but does not overrule, criticize, or otherwise alter its precedential value. It is used as a foundational citation for the doctrine discussed.

quote: The dissent cites not a single decision since Hans (other than Union Gas) that supports its view of state sovereign immunity, instead relying upon the now-discredited decision in Chisholm v. Georgia, 2 Dall. 419 (1793). See, e. g., post, at 152, n. 47. Its undocumented and highly speculative extralegal explanation of *69 the decision in Hans is a disservice to the Court’s traditional method of adjudication.
rationale: Chisholm v. Georgia is mentioned as a historical reference and is described as 'now-discredited,' but the Acting Decision does not itself overrule or otherwise directly treat Chisholm beyond noting its lack of current authority.

quote: We feel bound to conclude that Union Gas was wrongly decided and that it should be, and now is, overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Pennsylvania v. Union Gas Co. is overruled, directly nullifying its precedential value.

quote: In Atas-cadero, we held that '[a] general authorization for suit in federal court is not the kind of unequivocal statutory language sufficient to abrogate the Eleventh Amendment.' 473 U. S., at 246 ; see also Blatchford, supra, at 786, n. 4 ('The fact that Congress grants jurisdiction to hear a claim does not suffice to show Congress has abrogated all defenses to that claim') (emphases deleted).
rationale: Atascadero State Hospital v. Scanlon is cited for its rule regarding congressional abrogation of state immunity, but the Acting Decision neither criticizes nor alters its holding.

quote: In Principality of Monaco v. Mississippi, 292 U. S. 313 (1934), the Court held that the Eleventh Amendment barred a suit brought against a State by a foreign state. Chief Justice Hughes wrote for a unanimous Court: '[NJeither the literal sweep of the words of Clause one of § 2 of Article III, nor the absence of restriction in the letter of the Eleventh Amendment, permits the conclusion that in all controversies of the sort described in Clause one, and omitted from the words of the Eleventh Amendment, a State may be sued without her consent.'
rationale: The Acting Decision references Principality of Monaco v. Mississippi as precedent for the scope of the Eleventh Amendment, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority.

quote: We further hold that the doctrine of Ex parte Young, 209 U. S. 123 (1908), may not be used to enforce § 2710(d)(3) against a state official. ... We hold that Ex parte Young is inapplicable to petitioner’s suit against the Governor of Florida, and therefore that suit is barred by the Eleventh Amendment and must be dismissed for a lack of jurisdiction.
rationale: The Acting Decision holds that Ex parte Young does not apply to the statutory scheme at issue, thereby limiting the scope of the Ex parte Young doctrine in this context.

quote: In Cohens v. Virginia, 6 Wheat. 264 (1821), for instance, Chief Justice Marshall, writing for the Court, emphasized that the Amendment had no effect on federal courts’ jurisdiction grounded on the 'arising under' provision of Article III and concluded that 'a case arising under the constitution or laws of the United States, is cognizable in the Courts of the Union, whoever may be the parties to that case.' Id., at 383.
rationale: Cohens v. Virginia is cited as historical authority for the interpretation of the Eleventh Amendment, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: In Fitzpatrick, we recognized that the Fourteenth Amendment, by expanding federal power at the expense of state autonomy, had fundamentally altered the balance of state and federal power struck by the Constitution. Id., at 455 . We noted that § 1 of the Fourteenth Amendment contained prohibitions expressly directed at the States and that § 5 of the Amendment expressly provided that 'The Congress shall have power to enforce, by appropriate legislation, the provisions of this article.' See id., at 453 (internal quotation marks omitted). We held that through the Fourteenth Amendment, federal power extended to intrude upon the province of the Eleventh Amendment and therefore that § 5 of the Fourteenth Amendment allowed Congress to abrogate the immunity from suit guaranteed by that Amendment.
rationale: Fitzpatrick v. Bitzer is referenced as precedent for the proposition that Congress may abrogate state immunity under the Fourteenth Amendment, but the Acting Decision does not criticize or otherwise alter its holding.

cited_decision: Welch v. Texas Department of Highways & Public Transportation
quote: Rather, as we said in Dellmuth v. Muth, 491 U. S. 223 (1989): 'To temper Congress’ acknowledged powers of abrogation with due concern for the Eleventh Amendment’s role as an essential component of our constitutional structure, we have applied a simple but stringent test: ‘Congress may abrogate the States’ constitutionally secured immunity from suit in federal court only by making its intention unmistakably clear in the language of the statute.’ Id., at 227-228 . See also Welch v. Texas Dept. of Highways and Public Transp., 483 U. S. 468, 474 (1987) (plurality opinion).
rationale: Welch is cited as authority for the clear statement rule regarding congressional abrogation of state immunity, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its holding.

cited_decision: Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority v. Metcalf & Eddy, Inc.
quote: Respondents moved to dismiss the complaint, arguing that the suit violated the State’s sovereign immunity from suit in federal court. The District Court denied respondents’ motion, 801 F. Supp. 655 (SD Fla. 1992), and respondents took an interlocutory appeal of that decision. See Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority v. Metcalf & Eddy, Inc., 506 U. S. 139 (1993) (collateral order doctrine allows immediate appellate review of order denying claim of Eleventh Amendment immunity).
rationale: Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority v. Metcalf & Eddy, Inc. is cited for a procedural point about appellate review of Eleventh Amendment immunity claims, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its holding.

cited_decision: Seminole Tribe of Florida v. State of Florida, Lawton Chiles, Governor of the State of Florida, Poarch Creek Indians, Poarch Band of Creek Indians v. State of Alabama, James E. Folsom, Governor, State of Alabama
quote: The Eleventh Circuit consolidated petitioner’s appeal with an appeal from another suit brought under § 2710(d)(7)(A)(i) by a different Indian tribe. Although the District Court in that ease had granted the defendants’ motions to dismiss, the legal issues presented by the two appeals were virtually identical. See Poarch Band of Creek Indians v. Alabama, 776 F. Supp. 550 (SD Ala. 1991) (Eleventh Amendment bars suit against State), and 784 F. Supp. 1549 (SD Ala. 1992) (Eleventh Amendment bars suit against Governor). Following its conclusion that petitioner’s suit should be dismissed, the Court of Appeals went on to consider how § 2710(d)(7) would operate in the wake of its decision. The court decided that those provisions of § 2710(d)(7) that were problematic could be severed from the rest of the section, and read the surviving provisions of § 2710(d)(7) to provide an Indian tribe with immediate recourse to the Secretary of the Interior from the dismissal of a suit against a State. 11 F. 3d 1016 , 1029 (1994).
rationale: The cited Eleventh Circuit decision is mentioned as the lower court decision under review and for its reasoning, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its precedential value beyond affirming its result.

cited_decision: Central Hudson Gas & Electric Corp. v. Public Service Commission
quote: In Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm’n of N. Y., 447 U. S. 557 (1980), we took stock of our developing commercial speech jurisprudence. ... In those circumstances, 'a ban on speech could screen from public view the underlying governmental policy.' ... As a result, the Court concluded that 'special care' should attend the review of such blanket bans, and it pointedly remarked that 'in recent years this Court has not approved a blanket ban on commercial speech unless the expression itself was flawed in some way, either because it was deceptive or related to unlawful activity.' ... It necessarily follows that the price advertising ban cannot survive the more stringent constitutional review that Central Hudson itself concluded was appropriate for the complete suppression of truthful, nonmisleading commercial speech. 447 U. S., at 566, n. 9.
rationale: The Acting Decision applies and discusses the Central Hudson test as the controlling framework for commercial speech, but does not overrule, criticize, or limit it. The case is treated as authoritative and is repeatedly cited as the standard, so the treatment is 'Mentioned.'

cited_decision: Virginia State Board of Pharmacy v. Virginia Citizens Consumer Council, Inc.
quote: The following Term in Virginia Bd. of Pharmacy v. Virginia Citizens Consumer Council, Inc., 425 U. S. 748 (1976), we expanded on our holding in Bigelow and held that the State’s blanket ban on advertising the price of prescription drugs violated the First Amendment. Virginia Bd. of Pharmacy reflected the conclusion that the same interest that supports regulation of potentially misleading advertising, namely, the public’s interest in receiving accurate commercial information, also supports an interpretation of the First Amendment that provides constitutional protection for the dissemination of accurate and nonmis-leading commercial messages.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Virginia Bd. of Pharmacy as a foundational precedent for commercial speech protection, applying its principles without criticism or limitation. It is cited as supportive authority, so the treatment is 'Mentioned.'

cited_decision: Posadas De Puerto Rico Associates v. Tourism Co. of Puerto Rico
quote: The reasoning in Posadas does support the State’s argument, but, on reflection, we are now persuaded that Posadas erroneously performed the First Amendment analysis. ... Given our longstanding hostility to commercial speech regulation of this type, Posadas clearly erred in concluding that it was 'up to the legislature' to choose suppression over a less speech-restrictive policy. The Posadas majority’s conclusion on that point cannot be reconciled with the unbroken line of prior eases striking down similarly broad regulations on truthful, nonmisleading advertising when non-speech- related alternatives were available. ... As the entire Court apparently now agrees, the statements in the Posadas opinion on which Rhode Island relies are no longer persuasive.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly criticizes the reasoning and holding of Posadas, stating it 'erroneously performed the First Amendment analysis' and that its statements are 'no longer persuasive.' However, it does not formally overrule Posadas, so the treatment is 'Criticized.'

quote: last Term we held that a federal law abridging a brewer’s right to provide the public with accurate information about the alcoholic content of malt beverages is unconstitutional. Rubin v. Coors Brewing Co., 514 U. S. 476, 491 (1995). ... For that reason, the State bears the burden of showing not merely that its regulation will advance its interest, but also that it will do so 'to a material degree.' Edenfield, 507 U. S., at 771 ; see also Rubin v. Coors Brewing Co., 514 U. S., at 486-488.
rationale: Rubin v. Coors Brewing Co. is cited as recent, supportive precedent for the First Amendment protection of commercial speech and the burden on the state to justify restrictions. The Acting Decision applies and follows Rubin, so the treatment is 'Mentioned.'

quote: Indeed, the District Court’s considered and un-contradicted finding on this point is directly to the contrary. Id., at 549 . ... As a matter of law, he concluded that the price advertising ban was unconstitutional because it did not 'directly advance' the State’s interest in reducing alcohol consumption and was 'more extensive than necessary to serve that interest.' Id., at 555 .
rationale: The Acting Decision references the District Court's findings and legal conclusions in Racine as part of the procedural history and factual record, but does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its precedential value. The treatment is 'Mentioned.'

cited_decision: City of Cincinnati v. Discovery Network, Inc.
quote: It is the State’s interest in protecting consumers from 'commercial harms' that provides 'the typical reason why commercial speech can be subject to greater governmental regulation than noncommercial speech.' Cincinnati v. Discovery Network, Inc., 507 U. S. 410, 426 (1993). ... The State’s regulation must indicate a 'carefu[l] calculation of the costs and benefits associated with the burden on speech imposed by its prohibition.' Cincinnati v. Discovery Network, Inc., 507 U. S. 410, 417 (1993) (internal quotation marks omitted).
rationale: Discovery Network is cited as authority for the standards governing commercial speech regulation and the need for careful tailoring. The Acting Decision applies its reasoning without criticism or limitation, so the treatment is 'Mentioned.'

cited_decision: United States v. Edge Broadcasting Co.
quote: Rhode Island errs in concluding that Edge and Posadas establish the degree of deference that its decision to impose a price advertising ban warrants. In Edge, we upheld a federal statute that permitted only those broadcasters located in States that had legalized lotteries to air lottery advertising. The statute was designed to regulate advertising about an activity that had been deemed illegal in the jurisdiction in which the broadcaster was located. 509 U. S., at 433-434 . Here, by contrast, the commercial speech ban targets information about entirely lawful behavior.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Edge Broadcasting by noting that it involved advertising about illegal activity in the relevant jurisdiction, whereas the present case involves lawful activity. Thus, Edge is not controlling, and the treatment is 'Distinguished.'

cited_decision: Linmark Associates, Inc. v. Township of Willingboro
quote: For example, in Linmark, 431 U. S., at 92-94 , we concluded that a ban on 'For Sale' signs was 'content based' and failed to leave open 'satisfactory' alternative channels of communication; see also Virginia Bd. of Pharmacy, 425 U. S., at 771 . ... As a result, even under the less than strict standard that generally applies in commercial speech cases, the State has failed to establish a 'reasonable fit' between its abridgment of speech and its temperance goal. ... see also Rubin v. Coors Brewing Co., 514 U. S., at 491 (explaining that defects in a federal ban on alcohol advertising are 'further highlighted by the availability of alternatives that would prove less intrusive to the First Amendment’s protections for commercial speech'); Linmark, 431 U. S., at 97 (suggesting that the State use financial incentives or counterspeech, rather than speech restrictions, to advance its interests).
rationale: Linmark is cited as precedent for the principle that content-based bans on truthful commercial speech are subject to heightened scrutiny and that alternatives to speech bans should be considered. The Acting Decision applies Linmark's reasoning, so the treatment is 'Mentioned.'

cited_decision: Florida Bar v. Went for It, Inc.
quote: Moreover, last Term we upheld a 30-day prohibition against a certain form of legal solicitation largely because it left so many channels of communication open to Florida lawyers. Florida Bar v. Went For It, Inc., 515 U. S. 618, 633-634 (1995). ... The scope of the restriction on speech must be reasonably,, though it need not be perfectly, targeted to address the harm, intended to be regulated. See Florida Bar v. Went For It, Inc., 515 U. S. 618, 632-634 (1995).
rationale: Went for It is cited as an example of a narrowly tailored restriction on commercial speech that left open alternative channels of communication. The Acting Decision uses it to illustrate proper tailoring, so the treatment is 'Mentioned.'

cited_decision: Michigan Beer & Wine Wholesalers Ass'n v. Attorney General
quote: There, the Michigan Court of Appeals concluded that Queens-gate did not control because it involved a far narrower restriction on liquor advertising than the one that Michigan had imposed. 142 Mich. App., at 304-305 , 370 N. W. 2d, at 333-335 . ... cf. Michigan Beer & Wine Wholesalers Assn. v. Attorney General, 142 Mich. App., at 311 , 370 N. W. 2d, at 336 (explaining that 'any additional impact on the level of consumption attributable to the absence of price advertisements would be negligible').
rationale: The Acting Decision references Michigan Beer & Wine Wholesalers Ass'n for its factual findings and analysis regarding the impact of advertising bans, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its authority. The treatment is 'Mentioned.'

quote: In reaching its conclusion, the Court of Appeals relied on our decision in California v. LaRue, 409 U. S. 109 (1972). ... Without questioning the holding in LaRue , we now disavow its reasoning insofar as it relied on the Twenty-first Amendment. ... As we recently noted: 'LaRue did not involve commercial speech about alcohol, but instead concerned the regulation of nude dancing in places where alcohol was served.' Rubin v. Coors Brewing Co., 514 U. S., at 483, n. 2 .
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly limits LaRue by disavowing its reasoning to the extent it relied on the Twenty-first Amendment, while not questioning its holding on other grounds. Thus, the precedential scope of LaRue is narrowed, and the treatment is 'Limited.'

cited_decision: Zobrest v. Catalina Foothills School District
quote: In Zobrest v. Catalina Foothills School Dist., 509 U. S. 1 (1993), we examined whether the IDEA, 20 U. S. C. § 1400 et seq., was constitutional as applied to a deaf student who sought to bring his state-employed sign-language interpreter with him to his Roman Catholic high school. We held that this was permissible, expressly disavowing the notion that 'the Establishment Clause [laid] down [an] absolute bar to the placing of a public employee in a sectarian school.' 509 U. S., at 13.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses Zobrest as a precedent that modified the approach to Establishment Clause analysis, but does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its holding. Zobrest is cited as supporting authority for the new rule.

quote: Accordingly, we must acknowledge that Aguilar, as well as the portion of Ball addressing Grand Rapids’ Shared Time program, are no longer good law... We therefore overrule Ball and Aguilar to the extent those decisions are inconsistent with our current understanding of the Establishment Clause.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Aguilar is overruled and is no longer good law, directly nullifying its precedential value.

cited_decision: Witters v. Washington Department of Services for the Blind
quote: In Witters v. Washington Dept. of Servs. for Blind, 474 U. S. 481 (1986), we held that the Establishment Clause did not bar a State from issuing a vocational tuition grant to a blind person who wished to use the grant to attend a Christian college and become a pastor, missionary, or youth director.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Witters as an example of a case that shaped the current Establishment Clause jurisprudence, but does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its holding.

cited_decision: School District of Grand Rapids v. Ball
quote: Accordingly, we must acknowledge that Aguilar, as well as the portion of Ball addressing Grand Rapids’ Shared Time program, are no longer good law... We therefore overrule Ball and Aguilar to the extent those decisions are inconsistent with our current understanding of the Establishment Clause.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly overrules Ball, stating that its relevant portions are no longer good law.

quote: The Court conducted its analysis by applying the three-part test set forth in Lemon v. Kurtzman, 403 U. S. 602 (1971): 'First, the statute must have a secular legislative purpose; second, its principal or primary effect must be one that neither advances nor inhibits religion; finally, the statute must not foster an excessive government entanglement with religion.' 473 U. S., at 382-383 (quoting Lemon, supra, at 612-613 ) (citations and internal quotation marks omitted).
rationale: Lemon is cited as the source of the test applied in prior cases, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter Lemon's holding.

cited_decision: Betty-Louise Felton, Charlotte Green, Barbara Hruska, Meryl A. Schwartz, Robert H. Side and Allen H. Zelon v. Secretary, United States Department of Education, and the Chancellor of the Board of Education of the City of New York, and Yolanda Aguilar, Lillian Colon, Miriam Martinez and Belinda Williams, Intervenor-Defendants-Appellees
quote: Recognizing that more than 90% of the private schools within the Board’s jurisdiction are sectarian, Felton v. Secretary, United States Dept. of Ed., 739 F. 2d 48, 51 (CA2 1984), the Board initially arranged to transport children to public schools for after-school Title I instruction.
rationale: The Acting Decision references this case for factual background and does not discuss its legal reasoning or precedential value.

cited_decision: Board of Ed. of Kiryas Joel Village School Dist. v. Grumet
quote: Petitioners also argue that there have been two significant legal developments since Aguilar was decided: a majority of Justices have expressed their views that Aguilar should be reconsidered or overruled, see supra, at 214; and Aguilar has in any event been undermined by subsequent Establishment Clause decisions, including Witters v. Washington Dept. of Servs. for Blind, 474 U. S. 481 (1986), Zobrest v. Catalina Foothills School Dist., 509 U. S. 1 (1993), and Rosenberger v. Rector and Visitors of Univ. of Va., 515 U. S. 819 (1995). Respondents counter that, because the costs of providing Title I services off site were known at the time Aguilar was decided, and because the relevant case law has not changed, the District Court did not err in denying petitioners’ motions. Obviously, if neither the law supporting our original decision in this litigation nor the facts have changed, there would be no need to decide the propriety of a Rule 60(b)(5) motion. Accordingly, we turn to the threshold issue whether the factual or legal landscape has changed since we decided Aguilar . We agree with respondents that petitioners have failed to establish the significant change in factual conditions required by Rufo . Both petitioners and this Court were, at the time Aguilar was decided, aware that additional costs would be incurred if Title I services could not be provided in parochial school classrooms. See App. 66-68 (Defendants’ Joint Statement of Material Facts Not In Dispute, filed in 1982, detailing costs of providing off-premises services); Aguilar, 473 U. S., at 430-431 (O’Connor, J., dissenting) (observing that costs of complying with Aguilar decision would likely cause a decline in Title I services for 20,000 New York City students). That these predictions of additional costs turned out to be accurate does not constitute a change in factual conditions warranting relief under Rule 60(b)(5). Accord, Rufo, *217 supra, at 385 ('Ordinarily . . . modification should not be granted where a party relies upon events that actually were anticipated at the time [the order was entered]').
rationale: The Acting Decision mentions Grumet as a case in which Justices called for reconsideration of Aguilar, but does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: First, drawing upon the analysis in Meek v. Pittenger, 421 U. S. 349 (1975), the Court observed that 'the teachers participating in the programs may become involved in intentionally or inadvertently inculcating particular religious tenets or beliefs.' 473 U. S., at 385. Meek invalidated a Pennsylvania program in which full-time public employees provided supplemental 'auxiliary services'... Although the auxiliary services themselves were secular, they were mostly dispensed on the premises of parochial schools, where 'an atmosphere dedicated to the advancement of religious belief [was] constantly maintained.' Meek, 421 U. S., at 371. Instruction in that atmosphere was sufficient to create '[t]he potential for impermissible fostering of religion.' Id., at 372... Our more recent cases have undermined the assumptions upon which Ball and Aguilar relied... we have abandoned the presumption erected in Meek and Ball that the placement of public employees on parochial school grounds inevitably results in the impermissible effect of state-sponsored indoctrination or constitutes a symbolic union between government and religion.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that the assumptions underlying Meek have been undermined and abandoned, criticizing its reasoning and diminishing its precedential value.

cited_decision: Rufo v. Inmates of Suffolk County Jail
quote: In Rufo v. Inmates of Suffolk County Jail, supra, at 384, we held that it is appropriate to grant a Rule 60(b)(5) motion when the party seeking relief from an injunction or consent decree can show 'a significant change either in factual conditions or in law.'
rationale: Rufo is cited as authority for the standard governing Rule 60(b)(5) motions, but its reasoning or holding is not criticized, limited, or otherwise altered.

cited_decision: Rosenberger v. Rector & Visitors of University of Virginia
quote: Petitioners also argue that there have been two significant legal developments since Aguilar was decided: a majority of Justices have expressed their views that Aguilar should be reconsidered or overruled, see supra, at 214; and Aguilar has in any event been undermined by subsequent Establishment Clause decisions, including Witters v. Washington Dept. of Servs. for Blind, 474 U. S. 481 (1986), Zobrest v. Catalina Foothills School Dist., 509 U. S. 1 (1993), and Rosenberger v. Rector and Visitors of Univ. of Va., 515 U. S. 819 (1995).
rationale: Rosenberger is mentioned as one of the subsequent Establishment Clause decisions that have shaped the legal landscape, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: We continue to ask whether the government acted with the purpose of advancing or inhibiting religion, and the nature of that inquiry has remained largely unchanged. See Witters, 474 U. S., at 485-486; Bowen v. Kendrick, 487 U. S. 589, 602-604 (1988) (concluding that Adolescent Family Life Act had a secular purpose); Board of Ed. of Westside Community Schools (Dist. 66) v. Mergens, 496 U. S. 226, 248-249 (1990)...
rationale: Bowen is cited as an example of a case applying the secular purpose test, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: We now overrule Evans insofar as it holds that the Compensation Clause forbids Congress to apply a generally applicable, nondiseriminatory tax to the salaries of federal judges, whether or not they were appointed before enactment of the tax. ... Insofar as Evans holds to the contrary, that case, in O’Malley’s words, 'cannot survive.' 307 U.S., at 283.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that it is overruling Evans v. Gore to the extent that it prohibited nondiscriminatory taxes on judges, making clear that Evans is no longer good law on that point.

quote: And in so doing the Court, in an opinion announced by Justice Frankfurter, adopted the reasoning of the Evans dissent. The Court said that the question was whether judges are immune 'from the incidences of taxation to which everyone else within the defined classes ... is subjected.' 307 U.S., at 282. Holding that judges are not 'immun[e] from sharing with their fellow citizens the material burden of the government,' ibid., the Court pointed out that the legal profession had criticized Evans’ contrary conclusion, and that courts outside the United States had resolved similar matters differently, 307 U.S., at 281.
rationale: The Acting Decision discusses O'Malley v. Woodrough as precedent and adopts its reasoning, but does not alter, criticize, or limit its holding. It is cited as supporting authority and its reasoning is followed.

quote: Still later, this Court noted that '[b]ecause Miles relied on Evans v. Gore, O’Malley must also be read to undermine the reasoning of Evans.' United States v. Will, 449 U.S. 200, 227, n. 31 (1980). ... Finally, the Government looks to our decision in Will for support. ... The Will Year One example, however, shows only that, in the circumstances, and unlike the case before us, the later salary increase was related to the earlier salary diminishment. Regardless, the very fact that the matter was 'unquestioned' in Will shows that it was not argued. See 449 U. S., at 206, n. 3 (noting that the judges’ complaint sought relief for Year One’s diminution only up to the moment of the subsequent salary increase). Hence the Court did not decide the matter now before us.
rationale: United States v. Will is discussed for its factual and legal context, but the Acting Decision neither overrules, criticizes, nor limits it. The case is mentioned as background and for comparison.

quote: Hence, insofar as the Court of Appeals found that application of the Medicare tax law to federal judges is unconstitutional, we reverse its decision. ... Insofar as that court found the application of Social Security taxes to the salaries of judges taking office before 1984 unconstitutional, its judgment is affirmed.
