rationale: The Acting Decision directly reverses the Court of Appeals' (Hatter v. United States, 64 F.3d 647) holding regarding the Medicare tax, while affirming its holding regarding Social Security taxes. Thus, the treatment is 'Reversed' as to the Medicare tax issue.

cited_decision: Seminole Tribe of Florida v. Florida (1996)
quote: Our decision three Terms ago in Seminole Tribe, supra, held that the power “to regulate Commerce” conferred by Article I of the Constitution gives Congress no authority to abrogate state sovereign immunity. As authority for the abrogation in the present case, petitioner relies upon §5 of the Fourteenth Amendment, which we held in Fitzpatrick v. Bitzer, supra, and reaffirmed in Seminole Tribe, see 517 U. S., at 72-73 , could be used for that purpose.
rationale: The Acting Decision references Seminole Tribe as precedent for the proposition that Congress cannot abrogate state sovereign immunity under Article I, but does not criticize, overrule, or otherwise alter its holding. It is cited as controlling law.

cited_decision: Employees of Department of Public Health v. Department of Public Health (1973)
quote: Only nine years later, in Employees of Dept. of Public Health and Welfare of Mo. v. Department of Public Health and Welfare of Mo., 411 U. S. 279 (1973), we began to retreat from Parden . That case held — in an opinion written by one of the Parden dissenters over the solitary dissent of Parderis author — that the State of Missouri was immune from a suit brought under the Fair Labor Standards Act by employees of its state health facilities. Although the statute specifically covered the state hospitals in question, ... we did not think that the statute expressed with clarity Congress’s intention to supersede the States’ immunity from suits brought by individuals. We “put to one side” the Parden case, which we characterized as involving “dramatic circumstances” and “a rather isolated state activity,” 411 U. S., at 285 , unlike the provision of the Fair Labor Standards Act in question that applied to a broad class of state employees.
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes Employees from Parden, noting that Employees involved different circumstances and did not address the same issue of constructive waiver, thereby treating Employees as factually and legally distinct.

cited_decision: Parden v. Terminal Railway of Alabama State Docks Department (1964)
quote: In short, Parden stands as an anomaly in the jurisprudence of sovereign immunity, and indeed in the jurisprudence of constitutional law. Today, we drop the other shoe: Whatever may remain of our decision in Parden is expressly overruled.
rationale: The Acting Decision explicitly states that Parden is 'expressly overruled,' leaving no doubt as to its treatment.

cited_decision: Welch v. Texas Department of Highways & Public Transportation (1987)
quote: Several Terms later, in Welch v. Texas Dept. of Highways and Public Transp., 483 U. S. 468 (1987), although we expressly avoided addressing the constitutionality of Congress’s conditioning a State’s engaging in Commerce Clause activity upon the State’s waiver of sovereign immunity, we said there was “no doubt that Parden’s discussion of congressional intent to negate Eleventh Amendment immunity is no longer good law,” and overruled Parden “to the extent [it] is inconsistent with the requirement that an abrogation of Eleventh Amendment immunity by Congress must be expressed in unmistakably clear language,” 483 U. S., at 478 , and n. 8.
rationale: Welch is mentioned as part of the historical development of the law regarding sovereign immunity and waiver, but its holding is neither criticized nor changed by the Acting Decision.

quote: Atascadero State Hospital v. Scanlon, 478 U. S. 234 , 241 (1985). Generally, we will find a waiver either if the State voluntarily invokes our jurisdic *676 tion, Gunter v. Atlantic Coast Line R. Co., 200 U. S. 273, 284 (1906), or else if the State makes a clear declaration” that it intends to submit itself to our jurisdiction, Great Northern Life Ins. Co. v. Read, 322 U. S. 47, 54 (1944). See also Pennhurst State School and Hospital v. Halderman, 465 U. S., at 99 (State’s consent to suit must be unequivocally expressed”).
rationale: Atascadero is cited for the general principle that waiver of sovereign immunity must be unequivocal, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: As further evidence that constructive waiver is little more than abrogation under another name, consider the revealing facts of this case: The statutory provision relied upon to demonstrate that Florida constructively waived its sovereign immunity is the very same provision that purported to abrogate it. ... “All congressional creations of private rights of action attach recovery to the defendant’s commission of some act, or possession of some status, in a field where Congress has authority to regulate conduct. Thus, all federal prescriptions are, insofar as their prospective application is concerned, in a sense conditional, and — to the extent that the objects of the prescriptions consciously engage in the activity or hold the status that produces liability — can be rede-scribed as invitations to ‘waiver.’ ” Pennsylvania v. Union Gas Co., 491 U. S. 1, 43 (1989) (Scalia, J., dissenting).
rationale: Union Gas is mentioned in a parenthetical as part of a quotation from a dissenting opinion, used to illustrate a point about waiver and abrogation, but not otherwise discussed or altered.

cited_decision: White v. Massachusetts Council of Construction Employers, Inc. (1983)
quote: The “market participant” eases from our dormant Commerce Clause jurisprudence, relied upon by the United States, are inapposite. See, e.g., White v. Massachusetts Council of Constr. Employers, Inc., 460 U. S. 204 (1983); Reeves, Inc. v. Stake, 447 U. S. 429 (1980); and Hughes v. Alexandria Scrap Corp., 426 U. S. 794 (1976). Those cases hold that, where a State acts as a participant in the private market, it may prefer the goods or services of its own citizens, even though it could not do so while acting as a market regulator. ... In contrast, a suit by an individual against an unconsenting State is the very evil at which the Eleventh Amendment is directed — and it exists whether or not the State is acting for profit, in a traditionally “private” enterprise, and as a “market participant.”
rationale: The Acting Decision distinguishes White and similar cases, explaining that the market participant doctrine in dormant Commerce Clause jurisprudence does not apply to the sovereign immunity context at issue.

quote: Parden itself cited authority that found related “waivers” in at least roughly comparable circumstances. United States v. California, 297 U. S. 175 (1936), for example, held that a State, “by engaging in interstate commerce by rail, has subjected itself to the commerce power,” id., at 185 , which amounted to a waiver of a (different though related) substantive immunity. See also Taylor, supra, at 568.
rationale: California v. Taylor is mentioned as a precedent cited by Parden, but the Acting Decision does not discuss or alter its holding.

quote: First, Congress may authorize such a suit in the exercise of its power to enforce the Fourteenth Amendment — an Amendment enacted after the Eleventh Amendment and specifically designed to alter the federal-state balance. Fitzpatrick v. Bitzer, 427 U. S. 445 (1976).
rationale: Fitzpatrick is cited for the proposition that Congress may abrogate state sovereign immunity when legislating under the Fourteenth Amendment, but the Acting Decision does not criticize, limit, or otherwise alter its holding.

quote: In Agostini, however, we brought some clarity to our ease law, by overruling two anomalous precedents (one in whole, the other in part) and by consolidating some of our previously disparate considerations under a revised test. ... Whereas in Lemon we had considered whether a statute (1) has a secular purpose, (2) has a primary effect of advancing or inhibiting religion, or (3) creates an excessive entanglement between government and religion, see 403 U. S., at 612-613, in Agostini we modified Lemon for purposes of evaluating aid to schools and examined only the first and second factors, see 521 U. S., at 222-223.
rationale: The Acting Decision relies on Agostini as the controlling precedent and framework for analysis, applying its test and referencing its holdings, but does not overrule, criticize, or otherwise alter its precedential value. Agostini is treated as authoritative and is positively cited.

cited_decision: Zobrest v. Catalina Foothills School District
quote: Judge Livaudais cited our 1993 decision in Zobrest v. Catalina Foothills School Dish, 509 U. S. 1 , in which we held that a State could, as part *805 of a federal program for the disabled, provide a sign-language interpreter to a deaf student at a Catholic high school. ... The heart of our reasoning in Zobrest, upholding governmental provision of a sign-language interpreter to a deaf student at his Catholic high school, was as follows: 'The service at issue in this ease is part of a general government program that distributes benefits neutrally to any child qualifying as ‘disabled’ under the [statute], without regard to the ‘sectarian-nonseetarian, or publie-nonpublic nature’ of the school the child attends.'
rationale: Zobrest is discussed at length and its reasoning is applied to the facts of the present case. The Acting Decision neither overrules nor criticizes Zobrest, but instead treats it as good law and uses it to support its own holding.

cited_decision: Witters v. Washington Department of Services for the Blind
quote: In Witters, we held that the Establishment Clause did not bar a State from including within a neutral program providing tuition payments for vocational rehabilitation a blind person studying at a Christian college to become a pastor, missionary, or youth director. We explained: 'Any aid . . . that ultimately flows to religious institutions does so only as a result of the genuinely independent and private choices of aid recipients.'
rationale: Witters is cited as a supporting precedent for the principle of neutrality and private choice in government aid programs. The Acting Decision applies Witters' reasoning and treats it as valid and controlling, without criticism or limitation.

cited_decision: Board of Ed. of Central School Dist. No. 1 v. Allen
quote: The Ninth Circuit acknowledged in Walker, as Judge Heebe had in his 1990 summary judgment ruling, that Meek and Wolman appeared to erect a constitutional distinction between providing textbooks (permissible) and providing any other in-kind aid (impermissible). 46 F. 3d, at 1464-1465; see Board of Ed. of Central School Dist. No. 1 v. Allen, 392 U. S. 236 (1968) (upholding textbook program). ... We have repeatedly reaffirmed Allen since then, see, e. g., Agostini, supra, at 231.
rationale: Allen is repeatedly cited as a foundational precedent for the constitutionality of textbook lending programs. The Acting Decision reaffirms Allen and distinguishes it from overruled cases, treating it as good law.

cited_decision: Everson v. Board of Ed. of Ewing
quote: In the over 50 years since Everson v. Board of Ed. of Ewing, 330 U. S. 1 (1947), we have consistently struggled to apply these simple words in the context of governmental aid to religious schools. ... In disregarding the nature of the school, Zobrest and Agostini were merely returning to the approach of Everson and Allen, in which the Court upheld aid programs to students at pervasively sectarian schools.
rationale: Everson is cited as a historical precedent and is used to support the general principle of neutrality in government aid. The Acting Decision does not alter, criticize, or limit Everson, but treats it as a foundational case.

quote: We therefore hold that Chapter 2 is not a 'law respecting an establishment of religion.' In so holding, we acknowledge what both the Ninth and Fifth Circuits saw was inescapable — Meek and Wolman are anomalies in our case law. We therefore conclude that they are no longer good law. ... To the extent that Meek and Wolman conflict with this holding, we overrule them.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly states that Wolman is 'no longer good law' and is overruled to the extent it conflicts with the present holding, thus expressly nullifying its precedential value.

quote: We therefore hold that Chapter 2 is not a 'law respecting an establishment of religion.' In so holding, we acknowledge what both the Ninth and Fifth Circuits saw was inescapable — Meek and Wolman are anomalies in our case law. We therefore conclude that they are no longer good law. ... To the extent that Meek and Wolman conflict with this holding, we overrule them.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly overrules Meek, stating it is 'no longer good law' and is overruled to the extent it conflicts with the current holding.

quote: The tax deduction for educational expenses that we upheld in Mueller was, in these respects, the same as the tuition grant in Witters. We upheld it chiefly because it 'neutrally provides state assistance to a broad spectrum of citizens,' 463 U. S., at 398-399, and because 'numerous, private choices of individual parents of school-age children,' id., at 399, determined which schools would benefit from the deductions.
rationale: Mueller is cited as a supporting precedent for the principles of neutrality and private choice in government aid. The Acting Decision applies its reasoning and treats it as good law.

quote: Whereas in Lemon we had considered whether a statute (1) has a secular purpose, (2) has a primary effect of advancing or inhibiting religion, or (3) creates an excessive entanglement between government and religion, see 403 U. S., at 612-613, in Agostini we modified Lemon for purposes of evaluating aid to schools and examined only the first and second factors, see 521 U. S., at 222-223.
rationale: Lemon is referenced as the origin of the three-part test for Establishment Clause cases, but the Acting Decision notes that Agostini modified Lemon for school aid cases. Lemon is not overruled or criticized, but its test is updated for the context at issue.

cited_decision: Rosenberger v. Rector & Visitors of University of Virginia
quote: Finally, in addition to relying on our decision in Zobrest and the Ninth Circuit’s decision in Walker, Judge Livaudais invoked Rosenberger v. Rector and Visitors of Univ. of Va., 615 U. S. 819 (1995), in which, a few months after Walker, we held that the Establishment Clause does not require a public university to exclude a student-run religious publication from assistance available to numerous other student-run publications.
rationale: Rosenberger is cited as a supporting precedent for the principle that the Establishment Clause does not require exclusion of religious entities from generally available public benefits. The Acting Decision treats it as good law and applies its reasoning.

cited_decision: Oregon Department of Fish & Wildlife v. Klamath Indian Tribe (1985)
quote: To attack the conclusion that the 1855 Treaty rogate the usufructuary rights guaranteed under the 1837 Treaty, the State relies primarily on our decision in Oregon Dept. of Fish and Wildlife v. Klamath Tribe, 473 U. S. 753 (1985). ... This understanding of the Tribe’s usufructuary rights under the 1864 Treaty — that those rights were exclusive, on-reservation rights — informed our conclusion that the Klamath Tribe did not retain any usufructuary rights on the land that it ceded in the 1901 agreement, land that was not part of the reservation. ... First, the Chippewa’s usufructuary rights under the 1837 Treaty existed independently of land ownership; they were neither tied to a *202 reservation nor exclusive. In contrast to Klamath, there is no background understanding of the rights to suggest that they are extinguished when title to the land is extinguished.
rationale: The Acting Decision explains that the facts and treaty language in Klamath are materially different from those in the present case, and thus the reasoning and result in Klamath do not control the outcome here.

quote: We interpret Indian treaties to give effect to the terms as the Indians themselves would have understood them. See Washington v. Washington State Commercial Passenger Fishing Vessel Assn., 443 U. S. 658, 675-676 (1979); United States v. Winans, 198 U. S. 371, 380-381 (1905).
rationale: Winans is cited as authority for the principle of treaty interpretation but is not analyzed or criticized; it is referenced to support a general interpretive approach.

quote: of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit affirmed. 124 F. 3d 904 (1997). Three parts of the Eighth Circuit’s decision are relevant here. ... Accordingly, the judgment of the Appeals for the Eighth Circuit is affirmed. It is so ordered.
rationale: The Acting Decision expressly affirms the judgment of the Eighth Circuit, adopting its reasoning and result.

quote: This case does not bear the weight the State places on it, however, because it has been qualified by later decisions of this Court. ... But Race Horse rested on a subsequent eases have made clear, an Indian tribe’s treaty rights to hunt, fish, and gather on state land are not irreconcilable with a State’s sovereignty over the natural resources in the State. ... Thus, contrary to the State’s contentions, Race Horse does not compel the conclusion that Minnesota’s admission to the Union extinguished Chippewa usufructuary rights guaranteed by the 1837 Treaty.
rationale: The Acting Decision disagrees with the reasoning and continuing authority of Race Horse, explaining that its rationale has been undermined by later cases.

cited_decision: Washington v. Washington State Commercial Passenger Fishing Vessel Assn. (1979)
quote: We interpret Indian treaties to give effect to the terms as the Indians themselves would have understood them. See Washington v. Washington State Commercial Passenger Fishing Vessel Assn., 443 U. S. 658, 675-676 (1979); United States v. Winans, 198 U. S. 371, 380-381 (1905). ... We have repeatedly reaffirmed state authority to impose reasonable and necessary nondiscriminatory regulations on Indian hunting, fishing, and gathering rights in the interest of conservation. See Puyallup Tribe v. Department of Game of Wash., 391 U. S. 392, 398 (1968); Washington v. Washington State Commercial Passenger Fishing Vessel Assn., 443 U. S., at 682 ; Antoine v. Washington, supra, at 207-208.
rationale: The decision is cited for general principles of treaty interpretation and state regulatory authority, but not analyzed or distinguished in detail.

cited_decision: Mille Lacs Band of Chippewa Indians v. Minnesota (1994)
quote: With respect to the 1850 Executive Order, the District Court held, in relevant part, that the order was unlawful because the President had no authority to order removal of the Chippewa without their consent. Id., at 823-826 . The District Court also concluded that the United States ultimately abandoned and repealed the removal policy embodied in the 1850 order. Id., at 829-830 . With respect to the 1855 Treaty, the District Court reviewed the historical record and found that the parties to that agreement did not intend to abrogate the usufructuary privileges guaranteed by the 1837 Treaty. Id., at 830-835 .
rationale: The Acting Decision summarizes the District Court's findings as background but does not analyze or critique its reasoning; it is referenced as part of the procedural history.

cited_decision: Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Sawyer (1952)
quote: The Court of Appeals began its analysis of this question with a statement of black letter law: “ ‘The President’s power, if any, to issue the order must stem either from an act of Con *189 gress or from the Constitution itself.’” 124 F. 3d, at 915 (quoting Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Sawyer, 343 U. S. 579, 585 (1952)).
rationale: Youngstown is cited for a general legal principle regarding presidential authority, not for its specific facts or holding.

cited_decision: New York Ex Rel. Kennedy v. Becker (1916)
quote: In New York ex rel. Kennedy v. (1916), the Court considered significantly different language. The Big Tree Treaty of 1797, as the agreement was known, provided that the Seneca were to retain “the privilege of fishing and hunting on the said tract of land” conveyed by the agreement. 7 Stat. 602 (emphasis added); see also 241 U. S., at 562 (quoting the reservation clause). ... The only fair reading of Kennedy is that the Treaty reserved for the Seneca a privilege in common with all persons to whom the State chose to extend fishing and hunting privileges.
rationale: Kennedy is discussed as an example of different treaty language and its interpretation, but the Acting Decision does not rely on or distinguish its holding for the present case.

quote: The conservation necessity standard appears to have its origin in Tulee v. Washington, 315 U. S. 681 (1942). In the 1859 Treaty with the Yakima Indians, the Yakima reserved “The right of taking fish at all usual and accustomed places, in common with citizens of the Territory.’ ” Id., at 683 (quoting 12 Stat. 953 ). The Court held that Washington State had the “power to impose on Indians, equally with others, such restrictions of a purely regulatory nature concerning the time and manner of fishing outside the reservation as are necessary for the conservation offish,” but that the Treaty foreclosed “the state from charging the Indians a fee of the kind in question.” 315 U. S., at 684 (emphasis added).
rationale: Tulee is cited as the origin of the conservation necessity standard, but the Acting Decision does not analyze or distinguish its holding in detail.

quote: We have held that Indian treaties are to be interpreted liberally in favor of the Indians, Washington v. Washington State Commercial Passenger Fishing Vessel Assn., 443 U. S., at 675-676 ; Choctaw Nation v. United States, 318 U. S., at 432 , and that any ambiguities are to be resolved in their favor, Winters v. United States, 207 U.S. 564, 576-577 (1908).
rationale: Winters is cited for the general principle that ambiguities in Indian treaties are to be resolved in favor of the Indians, not for its specific facts or holding.
